questions.text:
Which of the following methods are used for the detection of RNA?
  1. PCR
  2. Real-time PCR
  3. RT-PCR
  4. Northern blotting
  5. Western blotting
questions.solution:
The methods that can be used for the detection of RNA are northern blotting and RT-PCR (option D - 3, 4).

PCR (polymerase chain reaction) is a technique used to amplify a selected DNA sequence. It can be used to synthesize millions of copies of the selected DNA sequence in a few hours, enabling the detection of even trace amounts of DNA in a sample. Therefore, PCR is used for:

  • Detecting mutant DNA 
  • DNA fingerprinting for forensic analysis- Detection of DNA from small amounts of samples from the crime scene
  • Detection of latent viral infections
  • Carrier detection of cystic fibrosis

Real-time PCR is used for quantitation of the number of viruses present in a sample e.g. viral load in HIV or HBV. So, the treatment modalities can be planned and the response to treatment can be assessed.

RT-PCR or reverse transcriptase PCR is used for the detection of RNA. It can be used to quantitate mRNA levels by generating complementary DNA (cDNA) copies of the mRNA using the reverse transcriptase enzyme. 

The northern blot technique can also be used to detect RNAs. Here, the mixture of mRNA molecules is separated by electrophoresis and then transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane and hybridized with radiolabeled probes.

Western blot, also called immunoblots, is a technique used to study protein molecules. The proteins undergo electrophoresis and then are transferred to a membrane. These proteins are then tagged with the specific antibodies and visualized.

questions.text:
Nystagmus to the opposite side of the lesion occurs in ________.
  1. Purulent labyrinthitis
  2. Trauma to labyrinth
  3. Serous labyrinthitis
  4. Sectioning of VIII nerve
questions.solution:
Nystagmus to the opposite side of the lesion occurs in 1,2,4. 

  • Purulent labyrinthitis
  • Trauma to labyrinth
  • Sectioning of VIII nerve

Vestibular nystagmus has a slow and fast component. By convention, the latter denotes the direction of nystagmus. Paretic lesions such as purulent labyrinthitis, trauma to the labyrinth, and sectioning of the 8th nerve cause nystagmus to the healthy side. Serous labyrinthitis, which is an irritative lesion, leads to nystagmus on the same side of the lesion.

Nystagmus is a rhythmical, involuntary, and oscillatory movement of the eyes. It can be horizontal, vertical, or rotatory. It can be of two types:

  • Vestibular (peripheral) nystagmus due to a lesion of the labyrinth or eighth cranial nerve.
  • Central nystagmus is due to a lesion in the vestibular nuclei, brainstem, or cerebellum.

The following features can be used to differentiate between peripheral and central nystagmus. 

Nystagmus Peripheral lesion Central lesion
Latency 2-20 seconds No latency
Duration Less than one minute More than one minute
Direction Fixed Changes
Fatiguability Fatiguable Nonfatiguable
Associated symptoms Severe vertigo None or slight

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the oncogenic mechanism of human papilloma virus ?

choices.text: E6 binds to RB protein and displaces E2F
E7 binds to RB protein and displaces E2F
Tax protein leading to polyclonal expansion of T cells
L1 protein leading to clonal expansion of T cells

questions.solution:
The true statement is that E7 protein of human papilloma virus (HPV) binds to the hypophosphorylated RB protein and displaces the E2F transcription factors, thereby promoting G1/S transition.

RB gene is a key negative regulator of the cell cycle at the G1/S transition. RB gene exists in an active hypophosphorylated state in resting cells and in an inactive hyperphosphorylated state in cells undergoing G1/S transition.

E7 protein from the high-risk types of HPV (such as HPV 16) binds to the hypophosphorylated RB through the same pocket that RB uses to bind and sequester the E2F transcription factors, thereby displacing the E2F which leads to the progression of the cell cycle and thus the proliferation of tumor cells. E7 proteins also inactivate the CDK inhibitors p21 and p27. E7 proteins from high-risk HPVs (types 16,18 and 31) also bind and presumably activate cyclins  A and E.

Oncogenic activities of protein E6:

The E6 protein binds to and helps in the degradation of p53 and stimulates the expression of telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT), which is the catalytic subunit of telomerase, thereby helping in the longevity of the cells. E6 from high-risk HPV types has a higher affinity for p53 than E6 from low-risk types. 

Other options :

Option C: HTLV-1 encodes the viral protein Tax, which leads to polyclonal expansion of T cells. It exhibits tropism for CD4+ T cells.

Option D: L1 major capsid protein is useful in the formulation of HPV vaccines.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles form the structure marked as "X" in the image?
  1. First lumbrical
  2. First palmar interossei
  3. Second palmar interossei
  4. First dorsal interossei
  5. Second dorsal interossei
questions.solution:
The structure marked as "X" in the given image is the dorsal digital expansion (extensor expansion) of the index finger. It is formed by the 1st lumbrical, 1st dorsal interossei and 2nd palmar interossei, the extensor digitorum slip and extensor indicis.

Dorsal digital expansion/ Extensor expansion: It is a small triangular aponeurosis covering the dorsum of the proximal phalanx. It is formed by the expansion of extensor tendons (digital expansion). It is located in the back of the digits (dorsal). The extensors making the expansion are the extensor digitorum and extensor pollicis longus. The muscles joining the expansion are extensor digiti minimi, extensor indicis, and extensor pollicis brevis.

Extensor expansion triangular hood attachments: (The shape of expansion)   
The apex is attached to the distal phalanx. The central region is attached to the middle phalanx (in the thumb, attached to the proximal phalanx). The corner of the base is attached to the sides of the metacarpophalangeal joint (in the thumb, attached to muscles). The extensor hood is attached to the lumbricals, interossei, and extensor digitorum muscles (in the thumb, the adductor pollicis, and the abductor pollicis brevis muscles).

Wing tendons refer to the insertion of lumbricals and interossei to the corners of the dorsal digital expansion or simply extensor expansion.

 

The extensor expansion trifurcates into a central slip and two lateral slips which are inserted on the dorsum of the base of the middle phalanx and the dorsum of the base of the distal phalanx.

Extensor expansion

questions.text: Emptying of the stomach is inhibited by all of the following, except _____.
questions.solution:
Emptying of the stomach is not inhibited, but rather increased by the secretion of gastrin. Gastrin promotes emptying of the stomach by stimulating the motor functions of the stomach, especially the pyloric pump.

After food enters the duodenum, the duodenal entero-gastric nerve reflexes ensure the inhibition of emptying of the stomach. This mainly includes 3 pathways. They are, via the enteric nervous system directly from the duodenum, via extrinsic nerves that go to the prevertebral sympathetic ganglia and then back through the sympathetic fibres to the stomach and finally via the vagus nerve that inhibits the excitatory signals to the stomach at the level of the brainstem. These reflexes inhibit the pyloric pump propulsive contractions and also increase the tone of the pyloric sphincter.

Gastrin is a hormone secreted by G cells located in the pyloric glands of the stomach. It is released into the blood, following which it is transported to the enterochromaffin-like cells of the stomach, resulting in the release of histamine, which stimulates gastric hydrochloric acid secretion.

Other options:

Option A: Increased acidity of chyme inhibits the emptying of the stomach by irritating the entero-gastric inhibitory reflexes of the duodenum. It prevents the subsequent release of stomach contents into the duodenum until the acidic chyme that is already present is neutralised.

Option B: Distension of the duodenum inhibits the emptying of the stomach via the enteric nervous system.

Option C: Cholecystokinin secretion decreases the motility of the stomach as a result of its inhibitory effect on gastrin. It is a hormone that is released from the mucosa of the jejunum and is sensitive to the presence of fats in the duodenum.

questions.text: While performing an elective hernia repair, the surgeon notices that the person has a pantaloon hernia. Which of the following features is found in this hernia?

choices.text: Content of the sac is a derivative of the vitellointestinal duct
The defect is in the aponeurosis of the transversus abdominis muscle
Herniation occurs through the pleuroperitoneal foramen
Both direct and indirect hernias present

questions.solution:
Both direct and indirect hernias are present on the same side of the groin in a pantaloon hernia. The hernia is named pantaloon because the two hernia sacs are divided by epigastric vessels, so they look like a pair of pants.

Other options:

Option A: Content of the sac is a derivative of the vitellointestinal duct (Meckel's diverticulum) is seen in Littre's hernia. 

Option B: The defect is in the aponeurosis of the transversus abdominis muscle. The aponeurosis is also called the Spigelian fascia. A Spigelian hernia occurs through slit-like defects in the anterior abdominal wall adjacent to the semilunar line. It is also called spontaneous lateral ventral hernia or hernia of the semilunar line. 

Option C: Bochdalek hernia (posterior) is the most common type of diaphragmatic hernia. Herniation occurs through the pleuroperitoneal foramen.

Related Pearl: Modified Gilbert's classification of hernia

Type 1 Indirect hernia with peritoneal sac passing through an intact internal ring that will not admit 1 fingerbreadth (ie,<1 cm.); the posterior wall is intact.

Type 2 Indirect hernia (the most common indirect hernia) with peritoneal sac coming through a 1-fingerbreadth internal ring (ie, ≤2 cm.); the posterior wall is intact.

Type 3 Indirect hernia with peritoneal sac coming through a 2-fingerbreadth or wider internal ring (ie, >2 cm.).They are frequently complete and often have a sliding component. They begin to break down a portion of the posterior wall just medial to the internal ring.

Type 4 Direct hernia with full floor posterior wall breakdown or multiple defects in the posterior wall. The internal ring is intact, and there is no peritoneal sac.

Type 5 Direct hernia with a diverticular defect. There is no peritoneal sac and the internal ring remains intact.

Type 6 Both direct and indirect inguinal hernia (a pantaloon hernia)

Type 7  Femoral hernia.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman presents with irregular vaginal bleeding for the past 4 months. She is not on any medications and has a family history of endometrial cancer. On transvaginal ultrasound, the endometrial thickness is 2 mm but a focal area shows 5 mm of endometrial thickness. Which of the following is the gold standard test to diagnose the cause of bleeding in this patient?

choices.text: Fractional curettage of the endometrium and endocervix
Dilatation and curettage of the endometrium
Endometrial sampling using Pipelle/ vabra aspirator

questions.solution:
In the given scenario of postmenopausal bleeding, the transvaginal ultrasound shows a focal area with 5 mm of endometrial thickness. The gold standard investigation for focal lesions causing post-menopausal bleeding is hysteroscopic inspection and selective biopsy. 

In the given scenario the overall endometrial thickness is 2 mm. However, if the overall endometrial thickness would be >4 mm, then the gold standard investigation would be fractional curettage or dilatation and curettage. Since the question only mentions a focal abnormality, hysteroscopy and selective biopsy is a better choice for this patient. 

Menopause is defined as the absence of menstruation for one year after the age of 40 years. But it is usually seen around 45 to 47 years of age. Any vaginal bleeding that occurs after menopause or even after just 6 months of amenorrhea in menopausal age group women is defined as postmenopausal bleeding. 

All postmenopausal women with unexpected uterine bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial carcinoma. Investigations used for diagnosing the cause of postmenopausal bleeding:

Outpatient procedures - 

  • Transvaginal ultrasound is the first-line investigation that checks for endometrial thickness. An endometrial thickness of >4mm calls for further investigation by endometrial biopsy.
  • Endometrial sampling using Pipelle aspirator - aspiration of the uterine cavity and sending the sample for histopathological examination. It is used as a screening test in menopausal women on HRT or tamoxifen.

Inpatient procedures - 

  • Fractional curettage (dilatation and curettage) of the endometrial and the endocervical tissue helps to know the site of malignancy, the extent of spread, and also staging of the tumor. It is the best test to perform if cancer is suspected as the cause of bleeding. This requires general anesthesia.
  • Hysteroscopic inspection & selective biopsy is the gold standard procedure to diagnose focal endometrial lesions. It can be performed as an outpatient procedure as well.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

questions.text:
Which of the following findings would be consistent with a diagnosis of Chediak-Higashi syndrome?

1. Giant inclusions in polymorphonuclear neutrophils
2. Peripheral Neuropathy
3. Oculocutaneous hyperpigmentation
4. Recurrent pyogenic infections
questions.solution:
The findings consistent with Chediak-Higashi syndrome are represented by Statements 1, 2, 4 (Option D):

  • Giant inclusions in polymorphonuclear neutrophils,
  • progressive intellectual decline
  • recurrent pyogenic infections.
  • Oculocutaneous hypopigmentation (not hyperpigmentation)

Chediak-Higashi syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to the loss of function of the LYST gene (Lysosomal trafficking regulator gene)- a protein required for the normal packaging and distribution of granules. This defect results in defective chemotaxis, phagolysosome fusion, degranulation of T-cells and NK cells, and ADP granule function in platelets.

Clinical features occur due to defective transport of cell products. These are neutropenia, significant pyogenic infections, oculo-cutaneous albinism (due to abnormalities of melanocytes), neurological abnormalities (peripheral neuropathy, progressive intellectual decline, cranial nerve palsies, decreased deep tendon reflexes, tremor, abnormal gait, nerve cell dysfunction), and bleeding.

The image below shows Wright-Giemsa staining of a peripheral blood smear showing polymorphonuclear leukocytes with abundant giant intracytoplasmic granules.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true of the baroreceptor reflex pathway?

1. Rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) is inhibited by gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA).
2. Caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) releases GABA.
3. Nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) releases GABA.
4. RVLM releases GABA.
questions.solution:
The correct statements are 1, 2.

RVLM (Rostral ventrolateral medulla) is inhibited by GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) and CVLM (Caudal ventrolateral medulla) releases GABA.

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors in the walls of the heart and blood vessels. Baroreceptors are stimulated by the stretching of the walls of the respective vessels when there is an increased volume or pressure in the vessel. They are important in the immediate management of blood pressure. 

The afferents from the baroreceptors activate NTS which in turn activates CVLM. The CVLM, on activation, releases gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) which is inhibitory to the RVLM. The RVLM is the major excitatory source of the sympathetic nervous system. As it is inhibited, there is sympathetic inhibition thus reducing the blood pressure.

The NTS also simultaneously activates the vagal motor neurons causing bradycardia.

 

The receptors of arterial circulation include the carotid sinus, which is present in the adventitia of the internal carotid artery just above the bifurcation of the common carotid. Afferent nerve innervation is by a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve called the carotid sinus nerve.  Aortic arch - present in the adventitia of the walls of the arch of the aorta. Afferent innervation is by the vagus nerve called the aortic depressor nerve.

The receptors of low-pressure system/ cardiopulmonary receptors are atrial receptors and pulmonary circulation receptors.

Atrial receptors are present in the walls of the right and left atria near the opening of the superior and inferior vena cava and pulmonary veins.

questions.text: Blackfoot disease as shown in the image below is associated with chronic poisoning by:
questions.solution:
The image above shows keratosis of the palms and blackfoot disease in a woman. These features are seen in chronic arsenic poisoning.

Blackfoot disease is a gangrenous condition affecting the limbs. This was especially seen in diabetic patients consuming water contaminated with arsenic for long durations. It occurs due to the hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries.

questions.text: Identify the correct statement about the information obtained from the vaccine vial monitor 14 (VVM14) shown in the image below.

choices.text: It takes 14 days for the inner square to become darker than outer circle
It takes 14 days for the inner square and outer circle to reach the same color
The vaccine can be used for 14 days after the inner square and outer circle reach the same color
The vaccine can be used for 14 days after the outer circle color  becomes darker

questions.solution:
The correct statement is option 2.

The given scenario mentions VVM 14 (vaccine vial monitor 14), where 14 indicates the VVM number. It is the time in days for the inner square to reach the color of the outer circle when the vial is exposed to a constant temperature of 37°C. This color change signifies the discard point of the vial.

Vaccine Vial Monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators that are routinely used to monitor vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain. It records cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.

There are currently 4 types of VVMs, they are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccines based on the VVM number. 

  • VVM 30: High Stability
  • VVM 14: Medium Stability
  • VVM 7: Moderate Stability
  • VVM 2: Least Stable

If the color of the inner square is the same or is darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to high temperatures and should be discarded.

Purpose of VVMs:

  • Ensures that vaccines damaged by heat are not administered
  • Decision on which vaccines to be kept after a cold chain break occurs, minimizing unnecessary vaccine wastage
  • Decision on which vaccine is to be used first. Vaccines showing significant heat exposure should be used before those that show lower heat exposure, even if their expiry date is longer

There are two different locations for VVMs :

  • On the label of the vaccine: The vaccine vial, once opened, can be kept for subsequent immunization sessions for up to 28 days, regardless of the formulation of the product
  • In a location other than on the label (e.g., cap or neck of ampoule): The vaccine vial, once opened should be discarded at the end of the immunization session or within six hours of opening, whichever comes first, regardless of the formulation of the product

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is amiloride.

Amiloride belongs to the K+-sparing diuretic group. It is a renal epithelial Na+ channel(ENac) inhibitor in collecting duct cells. Lithium enters through the ENac and inhibits the action of the anti-diuretic hormone. Amiloride blocks the entry of Li+ ion through the ENac and thus mitigates diabetes insipidus induced by lithium.

The most important adverse effect of amiloride is hyperkalemia. Other adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, and headache.

Other options:

Option A: Demeclocycline belongs to the tetracycline group of antibiotics. It interferes with the anti-diuretic hormone action but is used in the treatment of the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone(SIADH). 

Option B: Thiazide diuretics inhibit the Na+-Cl- symport present in the distal convoluted tubule of the nephron. It is used in the treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus by decreasing the ability of the kidney to excrete free water. It increases the reabsorption of water in the proximal tubule and reduces the ability of the distal tubule to dilute the urine. 

Option C: Tolvaptan is a vasopressin antagonist used in the treatment of SIADH, hypervolemic and euvolemic hyponatremia.

questions.text: An elderly man is admitted with deep vein thrombosis in his left leg. He is a known case of hypertension and chronic kidney disease (creatinine clearance - 29 mL/min). Which of the following will you prescribe for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Unfractionated heparin is to be prescribed to manage this patient's condition. Heparin is cleared and degraded primarily by the reticuloendothelial system and only a tiny amount appears in the urine. Hence, it is safe to be used in patients with renal impairment/ chronic kidney disease.

Heparin, low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), and fondaparinux have no intrinsic anticoagulant activity. These agents accelerate the action of anti-thrombin. Heparin binds to anti-thrombin and brings about a conformational change in anti-thrombin that accelerates the inhibition of factor Xa (anti-thrombin inhibits activated coagulation factors, especially thrombin and factor Xa).

Heparin, LMWH, and fondaparinux - can be used in the initial management of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism, unstable angina, and in acute myocardial infarction.

Heparin and LMWH are used in select patients with disseminated intravascular coagulation and coronary balloon angioplasty with or without stent placement to prevent thrombosis. Fondaparinux is contraindicated due to the risk of catheter thrombosis.

Heparin is the agent of choice for cardiopulmonary bypass surgeries.

Heparin, LMWH, and fondaparinux do not cross the placenta and hence are safe to use in pregnancy. The drugs may be discontinued 24 hours before delivery to minimize postpartum hemorrhage.

Other options :

Options B & C: Low molecular weight heparin and fondaparinux are both smaller molecules and are cleared almost exclusively by kidneys. These drugs can accumulate in patients with renal impairment and lead to bleeding. Both these drugs are contraindicated in patients whose creatinine clearance is below 30 mL/min. 

Option D: Rivaroxaban toxicity is increased in patients with renal impairment or severe hepatic dysfunction and should be avoided in these patients.

Related Pearl: Heparin vs. LMWH vs. Fondaparinux

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about G banding?

choices.text: Silver salts are used for staining
Staining pattern is specific for each chromosome

questions.solution:
The true statement about G banding is that the staining pattern is specific for each chromosome. 

G banding is a technique for the identification of chromosomes and their abnormalities. In this technique, chromosomes are stained using Giemsa stain. It is the most common technique used in cytogenetics to produce a visible karyotype.

G banding is based on differential staining of the GC-rich and AT-rich areas of the chromosome. Heterochromatin regions which are AT-rich DNA and relatively gene-poor stain more darkly. Whereas, euchromatin regions that are GC-rich (and more transcriptionally active) incorporate less Giemsa stain and appear as light bands in G-banding. 

The image below shows the G banding of chromosomes.

 

Various techniques are used in karyotyping to study chromosomes. Staining with various compounds produces various results and helps us to understand the chromosomes better.

Common techniques used are:

  • Q banding - fluorescence staining with quinacrine mustard
  • G banding - Giemsa staining after partial denaturation of chromatin
  • R banding - reverse Giemsa staining. In this, the light and dark areas are reversed
  • C banding - staining of heterochromatin with silver salts
  • T banding - staining the telomeres of chromosomes

C banding: Heterochromatin includes non-coding regions of DNA, such as centromeric regions. The staining of these constitutive heterochromatins is done by C-banding using silver salt staining. A dicentric chromosome having two centromeres can hence be identified by C banding.

The given image shows C banding:

 

The given image shows R banding:

 

The given image shows Q banding:

 

The given image shows NOR banding:

Banding type Staining method
G-banding (Most common) Giemsa stain

questions.text: What is the next step in excitation-contraction coupling after the power stroke in skeletal muscle contraction?

choices.text: Cessation of calcium release from sarcoplasm
Attachment of ATP to myosin head

questions.solution:
In excitation-contraction coupling, the next step after the power stroke is the attachment of ATP to the myosin head. 

Muscle contraction occurs by sliding the thin filament over the thick filament. The sequence of events is as follows: 

  • Troponin I is bound to actin and tropomyosin. In a resting muscle, it covers the sites where actin interacts with myosin heads. The myosin head contains a tightly bound adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and an inorganic phosphate (Pi).
  • Following an action potential, Calcium ions (Ca2+) are released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum and cytosolic Ca2+ is increased. Simultaneously Ca2+ influx also happens through the voltage-gated Ca2+ channels.
  • The free Ca2+ binds with troponin C. This binding will weaken the troponin I interaction with actin and exposes the actin-binding site for myosin.
  • This results in the formation of myosin-actin cross-bridges.
  • The cross-bridge between the head of myosin and the active site of actin causes a conformational change in the head. This leads to the power stroke, which moves the thin filament relative to the thick filament. 
  • A new ATP molecule binds to the free site on myosin. The ATP is further hydrolyzed to ADP and phosphate ions. The binding of the new ATP molecule to the free site on myosin causes detachment of the head of myosin from actin. 
  • This causes a re-cocking of myosin head which completes the cycle. 

Related Pearl: Sarcomere

questions.text: A 31-year-old patient presented to the casualty with severe upper abdominal pain and recurrent retching without vomiting. A nasogastric tube insertion was tried but it was unsuccessful. His X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is most likely present in the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and X-ray showing a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen are suggestive of gastric volvulus. Borchardt's triad will most likely be present in a case of gastric volvulus.

Gastric volvulus is the rotation of the gastric fundus occurring on the longitudinal (organoaxial) or vertical (mesenteroaxial) axis of the stomach. This occurs due to the laxity in the peritoneal attachment of the stomach.

The Borchardt triad comprises:

  • Sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain
  • Recurrent retching with minimal vomitus
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube

Organoaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the longitudinal axis of the stomach It is the most common type and often occurs acutely. It is associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

Mesenteroaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the vertical axis. It is partial (<180 degrees) and recurrent. It is not associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

 

Radiograph images shows a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen due to rotation of gastric fundus on the axis of the stomach. Gastric volvulus can be confirmed by a barium study. In barium study, the stomach may be inverted with greater curvature above the lesser curvature, or as the pylorus above the cardia. 

Emergency surgery is indicated for acute volvulus which includes decompression, reduction, and prevention of recurrence. The surgical intervention includes simple gastropexy with diaphragmatic hernia repair. 

Other options:

Option B- Dieulafoy’s triad is seen in acute appendicitis. It comprises of hypersensitiveness of skin, reflex muscular contraction, tenderness at Mc Burney’s point.

Option C- Quincke's triad is seen in hemobilia. It comprises upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage, abdominal pain, and obstructive jaundice.

Option D- Saint's triad comprises hiatus hernia, gallstones, and colonic diverticulosis.

questions.text:
A newborn presenting with which of the following signs can be managed in a newborn stabilization unit (NBSU)?
  1. Respiratory rate of 60-70/min without grunting or retractions
  2. Sepsis who are hemodynamically stable
  3. Hypothermic who are hemodynamically unstable
  4. Jaundiced who requires phototherapy
questions.solution:
Newborns with signs mentioned in statements 1, 2, and 4 can be managed in NBSU. A hemodynamically unstable newborn should be transferred to a special newborn care unit.

Newborns that can be managed at NBSU:

  • Newborns with respiratory distress, having respiratory rates 60-70/min without grunting or retractions for observation and oxygen therapy
  • Newborns with gestational age less than 34 weeks, weight less than 1800 gms, for observation and assisted feeding
  • Newborns with hypothermia and hyperthermia who are hemodynamically stable 
  • Newborns who require phototherapy for jaundice
  • Newborns with sepsis and hemodynamically stable for antibiotic therapy

The IMNCI has set up SNCUs at district hospitals, stabilization units at CHCs, and newborn care corners at all facilities offering delivery facilities.  The facilities available at different levels of Newborn Care Centers are as follows:

  Newborn care corner Newborn stabilization unit Special newborn care units
Present in Delivery room of all centers and hospitals Within or close to the maternity ward, in CHCs and first referral units District hospitals and facilities with >3000 deliveries/ year
Admits Immediate care to all newborns Sick and LBW >1800 gms Sick and LBW< 1800 gms

 

Neonates undergo quick screening for signs which helps to sort sick neonates according to emergency, priority, and non-urgent. Triage of sick newborn is done according to the signs observed as follows:

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman has been diagnosed with lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) on an excisional biopsy. What are the options for managing this patient?
  1. Close observation
  2. Tamoxifen
  3. Radiotherapy
  4. Local excision
  5. Bilateral mastectomy
questions.solution:
The options for managing a patient with lobular carcinoma in situ include close observation, tamoxifen, and bilateral mastectomy (Option D- 1, 2, and 5).

Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is a benign condition with an increased risk of invasive breast cancer. Treatment options for LCIS include close observation and screening, chemoprevention with tamoxifen, and prophylactic bilateral mastectomy.

LCIS is usually bilateral and multicentric and presents as an incidental finding on excisional biopsy. Invasive breast cancer develops in 25% to 35% of women with LCIS. Invasive cancer may develop in either breast, regardless of which breast harbored the initial focus of LCIS. 

Histological features of lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS):

  • LCIS originates from the terminal duct lobular units and is characterized by the distention and distortion of the terminal duct lobular units.
  • Cytoplasmic mucoid globules (signet-ring cells) are a distinctive cellular feature.
  • Neighborhood calcification is a feature that is unique to LCIS and contributes to its diagnosis.

The slide below shows cytoplasmic mucoid globules seen in lobular carcinoma in situ:

 

Management options include:

  • Close observation and screening (as the annual cancer risk is 1%)
  • Chemoprevention with tamoxifen (if ER/PR+)- 55% risk reduction
  • Prophylactic bilateral mastectomy (if high-risk patient)

There is no role of local excision, axillary dissection, radiotherapy, or chemotherapy.

questions.text:
Match the following slides of the causative organisms with their systemic mycosis.

             I. Valley fever

            II. Darling's disease

           III. Brazilian blastomycosis 

            IV. North American blastomycosis
questions.solution:
The correct answer is a-II, b-IV, c-I, d-III

a- Histoplasma II- Darling's disease
b- Blastomyces IV- North American blastomycosis
c- Coccidioides I- Valley fever
d- Para-coccidioidomycosis III- Brazilian blastomycosis 

Slide-a shows tiny oval yeast cells with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response suggestive of Histoplasma capsulatum that causes histoplasmosis/ Darling's disease/ reticuloendotheliosis.

Patients present with fever, cough, anorexia, and lymphadenopathy. X-ray of the chest shows focal infiltrates and patchy opacities. Aspiration from lymph nodes shows the presence of intracellular yeast.

Slide-b showing thick-walled round yeast cells with single broad-based budding depicting the figure of 8 appearance is suggestive of Blastomyces dermatitidis that causes North American blastomycosis. 

It is mostly seen in North America and is contracted through the inhalation of contaminated soil. Primary infection usually presents as pneumonia.  Chest X-ray reveals consolidation. Disseminated disease may lead to multiple abscesses. Cutaneous lesions present as papules and nodules which progress into large ulcerative lesions.

Slide-c showing mature spherules which are large sac-like structures filled with endospores is suggestive of Coccidioides immitis that causes Valley Fever.

Patients present with fever, cough, and severe fatigue. They may complain of night sweats and pleuritic chest pain. Chest X-ray shows mediastinal lymphadenopathy. It is most commonly seen in travelers to the southwestern USA.

Slide-d showing round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferentially giving rise to mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance is suggestive of Paracoccidioidomycosis brasiliensis that causes Brazilian blastomycosis/ South American blastomycosis/ Paracoccidioidal granuloma.

Patients present with fever, fatigue, and weight loss. On examination, multiple oral lesions and hepatosplenomegaly are noted. Granulomas are seen on a biopsy of the affected tissues.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text:
A young man complains of occasional cough and blood in the sputum, myalgia, and joint pains. He also reports having noticed blood in his urine for the past several days. He has a history of chronic sinusitis, and examination revealed nasal ulcerations. The investigations and the chest radiograph are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Pulmonary tissue biopsy: Vasculitis and necrotizing granulomas
Serology: Positive for ANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies)
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis). The patient shows the involvement of the upper respiratory tract (chronic sinusitis), lower respiratory tract (occasional hemoptysis and cavity in the radiograph), renal system (blood in the urine), and the presence of ANCA antibodies and necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis.

It is a granulomatous, necrotizing vasculitis of the small vessels that mainly affects both the upper and lower respiratory tracts and glomerulonephritis.

  • Upper respiratory tract presents with sinusitis, otitis media, and nasal septal perforation.
  • Lower respiratory tract presents with hemoptysis, dyspnea, and cough.
  • Glomerulonephritis presents with proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension. Initially, it appears as focal or segmental glomerulonephritis on biopsy. If this is left untreated, it leads to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

Apart from these organs, the disease can also affect the eye and skin. Skin lesions present as palpable purpura or subcutaneous nodules.

Laboratory investigations will show anemia, leucocytosis, elevated ESR, and ANCA positivity. Chest radiograph will show multiple bilateral cavitating nodules and pulmonary infiltrates. 

The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis on biopsy. Pulmonary tissue is preferred for biopsy other tissues are obtained from the skin and upper airways and rarely in the kidneys.

Other options:

Option A: Henoch-Schönlein purpura is seen mainly in children. They present with polyarthralgia, colicky abdominal pain, blood and mucus per rectum, hematuria, etc. A skin biopsy will show leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA and C3 deposition by immunofluorescence.

Option B: Microscopic polyangiitis predominantly affects capillaries, venules, and small and medium-sized arteries. In addition to symptoms like fever and body pains, they can have hemoptysis, glomerulonephritis, mononeuritis multiplex, etc. However, upper respiratory tract involvement and pulmonary nodules are rarely seen in this condition, and a biopsy will show vasculitis without any granulomas.

Option D: Takayasu arteritis is the inflammation of the medium to large-sized arteries. It mainly affects the aortic arch and its branches. The most commonly affected artery is the subclavian artery. Patients will present with features of arm claudication, Raynaud's phenomenon, etc. They can also present with syncope, transient ischemic attack, abdominal pain, or chest pain, depending on the arteries involved. A biopsy of the affected artery will show panarteritis with mononuclear cell infiltrates and occasionally giant cells.

questions.text:
A baby was born at 33 weeks of gestation by cesarean delivery. After 3 hours he was found to have cyanosis, tachypnea, and grunting. Auscultation revealed decreased air entry into the lungs. Chest radiograph was performed and it showed the following finding. Which of the following is true regarding the substance that is deficient in this baby?
  1. It is produced mainly by type I alveolar cells
  2. It contains phosphatidylcholine
  3. It also prevents pulmonary oedema
  4. Ceramide is the main component
  5. Steroids increase its production
questions.solution:
Statements 2, 3, and 5 are true regarding surfactant.

A preterm baby is showing features of respiratory distress along with the radiograph showing increased homogenous opacification of the lungs. This is suggestive of respiratory distress syndrome which occurs due to the deficiency of surfactant. 

Surfactant lines the alveoli of the lungs. It is secreted by the type II alveolar epithelial cells. It contains phospholipids, triglycerides, cholesterol, and fatty acids. Phosphatidylcholine is the major phospholipid. Other phospholipids are phosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine (PE), sphingomyelin (SM), phosphatidylinositol (PI), and phosphatidylserine. Ceramide is not a major component of surfactants. Important proteins are surfactant protein (SP)- A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D.

The important function is to reduce the surface tension of the alveoli. The pressure required for the expansion of alveoli is directly proportional to the surface tension present over the alveolar sacs. Surfactant reduces this surface tension and thereby reduces the pressure required to expand lungs. It also prevents pulmonary oedema.

Surfactant production starts around 20 weeks of life and peaks at 35 weeks gestation. Therefore, any neonate less than 35 weeks is prone to develop RDS.

 Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS):

RDS is common in preterm babies less than 34 weeks of gestation. It occurs due to the deficiency of the surfactant in the alveoli. Decreased surfactant increases the surface tension over the alveoli which makes the alveoli to collapse easily. Therefore, the baby has to put more effort to expand the lungs. This results in respiratory distress and hypoxemia. Ischemic damage to the alveoli causes the transudation of proteins into the alveoli that form the hyaline membrane.

It usually occurs in the first few hours of life. The babies will have tachypnea, grunting, retractions, cyanosis and decreased air entry. Chest radiograph will show reticulogranular pattern, ground-glass opacity, low lung volume, air bronchogram and white-out lungs in severe disease.

Mild to moderate RDS can be managed with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). CPAP is a noninvasive modality of support where a continuous distending pressure (5-7 cm H20) is applied at the nostril level to keep the alveoli open in a spontaneously breathing baby. Severe cases will require mechanical ventilation.

Steroids increase the production of the surfactant and therefore steroids are administered antenatally to mothers with preterm labour.

Related Pearl: Pulmonary Surfactant Composition

Constituents

Percentage

Phospholipids, mainly dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC)

70% to 80%

Proteins

10%

Neutral lipids

10%

Related Pearl: Radiologic features of the major respiratory distress disorders in newborns

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Symmetric ground-glass opacity (reticulogranular pattern)
  • Air bronchogram
  • White-out lung (severe disease)

Chest radiograph (A) on Day 2: shows reticulogranular opacities throughout both lungs with prominent air bronchograms. The cardiac silhouette is preserved and both lungs are hypoaerated.

Chest radiograph (B) on Day 9 (untreated): shows more severe changes. There is obliteration of the cardiac and diaphragmatic contours due to marked opacification, giving a complete ‘white out’ appearance

  • Patchy infiltrates
  • Coarse streaking

questions.text: Which of the following markers is seen in cyclin D1 negative mantle cell lymphoma?
questions.solution:
SOX 11 is a  marker seen in cyclin D1 negative mantle cell lymphoma.

Mantle cell lymphoma is seen in the fifth and sixth decades of life and has a male predominance. It is characterized by painless lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly.

In some cases, there is multifocal mucosal involvement of the small bowel and colon known as lymphomatoid polyposis.

It has (11;14) translocation. 

Lymph node biopsy shows nodal tumour cells surrounding reactive germinal centres. A homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft (cleaved) nuclear contours is typically seen.

Large cells resembling centroblasts and proliferation centres are absent, distinguishing mantle cell lymphoma from follicular lymphoma and CLL/SLL, respectively.

Other markers include:

  • CD 5, CD19 and CD20 +ve.
  • CD 23 -ve.
  • Moderately high levels of surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with κ or λ light chain) can be used to differentiate between CLL.

The IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation, supporting an origin from a naive B cell.

Other options:

Option A: Annexin A1 is a distinct marker for hairy cell leukaemia.

Option B: Mutated MYD88 is associated with lymphoplasmacytic leukaemia.

Option C: LC3 is increased in autophagy and is useful for identifying cells undergoing autophagy.

questions.text: Cape distribution of sensory deficit is seen in ____.
questions.solution:
Cape distribution of sensory deficit is seen in central cord syndrome. 

Central cord syndrome results from selective damage to the gray matter nerve cells crossing spinothalamic tracts surrounding the central canal. The main etiologies include spinal trauma, syringomyelia, and intrinsic cord tumors.

In the cervical cord, the central cord syndrome is characterised by:

  • Arm weakness out of proportion to leg weakness
  • Dissociated sensory loss i.e. loss of pain and temperature sensations over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk (cape distribution)
  • Preservation of light touch, joint position, and vibration sense in the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk

Other options: 

Option A: Brown Sequard syndrome is characterized by a contralateral sensory deficit.

Option C: Anterior spinal artery syndrome typically presents as loss of motor function and pain/temperature sensation, with relative sparing of proprioception and vibratory sense below the level of the lesion.

Option D: Foramen magnum syndrome is characterised by an around-the-clock pattern of weakness.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented with midline swelling of the neck and complains of loss of weight. She mentioned that her mother died of thyroid cancer at the age of 40 years. The tissue sample shows apple green birefringence on Congo red staining. What could be the probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario indicates thyroid swelling and apple green birefringence on Congo red staining indicates amyloid deposition. These features point to a diagnosis of medullary carcinoma of thyroid. 

Medullary carcinoma of thyroid is a familial malignancy of thyroid associated with localized amyloid deposition. It is also a part of multiple endocrine neoplasm type 2 ( MEN type 2 ) syndrome which occurs due to point mutation in RET gene. 

Localized amyloidosis is the presence of amyloid deposits confined to a single organ. The diagnosis can be confirmed by histological demonstration of amyloid deposits in tissues. Congo red staining can also aid in the diagnosis of amyloidosis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient is being evaluated for infertility. His semen analysis shows a sperm concentration of 10 million/ml, pH of 7.5, and volume of 2 mL. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The semen analysis showing a sperm concentration of 10 million/mL (<15 million/mL), and normal pH and volume are suggestive of oligozoospermia. 

According to the WHO 2010 criteria for semen analysis, the lower reference limit for normal sperm concentration is 15 million/mL. Oligozoospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL, and counts <5 million/mL are considered severe.

Other options: 

Option A: Normozoospermia refers to normal values of all ejaculate parameters. 

Option C: Azoospermia refers to no spermatozoa in the ejaculate. 

Option D: Aspermia refers to no semen. 

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria (2022)

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

Semen analysis Normal reference value and minimal reference (in parenthesis) limit
Volume 2ml or more (1.4ml)
pH 7.2-7.8
Viscosity Less than 3
Sperm concentration 20 million/ml (15 million/ml)
Total sperm count More than 40 million/ejaculate
Motility More than 50% progressive forward motility(Progressive motility = 30%)
Morphology More than 4% normal form (lower reference limit)
Forward progression >2 (Scale of 0-4)
Viability 54% or more living
Leucocytes Less than 1 million/ml
Round cells Less than 5 million/ml
Sperm agglutination Less than 10 spermatozoa with adherent particles (<2)

Related Pearl: Causes of Male Infertility

Pre-testicular causes:

Endocrine cause

  • Gonadotropin deficiency
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperprolactinemia

Psychosexual

  • Impotence
  • Erectile dysfunction

Drugs

  • Antihypertensives
  • Antipsychotics

Genetics

  • 47XXY
  • Y chromosome deletions

Testicular causes:

  • Immotile cilia syndrome
  • Cryptorchidism
  • Orchitis (mumps, Tb, gonorrhoea, traumatic)
  • Toxins(Drugs,radiation)
  • Primary testicular failure
  • Sertoli cell-only syndrome
  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia

Post-testicular causes:

Obstruction of efferent duct 

Congenital

  • Absence of Vas deferens
  • Youngs syndrome

Acquired (Inflammatory block)

  • Tuberculosis
  • Gonorrhea

Surgical

  • Vasectomy

Others

  • Ejaculatory failure
  • Bladder neck surgery
  • Retrograde ejaculation

questions.text: A young man is rushed to the emergency department after suffering a stab wound over the chest wall. The entry wound is present on the left side in the mid-axillary line. The lung is likely to be injured if the entry wound is above which level?
questions.solution:
The lung is likely to be injured if the entry wound is above the 8th rib. The lower border of the lung in the midaxillary line is at the level of the 8th rib. Hence, if the entry wound is above or at this level, the lung may be injured.

Related Pearl: Surface marking for Lungs and Pleura

Level

Lower border of lung (2 ribs higher)

Mid-clavicular line

8th rib

6th rib

Mid-axillary line

10th rib

8th rib

Paravertebral line

12th rib

10th rib

questions.text: Linear nodules with discharging sinuses along the course of the lymphatic tract are typically seen in patients with _____.
questions.solution:
Linear nodules and discharging sinuses along the course of the lymphatic tract are classical of sporotrichosis. Sporotrichosis is an acute or chronic fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii and closely related species.

S. schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous disease, by traumatic inoculation into the skin. This is usually followed by spread along the draining lymphatics and lymph nodes. 

It is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It is in the yeast phase in tissues and in cultures at 37°C, and in the mycelia phase in nature and cultures at 25°C. When it is cultured, the colonies are blackish-brown and fuzzy. The organism produces branching, septate hyphae, and microconidia clustered at the ends of conidiophores. It exists as cigar-shaped yeast cells. Stains used for identifying yeast forms: 

  • Gomori methenamine silver-cell wall appears black
  • Periodic acid-Schiff stain- cell wall appears red 
  • Fluorescent antibody staining

Clinical features: The initial infection develops as a nodule, which may break down to form a necrotic or ulcerative lesion. If untreated, the disease progresses and new nodules develop along the lymphatics leading to a chain of nodules. Less commonly, it may also cause systemic infection following inhalation, which causes local pulmonary disease or may lead to widely disseminated lesions in joints, meninges, and skin.

Treatment: Itraconazole is the drug of choice for lympho-cutaneous sporotrichosis, also terbinafine can be used. A saturated solution of potassium iodide (SSKI) is a second-line drug.

Other options:

Option A: Lichen planus is characterised by purple polygonal, flat-topped papules.

Option C: Pemphigus is characterised by flaccid superficial blisters.

Option D: Psoriasis is characterised by erythematous plaques with silvery-white scales.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought in by her mother. On examination, the child appears emaciated and her feet and ankles show an extensive, pruritic maculopapular rash. Blood examination reveals a hemoglobin of 6 g/dL and the peripheral blood smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia. Identify the egg belonging to the causative organism.
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of chronic hookworm infection (caused by A. duodenale or N. americanus) and image 4 shows the hookworm egg.

Features of the hookworm egg:

  • Oval/ elliptical with a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane.
  • Not bile stained.
  • Floats in a saturated salt solution.
  • Contains a segmented ovum, usually with 4-8 blastomeres when passed in the faeces.
  • A clear space lies between the segmented ovum and the shell.

Filariform larvae penetrate the skin when a person walks barefoot on soil containing larvae, causing a pruritic maculopapular rash at the site of entry (Ground itch). Common sites of entry include the skin between the toes, the dorsum of the foot and the medial part of the sole. It can occasionally lead to a creeping eruption along the path traversed by the larvae, similar to cutaneous larva migrans.

The larvae are then carried in the venous circulation to the heart and lungs, where they may cause mild transient pneumonitis or bronchitis. They migrate up the respiratory tract to the pharynx, are swallowed, and reach the small intestine producing epigastric pain, dyspepsia, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. 

A. duodenale or N. americanus ingest blood, secrete anticoagulants, and interfere with the absorption of iron, B12, and folic acid. This leads to iron deficiency anemia and protein-energy malnutrition resulting from blood loss. 

Diagnosis:

  • Demonstration of characteristic hookworm eggs in feces by direct wet microscopy. The modified Kato-Katz smear technique is useful for the quantitative estimation of eggs in the stool. 20 eggs or more are associated with anemia.
  • Stool culture: Harada-Mori method of stool culture demonstrates filariform larvae which differentiate A. duodenale and N. americanus.
  • Lab investigations characteristically show hypochromic microcytic anaemia, occasionally with eosinophilia or hypoalbuminemia.

Treatment:

  • Anthelmintic drugs- albendazole and mebendazole.
  • Iron replacement.
  • Nutritional support.

Other options:

Option A: Eggs of Ascaris can be fertilized or unfertilized. Unfertilized eggs have a thinner shell, containing a small atrophied ovum with a mass of disorganized granules. Fertilized eggs are always bile-stained, are usually surrounded by a 3 layer membrane, and contain a large unsegmented ovum. Infection is by swallowing fertilized eggs that contain the larvae.

Option B: Eggs of Strongyloides hatch out to rhabditiform larva as soon as they are laid, and are therefore not seen in the stool. Infection occurs when larvae penetrate the skin while walking, or by autoinfection.

Option C: Eggs of Enterobius are colourless, but have a characteristic plano-convex shape, with a double-layered membrane, and contain a tadpole-shaped embryo. Swallowing eggs by autoinfection or contaminated fingers is the mode of infection.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

Related Pearl: Parasites with bile-stained eggs

The following are the parasites with bile-stained eggs. (mnemonic: FaT CAT)

  • Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke)
  • Fasciolopsis buski (giant intestinal fluke)
  • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm)
  • Clonorchis sinensis (chinese liver fluke, oriental liver fluke)
  • Ascaris lumbricoides (round worm)
  • Taenia solium (pork tapeworm)
  • Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm)

Related Pearl: Helminth eggs that float in saturated salt solution

The following are the helminths whose eggs float in a saturated salt solution. (mnemonic: THE FAN)

  • Trichuris trichiura
  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Enterobius vermicularis
  • Fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides
  • Ancylostoma duodenale
  • Necator americanus.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy with sickle-cell anemia was brought by his parents with complaints of fever and a runny nose. The child has a maculopapular rash with a lacy pattern on his trunk and extremities, sparing the palm and soles. He also has a rash on his face as shown below. What specific complication would you anticipate in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical symptoms and the typical ‘slapped cheek appearance’ that is the erythematous facial flushing as shown in the image are suggestive of erythema infectiosum. A transient aplastic crisis is a complication that is anticipated in this patient. 

Erythema infectiosum or fifth disease is a viral infection caused by parvovirus B19. It usually has three phases:

  • First phase - sudden onset diffuse and macular, asymptomatic erythema of the cheeks or slapped cheek appearance. Prodromal symptoms may occur
  • Second phase - begins after 1–4 days, with discrete erythematous macules and papules on the proximal extremities and later the trunk
  • Third phase - recurring stage, the eruption is greatly reduced or invisible, only to recur after the patient is exposed to heat or sunlight, or in response to crying or exercise

Parvovirus B-19-induced transient aplastic crisis is a complication seen in patients with all types of chronic hemolytic anemia like sickle-cell disease, thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis, and pyruvate kinase deficiency.

Other options:

Option A: Coronary aneurysm is a complication of Kawasaki disease. Patients with this disease present with high fever for at least 5 days along with at least four out of the five characteristic features: polymorphous exanthem, bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis with limbal sparing, lip cracking, and oral mucosal erythema with strawberry tongue appearance, cervical lymphadenopathy, and extremity involvement - erythema of palms and soles with edema of hands and legs.

The image given below shows strawberry tongue and erythema of hands seen in Kawasaki disease.

Option B: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a complication of measles. The characteristic presentation of measles includes a high fever, cough, coryza, and a maculopapular rash which typically begins after 3-5 days of fever in a cephalocaudal fashion involving the palms and soles. A pathognomonic feature of measles is the Koplik spots which are bluish-white spots located on the buccal mucosa opposite the 1st and 2nd molars.

The image given below shows rashes and Koplik spots of measles.

Option D: Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis seen as a complication of group A streptococcal infection (more commonly seen with skin strains and a few pharyngeal strains). Common streptococcal infections in childhood are bacterial pharyngitis, Scarlett fever, non-bullous impetigo, and erysipelas. They present with acute pharyngitis or erythematous papulovesicular lesions which can become purulent.

The image given below shows the rash and strawberry tongue appearance of Scarlett fever.

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty with a history of acute onset of anxiety and hyperactivity. His friend gives a history of substance abuse. On examination, tachycardia, tachypnea, high blood pressure and dilated pupils were noted. The toxicity of which of the following drugs can be suspected in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario patient presenting with anxiety, hyperactivity, tachycardia, hypertension, and mydriasis with a history of substance abuse points towards a diagnosis of cocaine toxicity leading to sympathetic toxidrome.

Cocaine is a CNS stimulant obtained from coca plants belonging to the family Erythroxylaceae. It is also known as Coke, snow and white lady. The route of intake is by snorting, IV route and smoking. Tattoos may be made to cover the injection marks.

It inhibits the uptake of dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin.

At lower doses, it leads to alertness but at higher doses, it produces stereotyped behavior, involuntary actions, and paranoia. There is a transient euphoria. Tactile hallucinations (Magnan's symptom or cocaine bugs) are characteristic. 

There is a dose-dependent increase in heart rate and blood pressure. It causes dilation of pupils and is associated with chills and perspiration. In severe cases, intracranial bleeding due to increased blood pressure, and myocardial infarction due to coronary vasospasm can occur. Ultimately, the patient goes into a stage of depression with loss of reflexes, paralysis of muscles, cardiorespiratory failure, and coma.  

Management -  Administration of activated charcoal and gastric lavage with warm water and potassium permanganate in case of ingestion. Benzodiazepines to control heart rate/seizures. Amyl nitrite is the antidote given via inhalation. Thiamine 100 mg IV and Naloxone 2 mg IV can also be given.

Other options:

Option A - Benzodiazepines is a CNS depressant. They would present with dizziness, diplopia, dysarthria, ataxia and drowsiness. In overdose, respiratory depression and hypotension may occur, unlike the CNS stimulant effects of cocaine.

Option B - Cannabis acts on THC (tetrahydrocannabinol) receptors. It causes euphoria followed by narcosis. There is inattention, motor incoordination, ataxia, tremors, conjunctival suffusion, and somnolence, unlike cocaine which causes hyperactivity.

Option C - Heroin (opium) presents with an initial excitement followed by giddiness and headache. There is a fall in BP, heart rate, respiratory rate in the later stages and pupils are constricted.  

The image below shows the Erythroxylum plant:

Related Pearl: Common names of Drugs of abuse

Drug of abuse Common name
Cocaine White lady, Coke, Blow, Snow
Cannabis Weed, Pot, Reefer, Ganja, Mary Jane, Hash, Indian hemp
Heroin Smack, Dope, Brown sugar, Snowball
Ketamine Vitamin K, Special K, Super K
LSD Acid
Methamphetamine Ice, Meth, Crystal,
MDMA Ecstasy
Phencyclidine Angel dust

 

Forms of cannabis:

Bhang: Decoction prepared from dried leaves and fruit shoot

Majoon: Sweet prepared from bhang

Ganja: Prepared from flower tops of female plant and smoked

Hashish/Charas: Most potent; resin exudate from leaves and stem that's smoked

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented with a large, rapidly-progressing abdominal mass, lymphadenopathy, and ascites. He was suggested prophylactic therapy to prevent the spread to CNS. A lymph node biopsy given below shows two different cell populations labeled A & B .  Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: It can present with three distinct clinical forms
It is a very rapidly proliferating human tumor
Tumor cells are positive for CD19, CD20,  CD10 and BCL2 but negative for BCL6

questions.solution:
The clinical features and the starry-sky appearance on the lymph node biopsy are characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma. The false statement regarding this condition is that tumor cells are positive for CD19, CD20, CD10 and BCL2 but negative for BCL6.

In the given biopsy specimen, "A" indicates the reactive macrophages and "B" represents the tumour cells (B cells). The neoplastic cells are homogeneous, medium-sized B cells with frequent mitotic figures - an indication of a high growth fraction.  

Reactive macrophages are scattered throughout the tumour and their pale cytoplasm in a background of blue-staining tumour cells gives the tumour the so-called starry sky appearance. Reactive leukocytes and macrophages are not stained by special stains. 

The growth fraction of these lymphomas is very high, with frequent mitotic figures being seen and the fraction of Ki-67+ (MIB-1+) cells approaching 100%.

Related Pearl: Burkitt's Lymphoma

Burkitt's lymphoma is the most common non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in children < 15 years.

 Parameter  Features
Genetic factors

Translocations - t(8;14), t(2;8), t(8,22)
Clinical types

Endemic - affects children in Africa, affects jaw, maxilla and is EBV-associated

Sporadic - in adults in western countries 

Immunodeficiency associated - HIV infection
Clinical features

Peripheral lymphadenopathy

Intrabdominal mass

Rapid CNS metastasis 
Histology

Starry sky pattern

Ki-67 stains for 100% of cells (due to rapid proliferation)
Immunophenotype

B cell-associated antigens (CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a)

Germinal center-associated markers (CD10 & BCL-6)

CD43, BCL-2 in up to 20% of cases

Expression of CD21 (the EBV/C3d receptor) depends on EBV status of the tumors:

  • Endemic type (EBV+) - CD21
  • Non-endemic type (EBV-) - lack CD21
 Treatment

Started immediately after diagnosis

Intensive chemotherapy regimens with high doses of cyclophosphamide
 Prognosis  Good - 70-80% cure rate

A variant of this condition with bone marrow involvement is called Burkitt's leukemia (ALL-L3). It is associated with c-myc dysregulation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman came with complaints of progressive hearing loss and tinnitus for a few weeks.  Pure tone audiometry was done as shown below. Which of the following phenomenon is seen in the above patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of pregnant women presenting with progressive hearing loss, tinnitus, and pure tone audiometry showing Carhart's notch is suggestive of Otosclerosis. Paracusis willisii is seen in patients with stapedial otosclerosis.

An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. The louder voice is better transmitted through the fixed stapes. This phenomenon is known as Paracusis willisii.

Otosclerosis is caused by bony overgrowth involving the enchondral layer of the otic capsule. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and usually presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. It Is known to worsen during stress & hormonal variations like during pregnancy and menopause.

The types of otosclerosis and the sites involved are:

Type Site
Stapedial otosclerosis Near oval window
(fissula ante fenestram)
Cochlear otosclerosis Round window
Histologic otosclerosis  asymptomatic

In otosclerosis, the tympanic membrane is usually normal unless there is another co-existing pathology. Sometimes, a reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. Tuning fork tests show negative Rinne.

Tympanometry shows an ossicular stiffness type of curve. Pure tone audiometry shows a characteristic dip in the bone conduction curve at 2000 Hz known as Carhart's notch as shown below.

 

Surgical management includes stapedectomy and stapedotomy with the placement of a prosthesis.

The types of stapedial otosclerosis are:

  • Anterior focus
  • Posterior focus
  • Circumferential
  • Biscuit type (thick plate)
  • Obliterative

 

Option B - Tullio phenomenon is seen in Meniere's disease. In this phenomenon, loud sounds or noise produce vertigo. This is due to the distended saccule lying against the footplate of the stapes.

Option C - Recruitment is seen in diseases of the cochlea such as Meniere's disease and presbycusis, in which there is reduced tolerance to loudness. 

Option D - Roll-over phenomenon is seen in patients with acoustic neuroma. It is the reduction of discrimination score when the loudness is increased beyond a particular level. This reduction is disproportionate to the pure tone hearing loss

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with a white pupillary reflex for which enucleation was done. The histopathological specimen is given below. Identify the marked finding and the associated likely diagnosis.

choices.text: Irregular hyperchromatic nuclei in a fibrillar background, Astrocytoma

questions.solution:
The histopathological finding shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes and its associated diagnosis in a 7-year-old child with a whitish pupillary reflex is retinoblastoma. Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes refer to an arrangement of columnar cells around a central lumen. 

Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14. It is a tumor of a group called small round blue cell tumors because the immature retinal neural cells are seen as small round cells with large nuclei.

White pupillary reflex or leukocoria is the most common presenting feature, followed by a squint which is usually convergent. Rarely, the child may present with nystagmus and defective vision.

Image showing leukocoria of left eye.

 

Histopathology of the tumor shows small round cells with large nuclei. Microscopic features of a well-differentiated tumor include Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific of retinoblastoma), Homer-Wright rosettes, pseudorosettes, and fleurettes formation. Areas of necrosis and calcification can also be seen.

The histopathological image of retinoblastoma is shown below.

 
Treatment typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy. The commonly used three-drug regimen is the CVE regimen consisting of vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy. Enucleation is done when: 
  • the tumor involves more than half of the retina
  • the optic nerve is involved
  • glaucoma is present and the anterior chamber is involved

In the stage of extraocular extension, the globe bursts through the sclera, usually near the limbus or the optic disc. This is followed by rapid fungation and involvement of extraocular tissues resulting in marked proptosis. Distant metastasis occurs through the lymphatic spread and the direct extension by continuity to the optic nerve and brain.

Other options:

Option B: Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumor of childhood that occurs exclusively in the cerebellum. Patients usually present with headaches, ataxia, and signs of brainstem involvement.

Histologically, the tumor is very densely cellular. Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and elongated or crescent-shaped hyperchromatic nuclei. Tumor cells form Homer Wright rosettes. They express neuronal markers such as synaptophysin.

 

Option C: Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of childhood. The child usually presents with rapidly progressive unilateral proptosis. There are 4 subtypes - embryonal, alveolar, botryoid, and pleomorphic. Cells show light microscopic features of striated muscle differentiation. Immunohistochemistry is positive for desmin. 

 

Option D: Astrocytoma of the retina and optic nerve head is rare. It is usually asymptomatic and is most frequently seen in tuberous sclerosis. Fundus examination reveals a yellowish or white plaque, nodule, or mulberry-like lesion. These lesions are semitransparent peripherally and calcified centrally. 

The image below shows a calcified astrocytoma.

Histological finding includes hypercellularity, enlarged, elongated, or irregular hyperchromatic nuclei embedded in a fibrillar background.

Related Pearl: Reese Ellsworth classification for retinoblastoma

Group Prognosis for maintenance of sight Features
1 Very favourable
  • Solitary tumor, <4DD, at or behind equator
  • Multiple tumors, all <4DD, all at or behind the equator
2 Favourable
  • Solitary tumor, 4–10 DD, at or behind the equator
  • Multiple tumors, all 4–10DD all behind the equator
3 Possible
  • Any lesion anterior to equator
  • Solitary tumor, >10DD behind equator
4 Unfavorable
  • Multiple tumors, some >10 DD
  • Any lesion extending anteriorly to ora serrata
5 Highly unfavorable
  • Massive tumors involving more than one half of retina
  • Vitreous seeding

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old kid was brought to the emergency department by his father, as the kid had accidentally put some foreign body into his nose while playing. The ENT resident removes it with the help of the following instrument. This instrument can also be used for ________.

choices.text: Nasal packing and reducing nasal septum fracture
Nasal packing and reducing nasal bone fracture
Reducing nasal septum and nasal bone fractures

questions.solution:
The above image shows Tilley’s forceps.

It is used for nasal packing, ear dressing, removal of foreign bodies from the nose. It has a box joint.

Other options:

Asch's septum forceps is used to reduce a fracture of the nasal septum.

Walsham forceps is used for disimpacting and reducing fractures of the nasal bone.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is diagnosed to have Tourette syndrome. Which one of the following drugs can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Aripiprazole can be used to treat Tourette syndrome.  It is the only anti-psychotic drug approved as a first-line agent for the treatment of Tourette syndrome. 

Aripiprazole is an atypical 2nd generation antipsychotic and is a partial dopamine receptor (D2) agonist. Other partial agonists include cariprazine and brexiprazole.

Antipsychotic agents are dopamine receptor antagonists which also have some anti-histaminic and anti-adrenergic properties. They are classified into:

  • First-generation or typical antipsychotics - haloperidol, fluphenazine, thioridazine and chlorpromazine.
  • Second-generation or atypical antipsychotics - lurasidone, aripiprazole, cariprazine, asenapine, ziprasidone, risperidone, iloperidone, olanzapine, quetiapine and clozapine. These drugs also had additional 5HT2 receptor antagonism and alpha-adrenergic antagonism.

Specific indications of antipsychotics:

  • Acute mania can be treated with all atypical antipsychotics like clozapine, risperidone, quetiapine, and olanzapine
  • Bipolar disorder maintenance includes monotherapy with aripiprazole or olanzapine
  • Delirium, dementia and Parkinson's disease can be treated with haloperidol and risperidone
  • Refractory schizophrenia can be treated with clozapine
  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder can be treated with risperidone
  • Generalised anxiety disorders use quetiapine for monotherapy and low-dose risperidone as an adjunct
  • Disruptive behavioural problems in autism can be treated with risperidone and aripiprazole
  • Emesis can be treated with prochlorperazine

Other options:

Options B and C: Haloperidol and pimozide were earlier used to treat Tourette syndrome. But it had to be stopped because of their dopamine antagonistic property.

Option D: Pramipexole is a dopamine receptor agonist used to treat Parkinson's disease. It is not used in the management of Tourette syndrome.
