questions.text:
Match the following sensory receptors with their stimuli.
 1. Meissner's corpuscles  a. Direction and velocity of             movement of hair
 2. Ruffini's corpuscles  b. Vibration and deep pressure
 3. Hair end organs   c.  Stretch and joint rotation
 4. Pacinian corpuscles  d.  Two-point discrimination
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-b.

1. Meissner's corpuscles  d. Two-point discrimination
2. Ruffini's corpuscles  c. Stretch and joint rotation
3. Hair end organs  a. Direction and velocity of   movement of hair
4. Pacinian corpuscles  b. Vibration and deep pressure

Ruffini corpuscles are capsulated, enlarged, dendritic endings. They are located in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin, and in joint capsules. They are slowly-adapting receptors. They detect stretch and joint rotation.

The image below shows a Ruffini corpuscle.

 

Pacinian corpuscles are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptors. They are present in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin. They are composed of a nerve ending which is encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue that give them an onion-like appearance. The sensory nerves from cutaneous mechanoreceptors are myelinated Aα and Aβ fibers. These receptors respond to fast vibration and deep pressure and adapt very rapidly. 

The image shows the histology of Pacinian corpuscle.

 

Hair end organs include each hair along with its basal nerve fiber. They detect the movement of objects on the skin surface and initial contact of a substance with the body.

These touch receptors are stimulated when there is a slight movement of any hair in the body.

 

Meissner's corpuscles are present mainly in the dermis of non-hairy skin, particularly in the fingertips, lips, and other locations where tactile discrimination is well developed.  Meissner's corpuscles are rapidly adapting receptors that sense point discrimination, precise location, tapping, and flutter. These are encapsulated nerve endings of a large myelinated sensory nerve (Aβ type). They help in two­ point discrimination.

The image shows the histology of Meissner's corpuscle in the dermis.

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

Related Pearl: Slow vs rapidly adapting receptors

Slow adapting Rapidly adapting receptors
Also called tonic receptors Also called phasic receptors
They are expanded on free nerve endings. They are encapsulated nerve endings.
Responds to steady stimulus Respond to rate of change of stimulus
With steady stimulus, tonic receptors keep responding steadily. With steady stimulus, receptor responds initially but stops or adapts rapidly.
Examples: Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, Joint capsule, Muscle spindle, Golgi tendon organs Examples: Pacinian corpuscle, Meissner's corpuscles, Hair end organs

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the obstetric criteria for diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome?

choices.text: ≥ 1 unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus ≥10 weeks
Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery <37 weeks
Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery <34 weeks

questions.solution:
Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks(not <37 weeks) is an obstetric criterion for diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody (APLA) syndrome. 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that is commonly associated with fetal death, preterm delivery, early-onset preeclampsia, and fetal growth restriction due to placental insufficiency and thromboses. Pregnancy loss usually occurs before ten weeks.

Diagnosis of APLA requires at least one clinical criterion and one laboratory criterion:

  • Clinical
    • Obstetric criteria - 
      • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond ten weeks, or
      • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks or
      • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before ten weeks
    • Vascular - One or more episodes of arterial-venous or small vessel thrombosis in any organ or tissue
  • Laboratory criteria(2 positive tests at least 12 weeks apart) - 
    • Presence of lupus anticoagulant, or
    • Anticardiolipin antibodies, or
    • Anti-β2 glycoprotein antibody

Specific therapy in pregnancy: Aspirin plus heparin therapy is the most effective regimen. Women are treated with low-dose aspirin and heparin for up to 34 weeks. Unfractionated heparin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) are equally effective and safe. Corticosteroids are used only in secondary APLA syndrome (associated with SLE) and not in primary APLA syndrome. 

Prophylaxis:

  • Women with prior thromboembolic events - prophylactic anticoagulation throughout pregnancy and six weeks postpartum with either heparin are recommended. Serial sonographic assessment of fetal growth and antepartum testing should be done in the third trimester due to the risk of fetal growth abnormalities and stillbirths.
  • For women without prior thromboembolic events, acceptable regimes include - 
    • Close antepartum maternal observation with or without prophylactic heparin along with postpartum anticoagulation for 4 to 6 weeks or
    • Surveillance alone, or
    • Prophylactic heparin + low dose aspirin (if a prior history of recurrent abortion or stillbirth)

Note: The new 2023 ACR/EULAR criteria is an update from the revised Sapporo criteria with the clinical criteria, which includes an entry criterion of at least one positive antiphospholipid antibody within three years of identification of a clinical criterion, followed by scoring with weighted criteria divided into six clinical domains (macrovascular venous thromboembolism, macrovascular arterial thrombosis, microvascular, obstetric, cardiac valve, and hematologic) and two laboratory domains (lupus anticoagulant,  IgG/IgM anticardiolipin ELISA and/or IgG/IgM anti-β2 -glycoprotein I antibodies) This has increased the specificity in diagnosing APS.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman presents with a unilateral throbbing headache associated with nausea and vomiting. She has had similar episodes in the past where the headache usually lasts for 1-2 days. Bright light increases her discomfort and she prefers sitting in a dark room. Which of the following are used to prevent further episodes of this condition?
  1. Sumatriptan
  2. Propranolol
  3. Naproxen
  4. Topiramate
  5. Transcranial magnetic stimulation
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario featuring unilateral throbbing headache with aura (photophobia, nausea, vomiting) is suggestive of migraine with aura. Options 2,4, and 5 i.e. propranolol, topiramate, and transcranial magnetic stimulation are used for prophylaxis against migraine.

Sumatriptan and naproxen are used in the acute management of migraine (not used as preventive medication).

Other drugs used in the prophylaxis of migraine:

  • Beta-blockers - propranolol, metoprolol
  • Antidepressants - amitriptyline, venlafaxine
  • Anticonvulsants - valproate, topiramate
  • Serotonergic drugs - pizotifen
  • Flunarizine, Candesartan
  • CGRP antagonists - erenumab, fremanezumab, galcanezumab, eptinezumab.

Other modalities of preventive treatment:

  • Onabotulinum toxin A 
  • Neuromodulation: A single-pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation (sTMS) is delivered with a hand-held device (FDA approved) that creates a fluctuating magnetic field that triggers an electric current that modifies cortical excitability.

Drugs with no role in prophylaxis :

  • Calcium channel blockers - verapamil, nimodipine
  • α2 adrenergic agonist - clonidine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors - fluoxetine

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: A 62-year-old hypertensive male patient presents with dizziness and palpitations. On examination, his pulse rate is 132 per minute with an irregularly irregular rhythm. His ECG is given below. He does not have a history of diabetes milletus, congestive heart failure, cerebrovascular or other vascular diseases. What is his CHA2DS2-VASc score?
questions.solution:
The CHA2DS2-VASc score for the described patient is 1. The given clinical scenario and ECG features depict atrial fibrillation. 

The CHA2DS2-VASc score is used to assess the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation. Anticoagulation is recommended if the score is ≥2. The following risk factors are considered during the calculation of the score:

Risk factors Score
Congestive heart failure 1
Hypertension 1
Age ≥75years 2
Diabetes mellitus 1
Stroke or Transient ischemic attack or embolus 2
Vascular disease 1
Age 65-75years 1
Sex- female 1 

The patient is a known case of hypertension with none of the above-mentioned features present. Hence, his CHA2DS2-VASc score is 1.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a type of cardiac arrhythmia characterized by disorganized, rapid, and irregular atrial activation. It is common in men and risk factors include underlying cardiac disease, hypertension, diabetes, family history of AF, obesity, and sleeping disorders.

Features include heart rate typically ranging from 110-160 beats/minute. It is irregular and rapid. Presyncope and syncope can be seen. Thrombus formation can occur and thromboembolic events can take place. Typically, ECG shows an absent P wave.

Management is mainly by control of rate and rhythm, avoiding the thromboembolism risk and modifiable risk factors.

Immediate cardioversion should be done when the patient presents within 48 hours and are at low risk for developing stroke whereas in patients presenting after 48 hours or if the duration is not known, there is an increased risk of thromboembolism. Therefore, anticoagulation should be done for 3 weeks followed by cardioversion and 4 weeks post cardioversion. 

The other approach is to start anticoagulation following transesophageal echo. Cardioversion can be done only if the thrombus is absent. The rate control strategy is achieved with calcium channel blockers/ beta blockers and digoxin.

Related Pearl: CHA2DS2-VASC scoring for risk of stroke & need for oral anticoagulation in AF

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval

questions.text: The findings shown in the image are most likely to have been caused by?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows birdshot pellets within and around the shattered patella, distal femur, and proximal tibia. The wound shown in the image is most likely to have been caused by close-range shotgun injury to the knee.

The ammunition for the shotgun is a cartridge made of a cardboard or plastic cylinder fitted into a metal base. The base carries a percussion detonator that is struck by the spring-loaded firing pin when the trigger is pulled.  The primer is located in the percussion cup and contains the detonator.  The cartridge contains a charge of propellant (gunpowder), above which are ‘wads’ or pistons of felt, and cardboard or plastic discs, or both. Above these is the charge of shot (pellets), which varies greatly in number and size, finally covered by a card or plastic disc.

The image below shows a shotgun cartridge:

 

Ammunition of a rifled weapon:

  • There is a metal cylinder, closed at one end, which is the ‘shell’ or cartridge.
  • The cylinder carries a percussion detonator in the base, either centrally or peripherally.
  • The shell is loaded with explosive propellant such as nitrocellulose and the bullet is firmly clamped into the open end.

The image below shows a rifled gun cartridge:

 

Note: Blast particles would not have a uniform pellet size as seen in the image, which is characteristic of shotgun pellets.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odor. The saline microscopy of the vaginal smear showed the following finding. Which of the following is used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing clue cells suggest bacterial vaginosis. Clindamycin is used to treat this condition. 

Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial infection characterized by malodorous (fishy smell) vaginal discharge. Causative organisms include:

  • Gardnerella
  • Haemophilus vaginalis
  • Mobiluncus
  • Mycoplasma hominis 

This is due to the alteration in the normal vaginal flora which causes a decrease in the number of lactobacilli. It mainly reduces the pH and has antibacterial action by releasing hydrogen peroxide.

Amsel's Criteria: (any 3 should be present)

  • Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge
  • A pH of vaginal fluid >4.5
  • Fishy odor of discharge accentuated on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test)
  • Presence of Clue cells on microscopy. Many epithelial cells present granular cytoplasm caused by small gram-negative bacilli adhering on their surface, these cells are called clue cells.  

Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells with their surface covered by adherent bacilli seen in stained or unstained films. 

The treatment regimens for bacterial vaginosis are:

  • Tablet metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days
  • Clindamycin cream intravaginally for 7 days
  • Metronidazole gel intravaginally for 5 days

Other drugs that can be used include tinidazole and secnidazole.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginitis

Candidal vaginitis
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomonas vaginalis Candida albicans
Aetiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual transmission No Yes No
Discharge Fishy, thin, yellow Frothy, green Curdy, white
Symptoms Fishy odour, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test The whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: A man presented with low mood, loss of appetite, and sleep disturbances for the past 3 weeks. History revealed that he lost all his savings and landed in a financial crisis 1 month ago. He has no history of mental illness. He is trying to work towards improving his financial condition. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with low mood, loss of appetite, and sleep disturbances occurring within 3 months of a stressful event (financial crisis) suggests adjustment disorder. 

Adjustment disorder is an emotional response to a stressful event such as the loss of a job, divorce, moving to a new environment, financial problems, medical illnesses, or the death of a loved one. 

Most patients are able to return to their previous level of functioning within 3 months. Adolescents usually require a longer time to recover than adults and may develop mood disorders or substance­ related disorders in the future.

The suicidal risk is found to be higher in patients with chronic adjustment disorder with depressive symptoms, and associated substance-related disorders in those with previous suicide attempts. The highest risk is seen in adolescent patients.

Diagnostic criteria for adjustment disorder include:

  • Development of emotional or behavioral response within 3 months of the onset of the stressor
  • The symptoms or behavior are clinically significant, where, any one of the following are met - 
    • The response is out of proportion to the severity or intensity of the stressor
    • Significant impairment in social, occupational, or other areas of functioning
  • Stress-related disturbance does not meet the criteria for another mental disorder or exacerbation of pre-existing mental disorder
  • The symptoms do not represent normal bereavement
  • Once the stressor is terminated, the symptoms do not persist for more than 6 additional months.

The mainstay of treatment is psychotherapy. Pharmacotherapy is not commonly used, however it is reasonable to use medications for specific symptoms for a brief period of time.

Other options:

Option A: Depression usually leads to impairment of daily activity and loss of interest since this patient is trying to work towards improving his condition, he is unlikely to have depression. Furthermore, atypical depression is characterised by overeating and increased sleep, whereas, this patient has a loss of appetite, and disturbed sleep. 

Options C and D: PTSD is a psychiatric disorder characterised by increased stress and anxiety after a stressful or traumatic event. Examples include witnessing or being involved in violent accidents, crime, war, natural disasters, life-threatening illnesses, etc. Symptoms of PTSD can be divided into four types:

  • Intrusion symptoms - flashbacks 
  • Hyperarousal
  • Avoidance symptoms 
  • Negative cognitions associated with the traumatic event

Acute stress disorder presents with the same symptoms as PTSD, but the symptoms usually occur immediately after the trauma and persist for a period of 3 days to up to 1 month after the trauma.

Based on the duration between the event and the presentation of symptoms, stress disorder is classified as follows:

Duration Condition
3 days to 1 month Acute stress reaction
More than 1 month Post-traumatic stress disorder
Symptoms occur after 6 months of the stressor event Delayed Post-traumatic stress disorder

questions.text: Name the genes altered in the given pathway.
questions.solution:
The correct order is 1. APC gene, 2. K-RAS and 3. p53.

Adenocarcinoma of the colon is the most common malignancy of the GI tract. The pathogenesis of colon cancer can be explained by three distinct pathways of genomic instability:

  1. Chromosomal instability / APC-β-catenin pathway / Classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence.
  2. Microsatellite instability pathway (MSI).
  3. CpG Island Methylator Phenotype pathway.
1. Chromosomal instability / APC-β-catenin pathway / classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence is the most common pathway accounting for 80% of sporadic cancers. The "first-hit" in this pathway is the inherited or acquired mutation of the cancer suppressor gene APC on chromosome 5q21. But, both copies of the APC gene must be inactivated. The "second hit" is due to methylation abnormalities. This results in the loss of both APC alleles. The APC protein normally promotes the degradation of β-catenin. Since it is lost, β-catenin accumulates and translocates to the nucleus. This causes activation of transcription of genes that promote proliferation.
Mutations of K-RAS on chromosome 12p12, TP53 on chromosome 17p13, and LOH at chromosome 18q21 are involved in further steps of the classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence.
 
2. Microsatellite instability pathway (MSI) occurs in patients with DNA mismatch repair deficiency leading to the accumulation of mutations in microsatellite repeats. The main pathogenic mechanisms are mutations of type II TGF-β receptor, leading to uncontrolled cell growth, and loss of pro-apoptotic BAX genes that enhance the survival of genetically abnormal clones.
 
3. CpG island hypermethylation phenotype (CIMP) - The MLH1 promoter region undergoes hypermethylation, reducing MLH1 expression and its repair function. There are also activating mutations in the oncogenes like BRAF. KRAS and TP53 tumor suppressor genes are not mutated. The combination of MSI, BRAF mutation, and methylation of specific targets, such as MLH1, contributes to the development of colorectal cancer through this pathway. 

Related Pearl: Fearon-Vogelstein adenoma-carcinoma multistep model of colorectal neoplasia

Related Pearl: Cancers associated with important oncogenes

Oncogenes

Adenocarcinomas of the breast, lung, and colon

N-MYC

Neuroblastoma

L-MYC

Small-cell carcinoma of the lung

N-RAS

Melanoma

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Colorectal Cancer

The risk factors for colorectal cancer are:

  • Dietary:
    • High-animal-fat diet
    • Low-fiber diet
    • Alcohol
  • Hereditary syndromes:
    • FAP
    • HNPCC
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Cholecystectomy: increased right colon cancer due to exposure to bile acids
  • Ureterosigmoidostomy
  • Smoking
  • Acromegaly
  • Pelvic irradiation

questions.text: You are conducting a meta-analysis of studies on the effects of statin drugs and the risk of developing ventricular arrhythmias in patients with cardiomyopathy. The analysis is presented as the following plot. Which among the given statements is incorrect regarding the interpretation of these plots?

choices.text: The diamond shows the overall pooled results
Each rectangle depicts a single study
The vertical dashed line is the “line of no effect"
The size of the rectangle denotes the sample size

questions.solution:
The given plot for the meta-analysis is a forest plot. The vertical solid line is the “line of no effect", signifying no difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1)

The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analyzed measure of effect.

Forest plots allow the results to be seen at a glance with the identification of the outliers.

Interpretation of the graph given in the image: 

  • Each rectangle represents a single study. 
    - ex: Smith et al, Jones et al 
  • The size of the rectangle represents the sample size
    - ex: Smith et al 1999 had a small sample size whereas Chu et al 2009 had a large sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side represents the confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
    - ex: Ng et al 2004 has a small confidence interval and is more reliable than Jones et al 1993 as it has longer confidence intervals
  • The vertical solid line- the “line of no effect", no difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1) 
    -the location of the result depicts whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not. Any study line which crosses the line of null effect does not illustrate a statistically significant result.
  • A diamond represents the overall pooled result of the meta-analysis where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged. 
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
 

Related Pearl: Forest Plot

  • A forest plot is used to present the results of a meta-analysis.
  • It is also called blobbogram.

Interpretation of forest plots: 

  • The rectangles represent the single studies
  • The size of the rectangle is proportional to the sample size
  • The horizontal line on either side - confidence interval, the longer the lines, the wider the confidential interval, the less reliable the study results
  • The vertical solid line - the “line of no effect", which represents the odds ratio or relative risk. If it is the odds ratio, then the vertical line would be at 1. No difference between the intervention and the placebo (i.e., a risk ratio of 1). 
  • The location of the result - whether it favours the intervention (the statin drug) or not
  • A diamond shows the overall pooled result where all the individual studies are combined together and averaged
  • Lateral corners of the diamond represent the confidence interval, if these corners do not cross 'the line of no effect', then there is an overall statistically significant effect. If the diamond touches the vertical line, the overall result is not statistically significant.
  • The vertical dashed line represents the overall pooled estimate which represents the meta-analysed measure of effect.

Let's understand with an example - 

  • For study A- it has a wide horizontal line that crosses the line of null effect with a black box that is to the right of the vertical line. This most likely demonstrates a small scale study with few participants where the point estimate result favours the control used in the study. But because the study contains the null value in its 95% confidence interval, it is likely to have a p-value >0.05 and not be statistically significant.
  • For study B- it has quite a narrow line that does not cross the line of null effect with a black box that is to the left of the vertical line and is bigger than study A. This most likely demonstrates a larger study with more participants compared to study A, where the result favours the intervention used. Because the 95% confidence interval does not contain the null value, this study is likely to have a p-value <0.05 and hence the differences observed in the study can be regarded as statistically significant.

questions.text:
Nivolumab is used as a checkpoint inhibitor in which of the following conditions?
  1. Hodgkin's lymphoma
  2. Advanced melanoma
  3. Advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)
  4. Medulloblastoma
  5. Renal cell carcinoma
questions.solution:
Nivolumab is used as a checkpoint inhibitor in Hodgkin's lymphoma, advanced melanoma, advanced NSCLC that is previously treated, renal cell carcinoma, and advanced head and neck cancers.

Nivolumab is a checkpoint inhibitor that blocks the interaction between PD-1 and its ligands. It is a fully human monoclonal IgG4 antibody. It has a good response rate in patients with pretreated solid tumours and haematological malignancies. Similar effectiveness is also seen with pembrolizumab which is also an anti-PD-1 monoclonal antibody.

The adverse effects of nivolumab include rash in patients with melanoma. Fatigue, dyspnea, cough, musculoskeletal pain, decreased appetite, and constipation can be seen in patients with advanced squamous NSCLC. Pneumonitis, colitis, nephritis, hepatitis, and renal dysfunction are also seen.

Important note:

The FDA on May 2021 approved the use of nivolumab in patients having completely resected oesophagal or gastroesophageal junction cancers with residual pathologic disease who have received neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy.

Related Pearl: Monoclonal antibodies nomenclature

Murine - 0% human: “omab” (Tositumomab)

Chimeric - 65% human: “ximab” (Rituximab)

Humanized - 95% human: “zumab” (Trastuzumab)

Fully human - 100% human: “umab” (Adalimumab)

questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient has been using a long-acting beta-agonist to control her exercise-induced asthma. Which of the following is not a systemic effect of the drug due to the stimulation of the receptor involved?

choices.text: Relaxation of the ciliary muscle of eye

questions.solution:
Long-acting beta-agonists used in asthma control act by β2 adrenergic agonism. These drugs do not lead to a decrease in the contraction of the heart. The contraction of the heart is mediated by β1 adrenergic agonism.

Long-acting beta-agonists are used in the prophylaxis of exercise-induced asthma, COPD, and bronchial asthma. Its effect occurs within minutes of inhaling a therapeutic dose of the drug. 

The pharmacological effects due to β2 adrenergic agonism include:

  • Relaxation of the ciliary muscle of the eye
  • Relaxation of bronchial smooth muscle
  • Decreased motility of GIT
  • Increased lipolysis
  • Tremors
  • Increased skeletal muscle glycogenolysis
  • Increased potassium uptake
  • Increased insulin secretion
  • Gallbladder, splenic capsule, detrusor, and uterine relaxation

The effects of stimulation of the other adrenergic receptors are:

Alpha 1

  • Mydriasis
  • Major blood vessel vasoconstriction
  • Gastrointestinal and genitourinary tract sphincter contraction
  • Decreased renin secretion
  • Pregnant uterus contraction
  • Ejaculation
  • Piloerection
  • Liver glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis

Alpha 2

  • Decreased gastrointestinal secretion
  • Decreased insulin secretion
  • Decreased lipolysis

Beta 1

  • Increased heart rate
  • Increased force of contraction of the heart
  • Increased automaticity
  • Increased conduction velocity
  • Increased renin secretion
  • ADH secretion

Beta 3

  • Increased lipolysis

questions.text: A manufacturer imports a drug under a name that belongs to another drug. What is this type of drug called?
questions.solution:
This type of drug is called a spurious drug.

As per the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, a drug shall be deemed to be spurious if:

  • It is imported under a name that belongs to another drug
  • It imitates or resembles another drug in a manner likely to deceive
  • The manufacturer name is bogus (labeling a knock-off as a product of an established brand or manufacturing under a fake/ non-existent identity)
  • It has been substituted by another drug or substance wholly or in part

Other options:

Option A: As per the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, a drug shall be deemed to be misbranded if - 

  • It is made to appear of better or greater therapeutic value than it really is
  • It is not labeled in the prescribed manner
  • Its label or container or anything accompanying the drug bears any false claim for the drug

Option B: An adulterated drug is a drug that contains filthy or decomposed substances, substances that are injurious to health, or if the drug contains harmful substances to reduce the quality or strength of the drug. It also includes drugs that are prepared in unsanitary conditions.

Option C: The term unethical drug is not standard terminology in pharmacology. However, the term ethical drug is sometimes used to describe those drugs that are available only by prescription of a medical practitioner.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with progressive atrophy and weakness in her hands and forearms. On examination, she is found to have spasticity of the legs and a brisk jaw jerk.  Which of the following clinical findings would eliminate amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) as a differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Impaired bowel and bladder function are not associated with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Even in the late stages of the disease, bowel and bladder functions are preserved.

Sensory, bowel and bladder, ocular motility, and cognitive functions are preserved even in the later stages of ALS. Spontaneous fasciculations and progressive asymmetrical distal weakness are found early on in this disease. Degeneration of corticobulbar projections causes the pseudobulbar effect resulting in inappropriate laughing, crying, or yawning. 

ALS is the most common progressive motor neuron disease. The pathologic hallmark of ALS includes the involvement of lower motor neurons of the ventral/ anterior horn of the spinal cord, cranial nerves innervating the bulbar muscles, and the afferent corticospinal upper motor neurons in layer five of the motor cortex.

Clinical features of ALS include:

  • Lower motor neuron level - 
    • Fasciculations
    • Muscle cramps
    • Distal weakness and atrophy
    • Bulbar palsy - dysarthria, dysphagia, respiratory compromise
  • Upper motor neuron level - 
    • Spasticity
    • Increased reflexes
    • Flexor spasms
    • Pseudobulbar affect - inappropriate laughing, crying, yawning
  • Others - 
    • Split-hand syndrome - thenar hand intrinsic muscles are affected with relative sparing of the hypothenar muscles
    • Dropped head syndrome - due to severe neck extensor weakness
    • Frontotemporal dementia

The diagnosis of ALS is usually clinical. Presence of upper motor neuron and lower motor neuron signs, along with normal CSF, blood, and urine analysis. Electrodiagnostic studies like electromyography may show fibrillation, and positive sharp waves indicative of active denervation. Neuroimaging shows an increased signal in the corticospinal tracts on T2-weighted MRI. The newer Awaji criteria are used for the diagnosis of ALS by using electrophysiological findings in addition to the clinical findings.

The image given below shows an MRI with an increased T2 signal within the posterior part of the internal capsule, consistent with the clinical diagnosis of ALS. 


The treatment is not curative but aids in lengthening survival.

  • Riluzole reduces excitotoxicity by diminishing glutamate release and improving survival.
  • Edaravone is a novel scavenger of oxygen radicals, capable of slowing down ALS progression and improving survival. It is an adjuvant to riluzole.
  • Symptomatic treatment of spasticity - 
    • GABA receptor agonists like baclofen
    • Alpha-2 receptor agonists like tizanidine
    • Other agents - benzodiazepines like clonazepam are used in early ALS without respiratory compromise.

questions.text: A young woman presented with complaints of difficulty in vision for the past 2 weeks. She has been unable to see cars coming on the right of her car. She has difficulty with right-sided vision in both eyes. On examination, there is a deficit in the right half of her visual field in both eyes. Which of the following in the image below is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The patient is having a visual deficit in the right vision i.e right homonymous hemianopia. The structure marked 3 i.e. the left optic tract is likely to be affected. 

In the given scenario, vision is lost in the right half of both eyes, which means:

  • In the left eye, the nasal visual field is lost, and
  • In the right eye, the temporal visual field is lost.

It means left temporal and right nasal fibres are destroyed which leads to right homonymous hemianopia. Anatomically, this can be explained by the fact that each optic tract contains fibres from the ipsilateral temporal half of the retina and the contralateral nasal half of the retina.

Homonymous hemianopia (HH) involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. It is characteristically seen in lesions involving the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasma.

HH may be either:

  • Complete HH is characterised by the loss of the entire hemifield on the same side in both eyes
  • Incomplete HH is characterised by partial loss of visual field on the same side in both eyes. Depending on whether the extent of partial loss of the visual field in both the eyes is the same or different, incomplete HH is classified as congruous or incongruous respectively. 

Other options:

Option A: The structure marked as 1 is the left optic nerve. A lesion in this part leads to blindness in the left eye.

Option B: The structure marked as 2 is the right optic nerve. A lesion in this part leads to blindness in the right eye.

Option D: The structure marked as 4 is the right optic tract. A lesion in this part leads to left homonymous hemianopia.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Which of the following options represents the Australia antigen in the given image of viral structure?
questions.solution:
The Australia antigen, which is another name for hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), is marked as '1' in the given image. This antigen was first isolated from the serum of an Australian person, hence the name Australia antigen.

Under electron microscopy, the serum from hepatitis B patients shows three types of particles:

  • Spherical particle: 22 nm; most abundant; containing only HBsAg
  • Filamentous or tubular particle: 22 nm; containing only HBsAg
  • Double-walled spherical structure: 42 nm diameter; the complete hepatitis B virus; called the Dane particle, since it was first described by Dane

The illustration given below shows the sphericle structure of the hepatitis B virus.

Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is an objective marker of active HBV infection and is detectable in large quantities in the serum. It is present in active infection and also may be present in the chronic carrier state (when it persists for longer than 6 months). 

Hepatitis B core antigen (HBcAg) is a capsid/core protein found on nucleocapsid. 

Hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) is the envelop antigen. It is a protein on the nucleocapsid. It is a marker of active viral replication. The persistence of HBeAg is an indicator of chronic hepatitis B with active viral replication. Anti-HBeAg antibodies are produced against these antigens.

The nucleocapsid contains the DNA, which appears partially double-stranded and partially single-stranded. It is associated with a viral DNA polymerase that has both DNA-dependent DNA polymerase and RNA-dependent reverse transcriptase functions.

The image given below shows the hepatitis B virus genome.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman who is on an MAO inhibitor for major depression for 6 months underwent hernia surgery. Post-operatively the nurse administered an analgesic for the pain. After some time, the patient developed fever, hypotension, rigidity, restlessness, and delirium. Which of the following is unlikely to have caused her symptoms?

MAO: Monoamine oxidase
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of serotonin syndrome. Buprenorphine is unlikely to have caused her symptoms. 

Buprenorphine is a partial μ agonist and an antagonist at δ and κ receptors. It is used as an analgesic and in the management of opioid dependence. It does not have an effect on the neuronal uptake of serotonin so is not implicated in causing serotonin syndrome. 

Serotonin is metabolised by monoamine oxidases and MAO inhibition increases serotonin stores. Opioids such as meperidine, tramadol, fentanyl and dextromethorphan block the neuronal reuptake of serotonin. Therefore, combining MAO inhibitors with these opioids causes serotonin syndrome.

Clinical features of serotonin syndrome include: 

  • Hypotension, flushing
  • Extreme agitation, hyperreflexia
  • Hyperthermia, uncontrollable shivering, rigidity
  • Delirium, myoclonus, status epilepticus, and death. 

Treatment involves removing the offending agent and supportive care. 

Meperidine (pethidine) is a mu-opioid receptor (MOR) agonist. It has a strong analgesic effect on the central nervous system. It is mainly used as an analgesic but can also be used in post-anesthetic shivering. It has a greater ability to enter the CNS and produce analgesia at lower systemic concentrations compared to morphine. Therefore, constipation, urinary retention, and nausea are less frequent compared to morphine.

Meperdine can cross the placenta and cause significant respiratory depression in the fetus. In patients or addicts who are tolerant to the depressant effects of meperidine, large doses repeated at short intervals may produce an excitatory syndrome that includes hallucinations, tremors, muscle twitches, etc.

Tramadol is a synthetic codeine analog that is a MOR agonist. It is a centrally-acting analgesic used in the treatment of mild to moderate pain. 

Fentanyl is a synthetic opioid and MOR agonist. Fentanyl and sufentanil are commonly used during anesthesia because of their relatively short time of action, cardiovascular safety, and capacity to significantly reduce the dosing requirement for the volatile agents.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs has been recently approved by FDA for the treatment of HIV-1 infection?
questions.solution:
Fostemsavir has been recently approved (2020) by FDA for the treatment of HIV-1 (human immunodeficiency virus-1) infection.

Fostemsavir is an HIV-1 gp120-directed attachment inhibitor. It is used in combination with other antiretrovirals. It is indicated in patients with multi-drug resistant HIV-1 infection whose current antiretroviral agents have failed due to resistance, intolerance or safety considerations.

It is available as 600mg extended-release tablets. The recommended dosage is one tablet taken twice daily with or without food.

It is contraindicated in patients with a prior hypersensitivity reaction. Co-administration with strong cytochrome (CYP) P450 and CYP 3A inducers is not indicated as it may cause a significant reduction in the plasma concentration of fostemsavir.

Adverse reactions to this drug include immune reconstitution syndrome. In some patients, especially with hepatitis B or C virus co-infection, the plasma transaminase levels may be elevated. Fostemsavir should be given with caution in patients with a history of QTc prolongation or with relevant pre-existing cardiac disease or those taking drugs with a known risk of Torsade de Pointes. 

Other options:

Option B: Maftivimab has been recently approved (2020) by the FDA as part of a combination drug containing atoltivimab, maftivimab, and odesivimab-ebgn for the treatment of the Ebola virus.

Option C: Baloxavir in combination with marboxil got FDA approval in 2018 to treat acute uncomplicated influenza in patients who have been symptomatic for no more than 48 hours.

Option D: Tecovirimat got FDA approval in 2018 to treat smallpox.

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who are age >10 years and body weight >30 kg with HIV-1, HIV-2, HIV 1&2 co-infection who have not received any ART 
  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
  • All PLHIV with abnormal serum creatinine values 
  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who were on the previous recommended regime (Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Efavirenz) to be counselled to switch to new regime. Continue older regime if response is good
  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

*PLHIV: People living with HIV

questions.text:
A primigravida was rushed to the emergency with generalized tonic-clonic seizures at 38 weeks of gestation. Her family reported her having complained of a headache and abdominal pain before the seizures. Her medical records showed that she was diagnosed with gestational hypertension at 22 weeks of gestation. Which of the following is false regarding further management of this patient?

DTR: Deep tendon reflexes
MgSO4: Magnesium sulfate

choices.text: Loading dose of MgSO4 should be reduced if urine output <30 mL/hr
Plasma magnesium levels need to be maintained at 4-7 mEq/L
Maintenance doses of MgSO4 are given only if DTRs are present
Calcium gluconate should be readily available while giving MgSO4

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of eclampsia where the loading dose of 4 g IV MgSO4 is given irrespective of renal function status.

Although magnesium is cleared almost exclusively by renal excretion, the loading dose of magnesium sulfate can be safely administered regardless of renal function. Only the maintenance dose needs to be altered according to the renal function. This is because the loading dose is responsible for reaching therapeutic levels but the maintenance doses are responsible for maintaining steady states.

Magnesium sulfate is used for the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe pre-eclampsia. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L. (Option B)

The two regimens commonly used are Pritchard and Sibai regimens.

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard)  4 g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minutes followed by 10 g (5O%), deep IM (5 g in each buttock)  5 g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttocks
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai)  4 g IV slow over 15-20 minute  1-2 g/h IV infusion

Patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity:

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes 
  • Decreased respiratory rate (<12 per min)
  • Urine output (<30 ml/h)
  • Chest pain, heart block

Repeated or maintenance dose IM injections are continued only if:

  • Patellar reflex (deep tendon reflex) is present (Option C)
  • Respirations are not depressed
  • Urine output in the previous 4 hours exceeded 100 mL

Management of magnesium toxicity:

  • Stop magnesium therapy
  • Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels
  • Injection of calcium gluconate 10ml (10% solution) IV (Option D)

questions.text: What is the phenomenon seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the phenomenon of emperipolesis.

Emperipolesis is a condition wherein hematopoietic cells in a living and intact state are seen in the cytoplasm of a host cell without any damage. The cells frequently involved are neutrophils, lymphocytes, and plasma cells. 

In phagocytosis, the engulfed cells are dead or dying cells or other materials floating around the extracellular space.

Histopathologic characters:

  • The engulfed cell is enclosed in a membrane-bound vacuole in the cytoplasm of the host cell.
  • Internalized cells appear to continue living within the host cell for brief periods of time. Sometimes, they even undergo division within the vacuole.

Other options- 

Option A: Entosis is a phenomenon where a cell engulfs a cell of the same type. While cells that are internalized by this mechanism are initially viable with the majority of them undergoing a non-apoptotic form of cell death.

Option B: Necroptosis has features similar to necrosis and apoptosis. Like necrosis, it is characterized by loss of ATP, cellular and organelle swelling, the release of lysosomal enzymes, and the rupture of the plasma membrane. However, like apoptosis, this is programmed cell death. Ligation of TNFR1 initiates necroptosis.

Option D: Pyroptosis is a form of programmed cell death that is different from apoptosis and necrosis. It is involved in the clearance of necrotic and microbe-infected cells. Cytoplasmic innate immune receptors recognize microbial products that have entered infected cells and activate the multiprotein complex called the inflammasome.

questions.text:
Which of the following are vitamin B12-dependent enzymes?

1. Methyl malonyl CoA mutase
2. Homocysteine synthase
3. Folate reductase
4. Methionine synthase
questions.solution:
Among the given enzymes, 1 and 4 i.e., methyl malonyl CoA mutase and methionine synthase are vitamin B12-dependent enzymes. 

Vitamin B12 or cobalamin is a water-soluble vitamin that is derived from animal products such as red meat, dairy, and eggs. Its absorption in the terminal ileum is facilitated by the presence of intrinsic factor, produced by parietal cells in the stomach. There are two vitamin B12-dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (homocysteine methyltransferase) - catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine
  • Methylmalonyl CoA mutase - methylmalonyl CoA, formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine, isoleucine, and propionyl CoA is converted to succinyl CoA

The image below shows B12 serving as a cofactor of methionine synthase.

The conversion of 5,10-methylene-THF into 5-methyl-THF (methyltetrahydrofolate) is an irreversible process. The major source of tetrahydrofolate for tissues is 5-methyl-THF. The only way to make further use of 5-methyl-THF and to maintain the folate cycle is by the vitamin B12-dependent remethylation of homocysteine to methionine by the methioninesynthase enzyme.

Decreased activity of methionine synthase in vitamin B12 deficiency results in the accumulation of methyltetrahydrofolate, which cannot be used, resulting in a folate trap. The folate cycle acts as the link between the functions of folate and vitamin B12, and a deficiency of vitamin B12 can cause a functional deficiency of folate.

The activity of methylmalonyl CoA mutase is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to an accumulation of methylmalonic acid and its excretion in urine. Since vitamin B12 is also linked to the regeneration of methionine from homocysteine, its deficiency can result in hyperhomocysteinemia as well.

Urinary excretion of methylmalonic acid is also used to differentiate between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency.
