questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of the Ziehl-Neelsen staining technique in the correct sequence.

1. Flood with carbol fuchsin
2. Flood slides with 3% acid-alcohol
3. Flood the slides with methylene blue 
4. Let stand for 2-3 min
5. Heat the slide with a Bunsen burner flame
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of the steps of Ziehl-Neelsen staining is 1-5-2-4-3 (option A).

Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) staining is used to detect acid-fast bacteria, eg. Mycobacteria in patients with suspected tuberculosis. The steps of the process are as follows:

  1. Place slides on the staining rack so they are at least 1 cm apart, and flood with carbol fuchsin.
  2. Heat the slide to steaming with the flame from a Bunsen burner. Do not let the stain boil or dry. Add additional stain if necessary.
  3. Wash off the stain with distilled water.
  4. Flood slides with 3% acid-alcohol.
  5. Let stand for 2-3 min (more acid-alcohol should be used if the smear is heavily stained).
  6. Wash off the acid-alcohol with distilled water and tilt the slides to drain.
  7. Flood the slides with methylene blue and let them stand for 1-2 minutes.
  8. Wash off the methylene blue with distilled water.
  9. Tilt the slides to drain.
  10. Allow slides to air dry in the slide rack. Do not blot.

 

ZN- stained smears for AFB detection in tuberculosis are grading as follows:

Number of AFB per oil immersion field Grading Number of fields Result
>10 / field 3+ 20 Positive
1-10 / field 2+ 50 Positive
10-99 / 100 field 1+ 100 Positive
1-9 / 100 field Scanty 100 Positive
Nil AFB / 100 field  0 100 Negative

Note: The World Health Organization (WHO) and the RNTCP revised the recommended concentration of carbol fuchsin to 1% instead of 0.3%.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient experienced a complete loss of vision following a functional endoscopic sinus surgery for chronic ethmoidal sinusitis. The marked air cells are in close anatomical proximity to the structure which is injured in this patient. Identify the cell.
questions.solution:
The structure most likely injured in this patient is the optic nerve and the Onodi cell is in close proximity to it.

Onodi cell is an anatomical variant, in which the posterior ethmoidal cells enlarge and extend into the sphenoid bone laterally and superior to the sphenoid sinus. The sphenoid sinus is in close relation to the optic nerve and sometimes the carotid artery. Therefore, while removing posterior ethmoidal cells during endoscopic surgery, the presence of Onodi cells increases the risk to the optic nerve.

Ethmoidal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present in the lateral mass of the ethmoid bone. They are bound medially by the lateral nasal wall, laterally by a thin plate of bone called the lamina papyracea, and superiorly by an extension of the orbital plate of the frontal bone. 

The ethmoid sinusoidal air cells range from 3 to 18 in number and are divided into anterior and posterior groups by a basal lamina.

  • Anterior cells- They open into the middle meatus. They contain-
    • Agger nasi cells - Present in the agger nasi ridge
    • Ethmoid bulla - Forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris
    • Supraorbital cells
    • Frontoethmoid cells- In the area of the frontal recess
    • Haller cells - In the floor of the orbit. Lies in the roof of the maxillary sinus, and an enlargement may prevent drainage of the maxillary sinus
  • Posterior cells - They open into the superior or the supreme meatus. Occasionally, they may also open directly into the sphenoid sinus. They contain about 1-7 cells, the most important one being the Onodi cells. Onodi cells extend as far back as 1.5 centimeters from their anterior wall.

The image shown below shows the location of the Onodi cell or the sphenoethmoidal cell.

Haller cell (infraorbital ethmoidal air cell) is an anterior ethmoidal air cell that pneumatizes into the roof of maxillary sinus or orbital floor above the maxillary sinus ostium.

questions.text: A 14-year-old child comes to the ED after a fall on an outstretched hand. The X-ray of the left arm is shown below. The patient is unable to abduct the thumb and flex his wrist. There is a loss of sensation over the radial three-and-a-half digits. Distant pulses are faintly felt. Which of the following would be seen when the patient is asked to make a fist?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows an anteriorly displaced supracondylar fracture of the distal humerus. The clinical features described indicate a median nerve injury. When asked to make a fist, the position of the patient's hand with the above injuries would make a pointing index sign. 

The image shows the pointing index sign:

Median nerve injuries can be described as low or high lesions.

  • Low lesions involve injury to the median nerve in front of the wrist or carpal dislocations. There is loss of abduction of the thumb and loss of sensation over the radial three and a half digits.
  • High lesions involve injury to the median nerve due to forearm fractures or elbow dislocations. It features the same symptoms as low lesions and paralysis of the long flexors to the thumb, index, and middle fingers, the radial wrist flexors, and the forearm pronator muscles. So, when asked to make a fist, the patient flexes the ulnar fingers and extends the index finger, resulting in the pointing index sign. The patient also features a characteristic pinch defect because of deficient thumb and index finger flexors. The patient is not able to pinch with the thumb and index finger flexed. Instead, the patient pinches with fully extended distal joints.

Other options:

Options B and C: Median and ulnar claw hands are seen due to loss of lumbricals, overcompensated by the other extrinsic flexors. That is, the fingers extended at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexed at the proximal and distal interphalangeal joints. Since the median nerve supplies the lateral 3 digits, clawing is seen in these digits. The ulnar nerve supplies the medial digits, and if injured will lead to clawing of these digits.

Option D: The OK gesture/ sign is made when the thumb and the index finger are pinched together, forming a ring. When the ulnar nerve is injured, there is loss of action of the lumbricals in the 4th and 5th digits. So when asked to make a fist or flex his fingers, the patient will be able to flex only the thumb, index, and middle fingers, resulting in the OK gesture.

Note: The anterior interosseous nerve (AIN) of the median nerve is another commonly injured nerve in supracondylar fractures in children. It presents with the same symptoms as high lesions but without any sensory loss. Patients with anterior interosseous nerve injury are unable to make the OK gesture due to weakness of the flexors of the thumb and the index finger.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old medical student with dengue developed epistaxis which resolved spontaneously. He has been afebrile for 24 hrs but his platelet count is 18,000. What should be the management?

1. Give 4 units of platelets
2. Give plenty of oral fluids
3. Give IV fluids
4. Keep under observation
5. Discharge the patient
questions.solution:
Options 2, 3, and 4 are correct.

The main pathology in dengue is plasma leakage resulting in intravascular volume depletion and thereby shock. So, supportive management with continuous infusion of crystalloid IV fluids remains the primary modality of treatment in these patients. Oral rehydration is recommended. And often patients respond well to supportive management. 

Prophylactic platelet transfusion is limited to patients with severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000/mm3).

FFP and cryoglobulins are not the preferred treatment modality in dengue.

Warning signs of dengue include: 

  • Abdominal pain or tenderness
  • Persistent vomiting
  • Clinical fluid accumulation (ascites, pleural effusion)
  • Mucosal bleeding
  • Lethargy or restlessness
  • Hepatomegaly >2 cm
  • Increase in hematocrit concurrent with a rapid decrease in platelet count

Inpatient management is advised for all patients with dengue with warning signs.

questions.text: A young woman comes to the Suraksha clinic of the local primary health center. She is examined and the white kit is prescribed to her as treatment. Which of the following symptoms did the patient most likely present with?
questions.solution:
The patient most likely presented with a non-herpetic genital ulcer. 

Kit 3/ White Kit is used to treat patients with a non-herpetic genital ulcer.

All the partners in the last 3 months must be treated.

Contents and course:

Inj. Benzathine penicillin 2.4 MU stat +/ Tab. Azithromycin 1g stat.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text:
Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is used as the confirmatory test in which of the following conditions?

1. Mycetoma
2. Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid
3. Mediastinal tumour
4. Hepatic echinococcosis 
5. Granulomatous thyroiditis
questions.solution:
FNAC is used as the confirmatory test in diagnosing 1, 3, and 5 - mycetoma, mediastinal masses and granulomatous thyroiditis.

Fine needle aspiration cytology involves the puncture of the mass using a fine needle and immediate aspiration for assessment of cytology of the mass. A 21G or 23G needle and a 10 mL syringe are used. Aspiration must be done only when the needle is within the swelling. The sample is then smeared on a microscopic slide and fixed and sent for assessment. But if it can be immediately assessed, it can be sent without fixation. A positive FNA depends on the quality of the sample obtained and the skill of the cytologist.

It is used to sample accessible sites such as the breast, thyroid, and superficial lymph nodes. But, if FNA needs to be done for deeper structures, it is done under imaging guidance with ultrasound (USG) or computed tomography (CT). For example, USG-guided transbronchial FNA is used to assess mediastinal masses (3)

FNAC cannot distinguish between a follicular adenoma and a follicular carcinoma (2) of the thyroid. This distinction depends on histology based on capsular and vascular invasion and not on cytology. Diagnosis and treatment are made by wide local excision of the mass.

FNAC is also contraindicated in hepatic echinococcosis because of the risk of spillage of hydatid fluid, which can potentially cause peritoneal spread of the infestation and more importantly, fatal anaphylaxis.

There are certain contraindications for performing an FNAC : 

  • Hepatic echinococcosis
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Hepatic surface hemangioma
  • Scrotal / testicular masses (risk of tumour seeding)
  • Mass near carotid bifurcation (carotid body tumour)

questions.text:
A 32-year-old working IT professional came for the mobile cervical cancer screening camp planned in her work firm. Which of the following histories should be elicited in this patient before collecting the sample?

1. Ask about her last menstrual period/ date
2. Ask her when was the last time she had intercourse 
3. Ask her if she had used any douche while taking a bath
4. Ask her for any symptoms or history suggestive of immunosuppression 
5. Ask for a history of any contraceptive use
questions.solution:
The correct statements include 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5.

Pap or Papanicolaou test is a screening test only. A positive test requires further evaluation with colposcopy, cervical biopsy, or fractional curettage.

Specific history to be elicited in patients prior to collection of sample:

  • The ideal time for the collection of a sample is around ovulation. Cervical squamous cells vary in appearance throughout the menstrual cycle. Thus, asking the patient for their last menstrual and any use of contraception is a must. (Statement 1)
  • A pre-requisite for a pap smear is that the patient should avoid intercourse 24 hours prior to the test. Thus, this history should be taken. (Statement 2)
  • The use of lubricants and douches may prevent the detection of organisms and the cell structure. Thus, asking the patient for this history is a must to prevent missing appropriate findings. (Statement 3)
  • History of immunosuppression must be elicited, including a family history of cancer, use of steroids, sexual history for STDs, and HIV/AIDS. In women with such a history, an annual checkup should be advised instead of once every three years. (Statement 4)
  • The use of intravaginal contraceptive creams should be stopped 24-48 hours before the test. The use of exogenous hormones and intrauterine devices may alter the appearance of cervical squamous cells. Hence, this history should be noted for an accurate interpretation of the test. (Statement 5)

Screening guidelines:

  • Time for initiation - 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse
  • Women aged 21-29 years - every 3 years
  • Women who are aged 30-65 years - Pap test + HPV testing every 5 years
  • Women can stop cervical cancer screening after the age of 65 years. If suspicious PAP, screening till 75 years
  • HIV+ve women - annual screening 
  • HPV DNA testing in combination with PAP improves the sensitivity of screening.

Procedure:

The patient is put in a dorsal position and Cusco’s self-retaining speculum is introduced. The squamocolumnar junction is identified and scraped with Ayre’s spatula. Endocervix is scarped with a cytobrush. Samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides. The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol and stained with Pap stain or short stain.

The most common fixative used in pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol. The instruments used for pap smears are summarized in the image below.

 

The image below sums up the steps of collection of a sample for Pap testing.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text:
Match the following types of psoriasis with the areas they commonly involve.
i. Discoid psoriasis a. Flexural surfaces
ii. Inverse psoriasis b. Extensor surfaces
iii. Guttate psoriasis c. Para-nasal areas
iv. Seborrheic psoriasis d. Trunk
questions.solution:
The correctly matched set is i-b, ii-a, iii-d, iv-c. 

i. Discoid psoriasis b. Extensor surfaces
ii. Inverse psoriasis a. Flexural surfaces
iii. Guttate psoriasis d. Trunk 
iv. Seborrheic psoriasis c. Para nasal areas

Psoriasis is characterized by erythematous plaques covered with silver scales. It generally affects the extensor surfaces. The peak occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years.

Plaque psoriasis or discoid psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis. It presents with pruritis and a papulosquamous rash. Lesions can be described as red, scaly, and a well-defined demarcation from the normal skin. The scales often appear white and silvery. The lesions may be encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring. They are seen in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

An image of plaque psoriasis is shown below:

 

Inverse psoriasis or flexural psoriasis or intertriginous psoriasis refers to psoriasis of the flexural areas such as the inguinal creases, axillae, inframammary, and other body folds. Unlike characteristic lesions of psoriasis, these plaques are thin, with minimal or no scaling. The surface is glazed with fissuring.

Inverse psoriasis may manifest as new lesions occurring on the body or the Koebner phenomenon on top of existing intertriginous dermatoses, or it may be present along with classical plaque psoriasis. It typically involves the diaper area in infants, referred to as napkin psoriasis. It may also affect older, obese patients.

Guttate psoriasis usually has a sudden onset of small lesions on the trunk and proximal limbs, in children. It usually occurs weeks after streptococcal pharyngitis. It is shown in the image below.

Seborrhoeic psoriasis or sebopsoriasis presents as thin, demarcated erythema with scales. It is typically seen in areas that are involved in seborrhoeic dermatitis - paranasal areas, external ears, medial eyebrows, hairline, presternal, and interscapular chest wall.

 

Other types of psoriasis include:

  • Pustular psoriasis - the appearance of macroscopic pustules within lesions.
  • Erythrodermic psoriasis - an uncommon type where almost the entire body is affected, and the patient is systemically ill. 
  • Unstable psoriasis or active psoriasis or eruptive inflammatory psoriasis - characterised by actively enlarging erythematous plaques, with the development of new smaller plaques

Psoriasis may affect specific sites. These include:

  • Scalp psoriasis
  • Follicular psoriasis
  • Seborrhoeic psoriasis or sebopsoriasis
  • Flexural psoriasis or inverse psoriasis
  • Genital psoriasis
  • Non‐pustular palmoplantar psoriasis
  • Nail psoriasis
  • Ocular psoriasis
  • Mucosal psoriasis

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

Related Pearl: Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

Treatment Ladder for Psoriasis

I. In Mild Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • Coal tar
  • Dithranol
  • Potent topical steroid
  • Vitamin D analogue

Second line

  • Local NB-UVB or PUVA
  • Excimer laser

II. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis Without Arthritis

First line

  • NB-UVB or PUVA

Second line

  • Acitretin
  • Apremilast
  • Ciclosporin
  • Fumaric acid esters (where available)
  • Methotrexate

Third line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Secukinumab
  • Ustekinumab

III. In Moderate or Severe Psoriasis with Psoriatic Arthritis

First line

  • Apremilast
  • Methotrexate

Second line

  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab
  • Ustekinumab

Third line

  • Combination therapy

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Bartter’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Bartter’s syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder, not autosomal dominant. 

Bartter’s syndrome is a group of disorders associated with disturbances in electrolyte and acid/base balance, sometimes with nephrocalcinosis and other features. It occurs due to inactivating mutations of genes encoding Na-K-2Cl transport in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. 

Patients with classic BS typically suffer from polyuria and polydipsia, due to the reduction in renal concentrating ability. The combination of hypokalemia and alkalosis in a normotensive, nonedematous patient can be due to Bartter’s or Gitelman’s syndrome. Bartter’s syndrome is distinguished from Gitelman’s syndrome because of hypocalciuria in the latter disorder.

Patients with antenatal BS suffer from a severe systemic disorder characterised by marked electrolyte wasting, polyhydramnios, and hypercalciuria with nephrocalcinosis. Prostaglandin E2 synthesis and excretion are significantly increased accounting for much of the systemic symptoms. Other features include marked activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone axis. 

The form associated with sensorineural deafness has a mutation in the Barttin gene.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: A 7-month-old baby was brought with irritability, vomiting, and seizures. The mother reports that he was breastfed for 6 months and cereals and fruit juices were recently introduced into the diet. On examination, icterus and hepatomegaly were noted. Investigations revealed hypoglycemia and Benedict's test of the urine showed the finding as given below.  Which of the following is most likely to be deficient in him?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario, the child becomes symptomatic after ingesting fruit juice that contains fructose, and Benedict's test showing positive results for reducing sugars points towards a diagnosis of hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI). This condition is caused due to the deficiency of aldolase B.

Aldolase B converts fructose-1-phosphate to glyceraldehyde. The deficiency of aldolase B results in the accumulation of fructose 1-phosphate. This decreases the levels of inorganic phosphate and ATPs. ATP is required for gluconeogenesis and protein synthesis. Therefore, the patient presents with hypoglycemia and acidosis. 

Patients are asymptomatic until fructose or sucrose is ingested (usually from fruit, fruit juice, sweetened cereal, or table sugar). They present with profound hypoglycemia and vomiting after ingestion of fructose-containing foods. If the condition is not treated it might lead to the impairment of liver functioning.

Diagnosis is made by detecting reducing sugars in the urine, enzyme assay, or DNA testing for the mutations in the ALDOB gene. Once the diagnosis of HFI is made, the source of fructose must be removed from the diet.

Other options:

Option B: Fructokinase converts fructose to fructose-1-phosphate. Patients with a deficiency of this enzyme are usually asymptomatic as the accumulated fructose is eliminated from urine. This condition is called essential fructosuria.

Options C and D: Deficiency of galactose 1-phosphate uridyl transferase and galactokinase can result in similar symptoms. But it starts as soon as breastfeeding is initiated as the patient cannot metabolise galactose present in the breastmilk. The affected children might also have cataracts due to the accumulation of galactitol in the lens.

Related Pearl: Test for Carbohydrates

Purpose of test

Names of tests

Test for all carbohydrates

Molisch test

For reducing sugars

Benedicts test

Differentiate between mono- and disaccharides

Barfoed’s test                        

Moore’s test                                        

Fehling’s test

Differentiate aldoses and ketoses

Seliwanoff’s test

Rapid furfural test

Foulger’s test

Detect Deoxy sugars

Feulgen Staining

Test for Pentoses

Bial’s test

Test for Galactose

Mucic acid test

questions.text: Identify the components of the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing tool.
questions.solution:
The components of the CRISPR-9 gene-editing tool are guide RNA and Cas9 nuclease.

CRISPR-Cas9 is a genome editing tool and this system enables select bacteria to respond to and eliminate invading genetic material. It uses guide RNA transcribed from CRISPR DNA (Clustered Regularly Interspersed Palindromic Repeats of DNA) and a Cas9 (CRISPR-associated protein 9) nuclease.

The guide RNA targets and binds to specific complementary sequences of DNA which are then cleaved by Cas9. Following cleavage of the targeted DNA sequence, the natural DNA repair process can be allowed to proceed or a new sequence can be inserted.

This technique can be used for gene deletion, gene editing, gene visualization, and modulation of gene transcription.

The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2020 was awarded jointly to Emmanuelle Charpentier and Jennifer A. Doudna for the development of the CRISPR/ Cas9 gene-editing system, which has for the first time enabled scientists to make precise changes in the long stretches of DNA.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presents for a health check-up, during which the doctor finds that he is reluctant to talk about his illnesses. He is suspicious that the information will be used to harm him. He does not trust his family either for the same reason. He does not forgive easily and bears grudges. What is the type of personality disorder that he has?
questions.solution:
The given history of long-standing suspiciousness, not trusting people, and bearing grudges for insults is suggestive of paranoid personality disorder.

Paranoid personality disorder, a part of cluster A personality disorders, is characterized by pervasive suspiciousness and mistrust in all interpersonal relationships. They are excessively fearful of perceived threats and deceit and often read hidden demeaning or threatening meanings into benign remarks. They are reluctant to confide in others due to the fear that the information they provide will be used against them maliciously.

They tend to be extremely jealous, hostile, argumentative, and defensive. Their paranoia prevents them from establishing any overly involved relationship. They persistently bear grudges and can get irritable and angry easily. They use the defense mechanism of projection by displacing their insecurities on others. 

They may not be willing to accept that they need psychiatric help. Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice. Care should be taken by the therapist to not behave defensively if accused of making a mistake. Pharmacotherapy is generally used to deal with anxiety and agitation. Diazepam is used as an anxiolytic, while antipsychotics like haloperidol or pimozide may be required to deal with agitation.

Other options:

Option A: Individuals with schizoid personality disorder are usually eccentric and isolated. They neither desire nor enjoy close relationships. They always choose to be alone and lack close friends. They are emotionally cold and appear indifferent to praise or criticism.

Option B: Individuals with schizotypal personality disorder appear odd and strange to surrounding people. They have ideas of reference, odd or magical thinking, inappropriate or constricted affect, and suspiciousness.

Option D: Individuals with histrionic personality disorder have excessive emotional and attention-seeking behaviour. They are uncomfortable in situations where they are not the centre of attraction. They also have inappropriate, sexually seductive, or provocative behaviour. They try to use their physical appearance to draw others' attention.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text: While prescribing levonorgestrel as post-coital emergency contraception, you would advise for ______.

choices.text: 5 mg single dose within 24 hours of unprotected intercourse
0.75 mg single dose within 24 hours of unprotected intercourse
3 mg single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse
1.5 mg single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse

questions.solution:
Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse can be used for emergency contraception. Alternatively, it can also be administered in two doses of 0.75 mg. 1st dose is taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse and the 2nd dose 12 hours apart. 

Emergency contraception refers to backup methods for contraceptive emergencies which women can use within the first few days after unprotected intercourse to prevent an unwanted pregnancy. Administration of postcoital contraceptive agents that interfere with postovulatory events that can lead to pregnancy. 

The various emergency contraceptive methods along with their mechanism of action have been described below:

IUCD (intrauterine contraceptive device) prevents the implantation of a fertilized ovum. It does so by acting as a foreign body within the uterine cavity. This leads to increased contractility, and tubal peristalsis, and promotes leukocytic infiltration in the endometrium. 

Ulipristal is given as a 30 mg tablet and should be taken within 5 days. It is a synthetic progesterone hormone receptor modulator. The drug attaches to the progesterone receptor, delays ovulation and suppresses endometrium, thereby preventing implantation.

Ethinyl estradiol 50 μg + norgestrel 0.25 mg is administered as two tablets within 72 hours of coitus followed by the 2 tablets after 12 hours. The hormone may delay ovulation if taken soon after intercourse. 

Centchroman is administered as two tablets of 60 mg taken twice over a duration of 24 hours and within 24 hours of intercourse. It acts by preventing the implantation of the blastocyst in the endometrium. 

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

Related Pearl: Classification Of Contraceptives Based On Effectiveness

Category Failure rate in first year Contraceptive
First tier  < 2 % IUCD, Implants, Sterilization
Second tier  3-9 % Hormonal - oral, injected, transdermal patches, transvaginal rings
Third tier  10-20 % Barrier, Fertility awareness method
Fourth tier  21-30 % Spermicidal preparations

questions.text: A 24-years-old woman presented with patchy hair loss. Examination revealed non-scarring alopecia with multiple small broken hairs. Scrapings from the scalp showed mild inflammation, peri-follicular hemorrhage, and surrounding mild lymphocytic infiltration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given findings point to a diagnosis of trichotillomania. 

Trichotillomania is a disorder characterized by the compulsive pulling of hair. It is predominantly seen in females and is almost always associated with psychological or behavioral stress disorders like OCD (obsessive-compulsive disorder), BDD (body dysmorphic disorder), intellectual disability, or even psychosis. 

It presents as an area of patchy hair loss, often in a bizarre pattern. The hairs are often twisted and broken at varying lengths or may be present as uniform, coarse stubble. The scalp skin appears normal. Sites other than the scalp can also be affected, for example - eyelashes, eyebrows, beard, mons pubis, and perianal region.

Dermoscopy of the scalp helps in differentiating it from alopecia areata - follicular orifices appear as yellow dots in trichotillomania.

Scalp biopsy shows intraepithelial and perifollicular hemorrhages. The presence of numerous empty canals is the most consistent feature. Also, severely damaged follicles and clefts in the hair matrix are also seen. The follicular epithelium separates from the connec­tive tissue sheath.

Other options: 

Option A: Androgenetic alopecia is a disorder characterized by a reduction of hair fibre production by follicles and miniaturization. Dihydrotestosterone, an androgenic metabolite, is implicated in the etiology. It is of two types, male pattern and female pattern hair loss. Male pattern hair loss causes frontal hairline recession and thinning of the vertex.  Female-pattern hair loss involves the mid-frontal scalp diffusely. There is no or minimal involvement of the temporal region.

Option C: Alopecia areata preferentially targets pigmented hair. Older patients with grey hair have a mixture of white and pigmented hair. If the disease progresses rapidly, only pigmented hair will be affected, sparing the white hair. This leads to a dramatic change in overall hair color that is called going white overnight.

Option D: Telogen effluvium leads to diffuse hair loss that affects all hair equally, not just pigmented hair. So, overall hair color will not be affected.

Related Pearl: Causes of scarring and non-scarring alopecia- Mnemonic

Alopecia or hair loss can be classified as :

  1. Non-Scarring/Non-Cicatricial alopecia
  2. Scarring/Cicatricial alopecia 

Mnemonic for causes of non-scarring alopecia: THATS STD!

  • Tinea capitis(Non-Inflammatory Type  - grey patch and black dot types )
  • Hormonal - Hypothyroidism, Androgenetic alopecia
  • Anagen effluvium, Alopecia areata
  • Trichotillomania
  • Secondary syphilis (moth-eaten alopecia)
  • SLE(predominantly causes non-scarring alopecia but also can cause scarring alopecia)
  • Telogen effluvium
  • Deficiency of Zinc, Iron 

Mnemonic for causes of scarring alopecia: SF2L3

  • Scleroderma - Linear scalp morphea (en coup de sabre)
  • Favus and Kerion (Inflammatory Type of Tinea capitis)
  • Folliculitis decalvans
  • Lichen planopilaris
  • Lupus vulgaris
  • Lupus erythematosis - discoid (DLE)
  • Pseudopelade of Brocq

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are not at an increased risk of developing colorectal cancer?
questions.solution:
Patients with a solitary juvenile polyp are not at an increased risk to develop colorectal cancer.

A juvenile polyp is a bright-red, pedunculated sphere found in infants and children. It can cause bleeding, or pain during defecation if it prolapses. It usually separates itself and can be easily removed using a forceps or a snare.

A solitary juvenile polyp has no tendency to malignant transformation. Histologically, it appears as a large mucus-filled space covered by a smooth surface of thin cuboidal epithelium. Rarely, juvenile polyposis (multiple polyps) and positive family history may develop into a malignancy.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, Turcot syndrome (a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis coli [FAP] syndrome), and Muir-Torre syndrome (a variant of hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer [HNPCC]) are associated with an increased risk of colorectal cancer.

Colorectal polyps can be classified as:

Neoplastic:

Adenomatous polyps:

  • Tubular adenoma 
  • Tubulovillous adenomas
  • Villous adenoma (highest risk of malignancy)

Non-neoplastic:

  • Hyperplastic- benign
  • Hamartomatous
    • Juvenile polyp (solitary)- benign
    • Juvenile polyposis syndromes (multiple)- premalignant
    • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome - premalignant
    • Cronkite-Canada syndrome
  • Inflammatory
    • Pseudopolyp (seen in ulcerative colitis)- benign
    • Benign lymphoid polyp

Familial adenomatous polyposis coli [FAP] syndrome (APC gene mutation)- 100% risk of colorectal cancer. It has the following two variants:

  1. Gardner syndrome- features of FAP syndrome, osteomas, desmoid tumours, epidermoid cysts, and congenital hypertrophy of retinal epithelium
  2. Turcot syndrome - features of FAP syndrome, and brain tumours (cerebellar medulloblastoma and glioblastomas)

Hereditary Nonpolyposis Colon Cancer (HNPCC) is associated with a 70-80% lifetime risk for colorectal cancer. The Muir-Torre variant of HNPCC is characterized by sebaceous adenomas, keratoacanthomas, sebaceous epitheliomas, and basal cell epitheliomas. 

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Colorectal Cancer

The risk factors for colorectal cancer are:

  • Dietary:
    • High-animal-fat diet
    • Low-fiber diet
    • Alcohol
  • Hereditary syndromes:
    • FAP
    • HNPCC
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Cholecystectomy: increased right colon cancer due to exposure to bile acids
  • Ureterosigmoidostomy
  • Smoking
  • Acromegaly
  • Pelvic irradiation

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents with complaints of fever and rash. The fever developed 5 days back and the rash was first noticed 2 days back on the face, which then progressed to his trunk. He is diagnosed with measles. What is the recommended period of isolation for measles?

choices.text: From onset of rash to 3 days after rash onset
2 weeks before rash to 1 week after rash onset
During full course of the disease
From catarrhal stage to 7 days after rash onset

questions.solution:
The isolation period for measles is from the catarrhal stage to 7 days after the onset of the rash.

The incubation period is commonly 10 days from exposure to onset of fever, and 14 days from appearance of the rash. 

Measles can be divided into 3 phases:

1) The prodromal (catarrhal) stage

The prodromal phase begins at the onset of the first symptoms, which begin gradually and include a fever, a cough, a runny nose, and red eyes. Usually, the fever is the first symptom noticed by parents. The fever rises steadily and may reach maximum temperatures of 103F to 104F.

The runny nose with a profuse watery discharge, nasal congestion, and sneezing becomes prominent. Typically, there is a pronounced cough, which is hoarse, dry, and hacking. Some children may complain of tightening in the chest. The red eyes are characterized by increased tearing, eye pain that may be severe, and sensitivity to light. Other symptoms that are frequently observed during the prodromal phase include fatigue, irritability, a decreased appetite, a headache, abdominal pain, and a dry mouth and throat. Koplik spots are the peculiar spots present on the buccal mucosa and are considered to be a diagnostic/pathognomic feature of measles/rubeola in the prodromal stage.

2) The eruptive phase

Approximately two to four days after the onset of the symptoms, the rash appears, marking the beginning of the rash phase. The symptoms of the prodromal phase worsen with the onset of the rash, but then begin to decrease in severity. The measles rash is a flat or slightly raised rash and is not itchy. It first appears as irregular spots on the upper forehead or behind the ears and on the neck. Within 24 hours, it progresses to the entire face, head, and neck. Over the next two to four days, the rash extends to the chest, back, and extremities (as seen in the image shown), including the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. It remains most prominent on the face, especially on the cheeks.

3) The recovery phase

After four to five days, the rash begins to subside, marking the beginning of the recovery phase. Sometimes, a fine flaking of the skin is noted as the rash fades. About 10 to 14 days after developing the rash, the child is back to a normal level of activity.

The period of communicability is approximately 4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of the rash. Isolation of the patient for a week from the onset of rash more than covers the period of communicability.

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

questions.text:
Choose the correct statement regarding the oxygen delivery rate and the advantage of using the device shown below.

PEEP - positive end-expiratory pressure
questions.solution:
The correct statement regarding the oxygen delivery rate and the advantage of using high-flow nasal cannula is that it delivers oxygen at 40-60 L/min and increases positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP).

High flow nasal cannula is a mode of respiratory support used in the management of acute respiratory failure. It delivers humidified gas via the nasal cannula at high flow rates.

  • HFNC can deliver oxygen at 40L/min, 37°C, and 99.9% relative humidity.
  • The high-flow oxygen is delivered directly to the nasopharynx. This produces FiO2 equal to that delivered by traditional mask devices.

Advantages of using a high-flow nasal cannula are:

  • Soft and pliable nasal prongs provide comfort to the patient.
  • Warming and humidification of secretions: The heating of air to core temperature and humidification of the inspired air is better at high flow. The humidification causes increased water content in the secretions, which facilitates the removal of secretions. It also decreases the work of breathing and avoids airway desiccation and epithelial injury.
  • Reduces dead space: The high flow of the oxygen delivered clears the upper airway of the expired air, which reduces dead space by a decrease of rebreathing and allows a higher fraction of minute ventilation to participate in alveolar gas exchange.
  • Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP): HFNC increases the positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP), and reduces the work of breathing.
  • High flow rate causes decreased entrainment of room air, allowing more accurate delivery of oxygen. 

The HFNC equipment shown in the image below uses a heated humidifier (named PMH200), a nasal cannula (no. 2), and a ventilator (brand: vivo30).

questions.text: A 1-year-old baby is brought to the emergency room with bluish discoloration of the skin and rapid breathing. His mother reveals a history of congenital heart disease in the baby and adds that this episode was provoked by an incessant cry. Which of the following is least likely to be used for managing this child?
questions.solution:
The least likely drug to be used for managing this child is intravenous nitroglycerin. The given scenario is suggestive of a paroxysmal hypercyanotic attack/ cyanotic spell. The administration of intravenous nitroglycerin is of no use and can worsen the condition, as it decreases peripheral resistance.

Paroxysmal hypercyanotic spells may also be referred to as tet spells/ blue spells/ hypoxic spells. Though commonly associated with Tetralogy of Fallot, they can be associated with other forms of pulmonary stenosis with ventricular septal defect as well. Precipitating factors include crying, defecation, feeding, wakening from sleep, dehydration, fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and events provoking agitation.

They are characterized by:

  • Period of uncontrolled crying/ panic/ irritability
  • Rapid and deep breathing
  • Increased cyanosis
  • Limpness and lethargy
  • Reduced murmur intensity (signifying substantial blood flow reduction across the right ventricular outflow tract)

Management options for this child include the following:

  • Calm the child and minimize the stimuli
  • Place in the knee-chest position
  • Administer oxygen
  • Subcutaneous morphine (not in excess of 0.2mg/kg)
  • IV sodium bicarbonate - for correction of the ongoing metabolic acidosis
  • IV phenylephrine - as it increases the systemic vascular resistance
  • IV propranolol - as it reduces the pulmonary infundibular spasms in TOF
  • If the spell is resistant to all the above-said measures, then intubation and sedation of the child are required to break the spell

Related Pearl: Classification of congenital heart disease

Acyanotic
Cyanotic (5TE²VP)
Left to right shunts:

Ventricular septal defect (VSD)

Atrial septal defect (ASD)

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)

Obstructive lesions:

Coarctation of aorta

Infundibular stenosis

Pulmonary valve stenosis

Congenital mitral & tricuspid regurgitation
Right to left shunt:

Persistent Truncus arteriosus

Transposition of great vessels

Tricuspid atresia

Tetrology of Fallot

Total anomalous pulmonary venous communication

Ebstein anomaly

Eisenmenger's syndrome

VSD with pulmonic stenosis

Pulmonary arteriovenous malformation

questions.text:
Arrange the following sentences in the correct order for activation of B cells.

1. T-helper cells interact with the presented antigen peptides.
2. Improved quality of the immune response with affinity maturation.
3. Internalisation and degradation of the antigens.
4. Somatic hypermutation and immunoglobulin isotype class switching occur.
5. Antigen binding to B cell receptor.
6. Binding of CD40 ligand on T cells to CD 40 on B cells.
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of B cell activation is as follows:

5. Antigen binding to a B cell receptor.

3. Internalisation and degradation of the antigen.

1. T helper cells interact with the presented antigen peptides.

6. Binding of CD40 ligand on T cells to CD 40 on B cells. 

4. Somatic hypermutation and immunoglobulin isotype class switching occur.

2. Improved quality of the immune response with affinity maturation.

On activation, B cells proliferate and differentiate into plasma cells that secrete functionally distinct classes of antibodies. Most antibody responses are T-cell-dependent. The Ig receptors on B cells recognize antigens and facilitate the endocytosis of the antigens. The endocytosed antigens are degraded and the antigen peptides are displayed bound to the MHC class-II. The T helper cells recognize these antigen peptides and express CD40 ligand. The interaction between CD40 B cell receptors and CD40 ligand induces isotype switching. Isotype switching is the process of production of different classes of antibodies. Somatic hypermutation is the process by which antibody-producing activated B cells undergo extremely high rates of mutation in their hypervariable regions to produce antibodies specific to the antigen. The T helper cells also improve the affinity of the antibody to the antigen. This process is called affinity maturation. 

Related Pearl: Immune Cell Antigens Detected by Monoclonal Antibodies

Immune cells

Antigens associated

T-cell

CD1, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD8

B-cell

CD10, CD19, CD20, CD21, CD23, CD79a

Monocyte or macrophage

CD11c, CD13, CD14, CD15, CD33, CD64

NK-cell

CD16, CD56

Hematopoietic stem cells

CD34
Leukocyte common antigen CD45
Activated B cells, T cells, monocytes, and Reed-Sternberg cells CD30

 

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, complement fixation and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: A patient has been on warfarin therapy for the past 6 months after suffering from deep vein thrombosis. Administration of which of the following drugs would increase the risk of hemorrhage in this patient?
questions.solution:
The administration of ketoconazole would increase the risk of hemorrhage in a patient who is on warfarin. 

Warfarin is metabolized by a CYP2C9 cytochrome complex and ketoconazole is an enzyme inhibitor. Co-administration of these two drugs will result in decreased metabolism of warfarin leading to increased plasma concentration. This results in warfarin overdose and subsequent haemorrhagic symptoms. 

Other drugs that can enhance the risk of hemorrhage on co-administration with warfarin include amiodarone, cimetidine, metronidazole, clopidogrel, isoniazid, cotrimoxazole, etc. 

Enzyme inducers Enzyme inhibitors

Mnemonic: CRAP GPS

  • Carbamazepine
  • Rifampicin
  • Alcohol (chronic)
  • Phenytoin
  • Griseofulvin
  • Phenobarbitone
  • Sulfonylureas

Mnemonic: RED VICK

  • Ritonavir
  • Erythromycin
  • Diltiazem
  • Verapamil, Valproate
  • Itraconazole
  • Clarithromycin, Cimetidine
  • Ketoconazole

Other options:

Griseofulvin, carbamazepine, and phenobarbitone are enzyme inducers. These will cause excess degradation of warfarin leading to ineffective anti-coagulant treatment.

questions.text: Arrange in sequence the cyclins at different stages of the cell cycle starting from the G1 (Gap 1) to the G2 (Gap 2) phase.

choices.text: Cyclin B- Cyclin E- Cyclin A- Cyclin D
Cyclin E- Cyclin B- Cyclin A-  Cyclin D
Cyclin D- Cyclin E- Cyclin A-  Cyclin B
Cyclin B- Cyclin A- Cyclin E-  Cyclin D

questions.solution:
The correct sequence of cyclins through G1- S- G2 phase is  Cyclin D- Cyclin E- Cyclin A- Cyclin B.

Cell cycle progression is driven by the formation of complexes of proteins called cyclins and associated enzymes known as cyclin-dependent kinases. Cyclins are synthesized only during the cell cycle to regulate the progression of the cell across the phases of the cell cycle, while cyclin-dependent kinases are constitutively present irrespective of the cell cycle.

Cyclins D, E, A, and B appear sequentially during the cell cycle and bind to one or more CDKs.

  1. G1-S transition: Cyclin D-CDK4, cyclin D-CDK6, and cyclin E-CDK2.
  2. S-phase: Cyclin A-CDK1 and cyclin A-CDK2.
  3. G2-M transition: Cyclin B-CDK1.

CDK inhibitors (CDKIs) enforce the cell cycle checkpoints. There are several families of CDKIs:

  • CDKIs that broadly inhibit multiple CDKs: p21, p27, p57
  • CDKIs that inhibit CDK4 and CDK6: p15, p16, p18, and p19

The image below shows the different checkpoints and cell cycle regulators :

CDK : Cyclin-dependent kinase

questions.text: The following diagram shows the pattern of respiration in a 55-year-old man. Identify the pattern of breathing and its associated possible cause.
questions.solution:
The pattern of breathing seen in the image is Kussmaul’s breathing and one of its associated causes includes sepsis.

Kussmaul’s breathing is a type of deep, rapid breathing usually due to metabolic acidosis, but can also occur with ponto-mesencephalic lesions.

Normally, the H+ ions from acids in our body are buffered with various mechanisms. But in cases, where acid production is high like in diabetic ketoacidosis and sepsis, the buffering capacity is exceeded. The resulting acidosis stimulates respiration and decreases alveolar CO2 in order to produce a compensatory fall in the H+ ions.

Other options:

Option A. Biot's breathing is characterized by regular deep respirations with periods of apnea. It occurs due to pontine damage by stroke, trauma, or uncal herniation. 

Options B: Cheyne-Stokes breathing is characterized by progressively deeper and sometimes faster breathing (crescendo-decrescendo cycles), with periods of apnoea. It is seen in patients with heart failure and uremia. This pattern of breathing is associated with increased sensitivity to arterial PCO2 and prolonged lung-to-brain circulation time.

questions.text: An unclaimed dead body was brought for forensic examination. Postmortem examination reveals a complete fusion of the joint shown with the arrow mark in the below image. What would be the approximate age of this person?
questions.solution:
The arrow points to the manubrio-sternal joint which fuses in old age usually above 50 years of age.

The sternum is formed from the fusion of the manubrium, the body, and the xiphoid process. The fusion of the 4 pieces of the body of the sternum occurs from below upwards, followed by its fusion to the xiphoid process and then the fusion of manubrium to the fused sternum.

Joints 

Age of fusion
Fusion of manubrium with body

Usually above 50 years 
Fusion of body segments  14-25 years from below upwards
Fusion of xiphoid process with body 40-45 years

questions.solution:

questions.text: Identify step 3 in the given cataract surgery procedure.
questions.solution:
The picture illustrates extracapsular cataract extraction by the phacoemulsification method. Step 3 indicates hydro dissection.

Hydrodissection is the process of separating the capsule from the nucleus and cortex by injecting fluid between the two. This step is used in all extracapsular cataract extraction procedures and is mandatory in phacoemulsification and manual small incision cataract surgeries.

The steps involved in the cataract surgery are: 

  • Step 1 - small clear corneal incision 
  • Step 2 - continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis
  • Step 3 - hydro dissection, which also facilitates rotation and manipulation of the nucleus during emulsification of the lens
  • Step 4 - hydro delineation is done in some cases. This is done by injecting fluid between the nucleus and epinuclear lens substance. It aids in the separation of the cortex from the nucleus
  • Steps 5 and 6 - indicate the divide and conquer technique for the removal of the nucleus after phacoemulsification
  • Step 7 - removal of the cortical lens matter using an irrigation-aspiration technique
  • Step 8 - implantation of a foldable lens

Related Pearl: Different extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) techniques

Conventional ECCE

  • Incision: 10 to 2 o'clock
  • Anterior capsulotomy
    • Can opener’s technique
    • Envelope technique
    • Continuous circular capsulorrhexis

Manual SICS

  • Incision: 4-6 mm
  • A self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel incision is made.

Phacoemulsification

  • Incision:1.5–2.4 mm
  • Phacoprobe and foldable IOL is used
  • Sutureless surgery is possible with self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel or clear corneal incision.

questions.text:
Match the following E. coli with their respective toxins.
E. coli Mechanism of action
1. ETEC a. Produces EAST-1 toxin 
2. EHEC b. Produces a heat-stable and heat-labile toxin 
3. EAEC c. Produces verocytotoxin against vascular endothelial cells
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are as follows:

E. coli Mechanism of action
1. ETEC b. Produces a heat-stable and heat-labile toxin 
2. EHEC c. Produces verocytotoxin against vascular endothelial cells
3. EAEC a. Produces EAST-1 toxin

The various strains of Escherichia coli are:

Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) is the most common organism causing traveler’s diarrhea. It produces the following toxins:

  • LT (heat-labile toxin)- acts by ↑cAMP.
  • ST (heat-stable toxin)- two types of ST are known, ST-A (ST-I) and ST-B (ST-II)
    • ST-A is soluble in methanol and acts by ↑cGMP in the intestine. 
    • ST-B is insoluble in methanol, and the mode of action is not known.

Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) produces verocytotoxin, which targets vascular endothelium. It causes hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uremic syndrome.

Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) produces the stacked brick pattern of adherence on hep-2 cells. EAEC has been associated with persistent diarrhea. Intestinal colonization of EAEC is mediated by AAF (aggregative adherence fimbriae). EAEC produces EAST-1 toxin (enteroaggregative heat-stable toxin) which is considered to be a major virulence factor.

Enteroinvasive E.coli (EIEC) invades interstitial epithelial cells in the intestine and causes a condition resembling shigellosis. This ability is determined by a plasmid, which can be detected as a diagnostic test. 

Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) causes infantile diarrhea in developing countries. It adheres to the mucosal surface of the small intestine using E. coli adherent factor (EAF) and locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) and causes effacement of microvilli.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions does this capnography waveform appear?
questions.solution:
The above capnography waveform shows an elevated inspiratory baseline, which depicts rebreathing of CO2. 

Rebreathing of CO2 may occur due to exhausted soda lime or incompetent expiratory valve in closed-circuit breathing systems.

Waveform capnography is a continuous non-invasive measurement and graphical display of the EtCO2. It is a direct measure of lung ventilation and an indirect measure of circulation and metabolism.

The normal capnograph displays the exhaled CO2 in both the inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components:

  • Phase I: exhalation of dead space gas (i.e., partial pressure of CO2, pCO2 ∼0).
  • Phase II: A sharp rise in pCO2 to a plateau indicates the sampling of transitional gas between the airways and alveoli. 
  • Phase III: The plateau region of the capnograph, corresponds to the pCO2 in the alveolar compartment. 
  • Following phase III, a sharp inspiratory downstroke occurs, which is referred to as the beginning of phase 0 or phase IV by some authors.


Other options:

Option A- Oesophageal intubation shows a capnograph with some carbon dioxide detected initially followed by the absence of carbon dioxide. Swallowed air in the stomach would cause the initial detection of CO2 which is soon washed out and the ETCO2 comes to zero.


Option B- Bronchospasm (due to asthma, COPD) shows capnography with no plateau before the next inspiration and an increased upslope of phase III. This pattern can also be seen if the endotracheal tube or breathing circuit is partially obstructed. 


Option D- Malignant hyperthermia is associated with a dramatic increase in body temperature and muscle rigidity. The increased metabolic rate caused by malignant hyperthermia causes a marked rise in ETCO2.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: Which of the following components are produced by the Th1 cells?
questions.solution:
Interleukin-2 and interferon-γ are produced by the Th1 cells. 

CD 4+ cells become one of the following effector cells. They are Th1 cells, Th2 cells, Th17 cells, Tfh cells or T regulatory (T reg) cells.

Th1 cells: These cells are triggered in response to interleukin-2 and interleukin-12. They cause activation of macrophages and cause B cells to switch into different classes of IgG. This leads to the direct destruction of the bacterial cells and their clearance by the interferon-γ activated macrophages or by the phagocytosis of opsonized particles. Th1 cells produce interleukin-2 and interferon-γ.

Other options:

Option B- Interleukin-4 and interleukin-5 are produced by the Th2 cells. Th2 cells also secrete interleukins-9 and 13. These cells cause the activation of mast cells and eosinophils. They stimulate B cells to produce IgE. These cells are helpful in protecting patients from helminth infections.

Option C- Interleukins 21, 22 and 17 are produced from the Th17 cells. Th17 cells are produced in response to transforming growth factor-β, interleukins-6 and 23. Interleukin-17 induces the production of interleukin-8, which is a potent chemotactic factor.

Option D- Transforming growth factor-β and interleukin-10 are produced by the T reg cells. These chemokines suppress the immune responses.

Related Pearl: T Helper cells- Types and functions

Cell Type

T helper cell 1

T helper 2

T helper 17

Major cytokines produced

IFN-γ

IL-4, IL-5, IL-13

IL-17, IL-22

Cytokines that induce this subset

IFN-γ, IL-12

IL-4

TGF-β, IL-6, IL-1, IL-23

Immunological reactions triggered

Macrophage activation, stimulation of IgG antibody production

Stimulation of IgE production, activation of mast cells and eosinophils

Recruitment of neutrophils, monocytes

Host defense against

Intracellular microbes

Helminthic parasites

Extracellular bacteria, fungi

Role in disease

Autoimmune and other chronic inflammatory diseases (such as IBD, psoriasis, granulomatous inflammation)

questions.text: The following image shows the superior view of the first cervical vertebra. The part of the bone marked as number 7 gives attachment to ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Atlas bone. The part marked as number 7 is the posterior arch, and its inferior border gives attachment to ligamentum flavum.

 

Atlas (C1): Bony features include no body and spinous processes. It has 2 lateral masses - with upper and lower articular facets, anterior and posterior arches, and 2 transverse processes with lateral transverse foramen through which the vertebral vessels pass.

The anterior arch provides attachment to the anterior longitudinal ligament anteriorly and articulates with the facet of dens posteriorly.

The superior border of the posterior arch is attached to the atlantooccipital membrane and its inferior border is attached to the ligamentum flavum.

Articulation of the atlas:

  • The atlantooccipital joint allows the head to nod up and down (like showing yes).
  • The atlantoaxial joint allows the head to turn side to side (like showing no).

Axis (C2): Bony features include a cylindrical body, transverse process with transverse foramen, and a bifid spine. The dens (odontoid process) projects up to the space left due to the missing body of C1.

The given image shows the articulation of the atlas and the axis:

 

The stability of the vertebral column is maintained mainly by 4 ligaments - the anterior longitudinal, posterior longitudinal, ligamentum flavum, and the interspinous ligament.

C1 compression fracture at multiple sites is called Jefferson fracture. C2 hyperextension fracture is also called hangman fracture.

questions.text: A technetium-99 m scan of a 3-year-old boy with Meckel's diverticulum is given below. Identify the false statement regarding this imaging modality in the given condition.

choices.text: Detects the presence of ectopic gastric tissue
Less sensitive for diagnosis in adults
CT is the most accurate investigation for diagnosis

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding imaging modalities in Merkel's diverticulum is- CT is the most accurate for diagnosis in Meckel's diverticulum. Sodium 99mTc-pertechnetate scintigraphy is the most accurate diagnostic test for Meckel's diverticula in children.

Meckel's diverticulum results from the failure of the yolk sac to close during fetal life. It is located on the anti-mesenteric border of the ileum. It is usually detected incidentally but may present with gastrointestinal bleeding. The bleeding is usually from a chronic acid-induced ulcer adjacent to a Meckel diverticulum that contains ectopic gastric mucosa.

Diagnosis of Meckel’s diverticulum:

In the absence of bleeding, Meckel’s diverticula are rarely diagnosed prior to the time of surgical intervention. Plain abdominal X-ray, CT, and ultrasonography are rarely helpful in the diagnosis. 

Radionuclide scans like the 99mTc-pertechnetate accurately detect the presence of ectopic gastric mucosa. In children who present with bleeding, ectopic gastric mucosa is found in the majority of the cases. Hence, the most accurate diagnostic test in children. It is less accurate in adults. 

The sensitivity of the scan can be improved by H2-receptor antagonists like cimetidine. It leads to a higher concentration of radionucleotide in the wall of the diverticulum.

Angiography may be used to locate the site of bleeding in acute hemorrhage. The presence of a persistent vitelline artery is diagnostic.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy is brought to the department of paediatrics with complaints of sudden jerks in the morning causing him to drop objects. An EEG revealed a generalized 4-5 Hz polyspike and slow-wave discharges. Identify the correct statements regarding this condition.

1. It is the most common generalized epilepsy in young adults
2. CACNB4, CLNC2 and EJM2 genes are mutated
3. Onset is classically during early infancy
4. KCNQ2 and SLC2A1 genes are mutated
5. Precipitated by sleep deprivation
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy or Janz syndrome, and options 1, 2, and 5 are correct.

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is the most common generalized epilepsy in young adults. It has been linked to mutations in the genes:

  • CACNB4
  • CLNC2
  • EJM2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9
  • GABRA1
  • GABRD
  • Myoclonin1/ EFHC1

It typically starts in early adolescence with myoclonic jerks in the morning causing the patient to drop things, generalized tonic-clonic seizures while sleeping, or on waking up, and juvenile absence seizures. Precipitating factors include sleep deprivation, photic stimulation, alcohol (in older patients), and certain cognitive activities.

The EEG in shows generalized 4-5 Hz polyspike–and–slow-wave discharges in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

Disease Typical EEG feature
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep
Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-5 Hz spike
West syndrome  Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)

Treatment of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy: The FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy are lamotrigine, levetiracetam, and topiramate, while NICE guidelines recommend valproate in addition to these. 

Other options:

Option 4: Mutations in KCNQ2 are associated with benign familial neonatal seizures while mutations in SLC2A1 are linked with epileptic encephalopathies and early-onset absence seizures.

Related Pearl: First-line Agents in Different Types of Seizures

questions.text:
An 8-year-old girl presents with frequent episodes of staring spells in school. She is diagnosed with absence seizures. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the drug of choice used for this condition?

GABA: gamma-aminobutyric acid

choices.text: Inhibition of the T-type calcium channels

questions.solution:
Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for use in children suffering from absence seizures. Its mechanism of action is the inhibition of T-type calcium channels.

Absence seizures originate in the thalamus and produce the pathognomonic 3 Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG. This pattern is produced due to the intrinsic properties of the low threshold T-type calcium channels of the thalamus. These channels are activated at a much lower threshold and produce larger currents as compared to most other calcium channels in the brain. Hence, inhibition of these T-type calcium currents in the neurons of the thalamus by ethosuximide is effective for the management of absence seizures.

Absence seizures are mostly seen in young school-going children. They present with briefly altered consciousness with staring spells often confused with daydreaming and declining performance in school by their parents and teachers. These can be accompanied by rapid blinking or chewing motions. The episodes typically last for only 1-2 seconds, and the child regains consciousness immediately without any postictal confusion. Such episodes can occur up to 100 times per day. 

Other options:

Option A: Valproate acts by blocking both calcium and sodium channels. It can be used in absence seizures, but it is preferred when the child also suffers from generalized tonic clinic seizures. It is the drug of choice for juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

Option B: Vigabatrin acts as a GABA uptake inhibitor. It is the drug of choice for infantile spasms (West syndrome) seen in tuberous sclerosis.

Option C: Benzodiazepines act by promoting GABA inhibition by binding to the GABA receptor itself and inhibiting nerve transmission. Diazepam is used to prevent febrile seizures from recurring in children.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man comes to the psychiatric outpatient department after a nervous breakdown. He says that he got divorced about a week ago, and has been feeling depressed since then. He has also started hearing voices for the past few days, saying he is useless and telling him to kill himself. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A brief psychotic disorder is the best answer in this scenario, as the symptoms are present for less than 30 days.

The diagnosis of brief psychotic disorder in DSM-5 is based on the presence of one or more of the following psychotic symptoms for a period of at least 1 day but less than 1 month:

  • Delusions
  • Hallucinations
  • Thought disorder as evidenced by disorganized speech
  • Disorganized or catatonic behavior.

DSM-5 specifies that one of the first three symptoms must be present for the diagnosis to be made.

Other options: 

Option D: Major Depressive Disorder is diagnosed by the presence of depressive symptoms for at least two weeks, including persistent feelings of sadness, anhedonia, changes in appetite or weight, sleep disturbances, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness or guilt, difficulty concentrating, and thoughts of death or suicide. Patients experiencing a major depressive episode may exhibit delusions and hallucinations, which is known as psychotic depression. These delusions and hallucinations are usually mood-congruent and often revolve around themes of guilt and self-deprecation. 

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

Differential diagnosis of DSM-5 psychotic disorders

Psychotic disorder

 Criteria for diagnosis
Brief psychotic disorder

Sudden onset and a full return to function

Duration: > 1 day and < 1 month
Schizophreniform disorder

Same symptoms as schizophrenia and functional decline not required

Duration: > 1 month & < 6 months
Schizophrenia

Requires functional decline

At least 6 months (includes at least 1 month of active symptoms, can include prodromal and residual periods)
Schizoaffective disorder

With concurrent mood episode. Active-phase symptoms of schizophrenia with at least a 2 weeks of lifetime history of delusions or hallucinations in absence of prominent mood symptoms
Delusional disorder

One or more delusions for > 1 month

No other psychotic symptoms and normal functioning apart from the direct impact of delusions
Shared psychotic disorder (folie a deux)

Development of delusions in a person who is in a close relationship (ex: spouse, child) with someone who has a delusional disorder (the inducer)

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman who was operated for a femur fracture complains of shortness of breath on the fourth postoperative day. She has chest pain and tachycardia as well. Her chest X-ray is shown below. This finding is most probably suggestive of ________.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the X-ray showing Hampton's hump is suggestive of pulmonary embolism.

Pulmonary embolism:

Pulmonary embolism refers to embolic occlusion of the pulmonary arterial system.

Most patients present with pleuritic chest pain, dyspnoea, and tachypnoea. The classical clinical triad of sudden onset of chest pain, dyspnoea, and hemoptysis is present in only a few cases.

Chest x-ray signs related to pulmonary embolism include:

  • Hampton's hump is a pleural-based, wedge-shaped opacity with the apex of the triangle pointed towards the occluding vessel or hilum and implies lung infarction. 
  • Westermark sign is a chest X-ray finding in pulmonary embolism. It is defined by a hyperlucent area with decreased vascularity due to oligemia of the involved part of the lung.
  • Chest x-ray: A large part of the right hemithorax is hypodense due to oligaemia, secondary to vasoconstriction distal to an embolus.
  • Fleishner sign: Enlarged pulmonary artery.
  • Knuckle or sausage sign, describing a dilatation of a central pulmonary artery due to occlusion by the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.
  • Palla’s sign: Dilated right descending pulmonary artery (Image below):
  • Melting sign: infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.
  • Elevated hemidiaphragm.
  • The best known indirect sign of PE on transthoracic echo is McConnell's sign. That is hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with the normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs act by inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis?
questions.solution:
Delamanid acts by inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis.

Pretomanid and delamanid are bicyclic nitroimidazoles that act by inhibiting mycolic acid (a component of the mycobacterial cell wall) and protein synthesis in the mycobacteria.

Pretomanid in combination with bedaquiline and linezolid was approved by FDA in 2019 for the treatment of adult patients with extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB and for patients who are treatment-intolerant or nonresponsive to multidrug-resistant pulmonary (MDR) TB treatment.

In India, delamanid is only approved for the management of MDR-TB.

Other options:

Option A: Bedaquiline acts by inhibition of ATP synthase. It is a diarylquinoline that targets the subunit c of the ATP synthase of M. tuberculosis. This leads to inhibition of the proton pump activity of the ATP synthase and causes a failure in the bacillary energy metabolism.

Option C: Cycloserine is a D-alanine analog used as a second-line drug for MDR-TB that acts by inhibiting alanine racemase. Alanine racemase converts L-alanine to D-alanine which is needed for the mycobacterial cell wall. 

Option D: Terizidone (a derivative of cycloserine) contains two molecules of cycloserine and has a similar mechanism of action but is believed to be less neurotoxic. It is used in genitourinary TB because it attains higher and longer-lasting concentrations in urine.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments

  3. Patients >14 years of age.
