questions.text:
Which of the following coagulation factors decrease in pregnancy?

1. Factor XI
2. Factor II
3. Factor VII
4. Factor VIII
5. Factor V
questions.solution:
Factors XI is decreased during pregnancy.

All the other coagulation factors mentioned above, i.e., factors ll, V, Vll, Vlll are increased in pregnancy.

Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state. This is in order to control bleeding and help in hemostasis after placental separation. Hematological changes in pregnancy include:

  • Most clotting factors are increased, while factors XI and XIII are decreased.
  • Anticoagulants protein C, protein S, and antithrombin decrease during pregnancy
  • Fibrinogen levels are also increased by 50%
  • Clotting time and bleeding time are unaffected
  • The viscosity of blood decreases due to relative hemodilution (a relatively higher increase in plasma volume as compared to the increase in RBC mass)
  • ESR is raised due to an increase in fibrinogen and globulin levels
  • Because of a marked fall in albumin level and only a slight rise of globulin, the normal albumin: globulin ratio of 1.7:1 is diminished to 1:1
  • Platelet counts remain the same or fall by a small amount (15%)

The most common cause of decreased platelet count in pregnancy is benign gestational thrombocytopenia. This is due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption. The women are generally asymptomatic.

questions.text:
A patient who sustained a tibial fracture was managed conservatively with a plaster cast. A few days later, he presents with complaints of pain and paresthesia in the affected limb. On examination, severe pain was elicited on passive stretching. Which of the following statements is/are true regarding this condition?
  1. Fasciotomy is done if the differential pressure is less than 30 mmHg
  2. The earliest symptom to develop is paresthesia
  3. The fractures of the elbow and forearm are at high risk
  4. Paralysis of the muscle group is a late sign
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation is suggestive of acute compartment syndrome and the true statements regarding this condition are 1, 3, and 4. Statement 2 is false because the earliest symptom to develop is pain and not paresthesia. 

Acute compartment syndrome can be defined as the elevation of intra-compartmental pressure that will cause tissue ischemia and necrosis without decompression. This occurs because increased pressure within a closed space in the body leads to a critical reduction of blood flow to the tissues.

The classic features of acute compartment syndrome include the 5 P's:

  • Pain is the first symptom of acute compartment syndrome. It can be elicited on passive stretching of the muscles.
  • Paresthesia occurs due to the compression of nerves in the compartment and indicates nerve ischemia.
  • Pallor occurs due to ischemia.
  • Paralysis of muscle groups in the compartment is a late sign.
  • Pulselessness is usually not seen in the early stages unless there is a major arterial injury. If pulses are absent, arteriography is indicated. 

The injuries that are at high risk of developing acute compartment syndrome are the fractures of the elbow, forearm, proximal third of the tibia, and multiple fractures of the hand and foot. Other high-risk injuries are crush injuries and circumferential burns.

The intra-compartmental pressure (ICP) is measured using a split catheter introduced into the compartment. Earlier, the ICP values alone were used to determine the critical threshold for compartment syndrome. However, it was noted that different individuals had different levels of tolerance for raised ICP. Therefore, differential pressure is used now to determine the need for decompression.

Differential pressure (ΔP) is the difference between diastolic pressure and compartment pressure. When the ΔP is less than 30 mm Hg, the perfusion from blood vessels to the tissues is impaired. Hence, immediate compartment decompression/ fasciotomy is indicated.

All the dressings, bandages, and cast on the affected limb are removed and the limb is nursed flat. 

Fasciotomy wounds are left open. After 2 days, if there is necrosis, debridement is done. If the wounds are healthy, they can be sutured without tension. Alternatively, skin grafting can be done.

Related Pearl: Acute Compartment and Crush Syndromes

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes less than or equal to 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush Syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man was brought to the emergency with complaints of palpitations. On examination, he was tachycardic with an irregularly irregular rhythm. He is a known case of long-standing emphysema. His ECG is given below. Which of the following modalities is ineffective in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ECG showing different p-wave morphologies and the irregular interval between p-waves are suggestive of multifocal atrial tachycardia. Electric cardioversion is an ineffective treatment modality.

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is a supraventricular arrhythmia characterised by:

  • Heart rate >100-150bpm
  • At least 3 different non-sinus p-wave morphology
  • Clear but irregular isoelectric intervals between p waves

The most common etiology is any underlying pulmonary disease - COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease). Other causes include hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia, the postoperative period after major surgery, drugs like aminophylline and theophylline and pulmonary artery hypertension.

MAT is typically seen in elderly patients. Most patients are hemodynamically stable and generally present with tachycardia and irregularly irregular rhythm. Diagnosis is done based on the electrocardiogram features mentioned above.

MAT is characterised by at least 3 distinct P-wave morphologies as shown by arrows in the image below.

Treatment of underlying disease is the mainstay of the management of MAT. If patients are symptomatic treatment should begin with the correction of hypokalemia to maintain >4 mEq/L and hypomagnesemia to maintain >2 mEq/L. 

In the absence of pulmonary disease, beta-blockers are the first-line treatment. In the presence of pulmonary disease, a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker such as verapamil or diltiazem is the first line. Ablation of the AV node is usually done when patients do not respond to or cannot tolerate pharmacologic therapy. Electric cardioversion is ineffective.

Differential diagnoses of MAT include:

Sinus tachycardia with frequent premature atrial contractions - this would have regular PP intervals.

Atrial flutter shows flutter waves as given in the below ECG.

Atrial fibrillation would not have discrete P-wave morphologies.

Related Pearl: Supraventricular tachycardias

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with narrow QRS complex:

  • Narrow QRS with regular RR interval
   Tachycardia                ECG features
Sinus tachycardia Normal P wave, normal ECG features except for the rate
Focal atrial tachycardia A single type of abnormal p wave morphology is seen
Junctional tachycardia No p waves. Heart rate is 100- 200/ min
AV nodal reentry tachycardia No p waves. Pseudo R' waves may be seen. Heart rate is 150-250/ min
Atrioventricular reentry tachycardia P wave always follows QRS. RP interval< PR interval
Atrial flutter Sawtooth shaped flutter waves are seen

 

  • Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval
     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

 

Supraventricular tachycardias with wide QRS complex:

  • Antidromic AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia)
  • Supraventricular tachycardias with bundle branch block

questions.text:
A 38-year-old post-cholecystectomy patient presents with pain in the right upper quadrant on the third postoperative day. Evaluation reveals a collection in Morrison's pouch. A bile leak was suspected. Which of the following investigations will be most helpful in this case?

ERCP - Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

MRCP - Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography

HIDA - Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid 

CT - Computed tomography
questions.solution:
ERCP is the most useful investigation in a patient suspected of post-cholecystectomy biliary leaks. It has the advantage of being diagnostic as well as therapeutic.

ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography) is useful post-cholecystectomy as there is a high likelihood of a retained stone and stone extraction and or temporary stenting may be required. 

ERCP allows the insertion of a stent in the bile duct to manage the biliary leak. 

The most common post-cholecystectomy biliary leak is from the cystic duct. This can be managed by placing a biliary endoprosthesis (stent) in the common bile duct across the origin.

Other options:

Option A- MRCP (magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography) can demonstrate fluid collection arising from the biliary leak but, it can not differentiate these from other fluid collections. 

Option C and Option D- Both HIDA (hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid) scintigraphy and CT can demonstrate biliary leaks. HIDA is more sensitive and CT provides more anatomical information.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause permanent impairment of fingerprint pattern?
questions.solution:
Among the given conditions, electrical injury is most likely to cause permanent impairment of fingerprint patterns.

Some changes in fingerprints include:

  • Moderate epidermal ridge atrophy and loss of pattern in celiac disease
  • Incomplete atrophy of the ridges in dermatitis
  • Ridge alteration occurs in eczema, acanthosis nigricans, scleroderma, and dry or atrophic skin
  • Permanent impairment of the fingerprint pattern occurs in leprosy, electric injury, and after exposure to radiation
  • Distance between the ridges is changed, but the pattern is not altered in infantile paralysis, rickets, and acromegaly

Other options:

First-degree burns (option A) cannot cause permanent damage to the fingerprints. Fingerprints are better protected than other parts of the body in case of burns as they are bent inwards against the palm of the hand.

In decomposed bodies (option C), the skin is found loose like a glove, which is removed, preserved in formalin, and used for impressions. Prints can be obtained from the dermis after the epidermis is lost.

If the fingers are mummified (option D), their outline can be made level by injecting liquid paraffin or formalin.

questions.text: A female patient with twin pregnancies underwent an abdominal ultrasound. It showed that the upper part of the body of one fetus was absent and the other fetus was normal. The echo of the normal fetus was suggestive of congestive cardiac failure. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis here is twin reversed arterial perfusion (TRAP).

TRAP is a complication seen in monochorionic multifetal gestation. It is caused by a large artery-to-artery or vein-to-vein placental shunt. Here, the recipient twin lacks a cardiac system, while the donor twin does the work of supplying blood for both twins. Blood from the donor twin reaches the iliac vessels of the recipient twin through the umbilical arteries. Therefore, in the recipient twin, only the lower body is developed, while the upper body is poorly developed. The donor twin may show signs of heart failure.

Developmental abnormality in the recipient twin:

  • No identifiable structures - Acardius amorphous
  • Failure of head growth - Acardius acephalus
  • Partially developed head with identifiable limbs - Acardius myelacephalus

Other options: 

Option A- Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) is a deep arteriovenous anastomotic complication seen in monochorionic twins. Deoxygenated blood from the donor enters through anastomosis into a shared cotyledon for oxygen exchange. After oxygenation, the blood is taken up by the recipient twin. The donor twin will have anemia and appears pale, while the recipient twin will have polycythemia and features of heart failure.

Option B- Twin anemia–polycythemia sequence (TAPS) is similar to TTTS, where the donor twin is pale and anemic, whereas the recipient twin is polycythemic. However, unlike the case with TTTS, the amniotic fluid volumes in TAPS are similar for both fetuses.

Option D- Twin oligohydramnios polyhydramnios syndrome (TOPS) is seen in TTTS. The donor fetus becomes oliguric due to hypovolemia, and the recipient fetus develops increased urine output due to hypervolemia. This results in oligohydramnios in the donor and hydramnios in the recipient fetus.

Related Pearl: Twinning

questions.text: The type of epithelium shown in the image is found in _____.
questions.solution:
The given image shows non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, which is found lining the esophagus. 

Other areas lined by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium include:

  • Buccal cavity (except gingivae, hard palate and filiform papillae on the anterior part of the dorsal surface of the tongue)
  • Oropharynx and laryngopharynx
  • Esophagus
  • Part of the anal canal
  • Vagina
  • Ectocervix
  • Distal urethra
  • Cornea
  • Inner surfaces of the eyelids
  • vestibule of the nasal cavities.

Other options: 

Option A: The trachea is lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium. 

Options B and D: Urinary bladder and renal pelvis are lined by transitional epithelium. 

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the characteristics of elimination plotted in orange?

choices.text: Fixed amount of drug is cleared per unit time
Exhibited by drugs such as phenytoin

questions.solution:
In the given image, the orange line depicts zero-order elimination. The incorrect statement about this type of elimination is that t½ remains constant. In zero-order elimination, the t½ is not constant and is less at low concentration and more at high concentration.

Zero-order kinetics denotes that the rate of elimination is constant regardless of the concentration of the drug. Here a fixed amount of drug is cleared per unit time. This is usually seen when the drugs saturate their elimination mechanisms. Therefore, as the concentration of the drug increases beyond metabolic saturation, clearance of the drug decreases as depicted by the orange line. Drugs such as phenytoin, and aspirin follow this type of elimination at higher concentrations. 

First-order kinetics denotes that the rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration of the drug. Here a constant fraction of the drug is eliminated. The drugs following this elimination have a constant  t½. As the dosage of the drug increases, the clearance remains constant as the fraction of drug eliminated is constant as depicted by the black line. Most drugs follow this type of elimination. 

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: Which of the following structures do not pass through the foramen marked in the image given below?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl was brought to the hospital after a history of sexual abuse. Prior to the examination, stained portions of the girl's clothing were taken for analysis. The stain was extracted using 10% hydrochloric acid, following which a reagent containing potassium iodide, iodine, and water was added to it. Identify the correct statement about the test performed.

choices.text: Dark brown crystals indicate the presence of semen
The reaction is based on presence of prostatic secretions
It is a confirmatory test for the presence of semen
It detects the presence of acid phosphatase

questions.solution:
The correct statement here is that dark brown crystals indicate the presence of semen. The test described here is the Florence test. It is used to detect seminal fluid.

The suspected seminal stain is extracted with 10% hydrochloric acid and a drop of it is placed over a slide. A coverslip is placed over it and a drop of Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water) is made to run under the coverslip. If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately. Choline originates from the seminal vesicles. 

The test is not confirmatory for the presence of semen, however, a negative reaction rules out the presence of semen. Confirmation of the presence of semen can be done only if there is presence of at least one unbroken spermatozoon, or detection of  sperms by electrophoretic LDH isoenzyme.

Other tests for Semen detection include:

  • Barberio's Test: Yellow needle-shaped crystals on addition of picric acid. Reaction is based on prostatic secretions.
  • Acid Phosphatase Test: Detects presence of acid phosphatase (from prostatic secretions) in the seminal fluid.
  • Creatine Phosphokinase: Spermatozoa contain a high level of creatinine phosphokinase, which can be detected.
  • Immunological detection of P30, MHS 5 or MAB E6

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: Where does trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole act respectively in the given diagram?
questions.solution:
Trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole act at sites 2 and 1 respectively in the given image.

Sulfamethoxazole inhibits dihydropteroate synthase (1) that converts para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) to dihydrofolate. Trimethoprim is a selective inhibitor of microbial dihydrofolate reductase (2). Dihydrofolate reductase is involved in the reduction of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate. Both these enzymes are essential for the synthesis of folic acid in a bacterial cell. Inhibition of folic acid synthesis will cause disruption of basic metabolic functions in the microbe leading to its death.

Co-trimoxazole is a combination of trimethoprim with sulfamethoxazole in the ratio of 1:5. Sulfamethoxazole is an intermediate-acting sulfonamide with a plasma half-life of around 10 hours. Trimethoprim also has a similar plasma half-life and therefore combined with sulfamethoxazole. 

Co-trimoxazole is used to treat urinary tract infections, and respiratory tract infections against organisms like gram-positive cocci, Hemophilus influenza, and Moraxella catarrhalis. It is also used against severe infections of E. coli, Shigella, non-typhoid Salmonella, and Yersinia enterocolitica. High doses of Co-trimoxazole are used in neutropenic and AIDS patients against Pneumocystis jirovecii.

Adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, stomatitis, and megaloblastic anemia due to folate deficiency. Trimethoprim is teratogenic as it inhibits folate synthesis. It should be used with caution in renal failure patients.

Other options:
Option C: 3 indicates cell wall inhibitors that include drugs like Vancomycin, Bacitracin, Penicillins, Cephalosporins, Carbapenems, and Monobactams. 6 represents fluoroquinolones which inhibit DNA gyrase.
 
Option D: 4 and 5 are protein synthesis inhibitors specifically inhibiting 30s and 50s subunits of the ribosomes. 30s inhibitors (4) include Aminoglycosides and Tetracyclines. 50s inhibitors (5) include Macrolides, Linezolid, Clindamycin, and Chloramphenicol.

Related Pearl: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

Mnemonic: 50 CELLS arranged into 30 TEAM

50s subunit binding:

  • C: Chloramphenicol, Clindamycin
  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

30s subunit binding

  • Te: Tetracyclines
  • Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text:
A man was brought unconscious to the casualty ward following a head injury. His GCS was 5 but his CT was normal. MRI showed multiple small hemorrhages in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain with no midline shift. The patient died after 48 hours and his body was sent for post-mortem. Which of the following statements regarding the patient's disease condition is true?
  1. The patient had diffuse axonal injury.
  2. It is caused due to stretching of axons due to sudden deceleration injuries.
  3. Several focal subcortical grey matter lesions of 1-15 mm can be seen.
  4. Histopathology sections will reveal retraction balls on congo red staining.
  5. Immunohistochemistry will be positive for beta-amyloid precursor protein.
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, 4, and 5 are true. 

A patient with a head injury having a poor Glasgow Coma Score (GCS), normal findings on CT scan, and evidence of hemorrhages on MRI is likely to have diffuse axonal injury. 

Diffuse axonal injury is a form of primary brain injury seen in high-energy accidents. It is caused by damage to axons throughout the brain due to rotational acceleration followed by deceleration. There is disruption and shearing of axons leading to microhemorrhages.

Diffuse axonal injury typically consists of several focal white-matter lesions measuring 1-15 mm in a characteristic distribution. CT may be normal. Small hemorrhages can be seen in more severe cases, especially on MRI (investigation of choice). Hemorrhages are classically seen in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain.

The earliest microscopic evidence for diffuse axonal injury is 'retraction balls/globes' which appear 12-18 hours after injury. This can be appreciated using the congo red stain.

Immunohistochemistry marker with beta-amyloid precursor protein is considered to be the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours.  

The prognosis is very poor. It results in a persistent vegetative state after severe head trauma.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Axonal Injury

The mechanism of diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is primarily a non-impact rotational acceleration-deceleration injury. This leads to the deformation of the axons by stretching them.

Pathology of DAI:

  • Changes in permeability of the axolemma
  • Axonal swelling
  • Intracellular calcium accumulation
  • Proteolysis
  • The collapse of the cytoskeleton
  • 'Retraction balls or globes' - bulbous and clubbed axons. Seen earliest at 12-18 hours. The number of retraction balls begins to decrease after 2-3 weeks after injury and a cluster of microglial cells appears followed by astrocytosis and demyelination.
  • Immuno-histochemistry shows beta-amyloid precursor protein - the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours. 

Image shows scattered axonal retraction balls stained with Congo Red:

questions.text: The device shown in the image cannot be used for _____.

choices.text: A patient with cellulitis of the same limb compartment

questions.solution:
Ilizarov fixator cannot be used for a patient with cellulitis of the same limb compartment as it would cause direct seeding of tissue.

Uses:

  • Limb lengthening
  • Nonunion
  • Deformity correction
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Arthrodesis by crushing the articular surfaces against each other

It can also be used for preventing the progression of fat embolism syndrome as external fixation is one of the modalities used as a part of damage control surgery.

questions.text: A young man suffered a trauma to his right hand while playing basketball. 3 weeks later, he reports to the orthopedician because of pain and stiffness over the right wrist. On examination, wrist movements are limited and painful. He is diagnosed with Kienböck's disease. This condition involves avascular necrosis of:
questions.solution:
Kienböck's disease involves avascular necrosis of the lunate.

This condition is usually seen in young adults, who present with pain and stiffness in the wrist. A history of trauma may be present. On examination, localized tenderness can be appreciated over the lunate, and a reduction in grip strength can be noted. Limited and painful wrist movements are noted in the later stages of the disease.

It involves four stages: 

  • Stage 1 involves ischemia of the bone, without any clinical or radiographic abnormality 
  • Stage 2 shows trabecular necrosis with reactive new bone formation. There is increased radiographic density, but little/no distortion of the shape
  • Stage 3 involves the collapse of the bone
  • Stage 4 is characterized by disruption of radiocarpal congruence and secondary osteoarthritis

In the initial stages, an X-ray might be normal, therefore an MRI with gadolinium enhancement is the investigation of choice. 

Management includes the use of splints and vascularized bone grafts for the early stages of the disease and total wrist fusion/replacement for advanced disease.

Note: Avascular necrosis of the scaphoid occurs due to a fracture of the waist of the scaphoid bone.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about the levator ani?

1) It arises from the condensation of the obturator fascia
2) It consists of 2 muscle components
3) Puborectalis and pubococcygeus create the anorectal angle
4) Its contraction leads to defecation and urination
5) It is innervated by S3 and S4 sacral segments
questions.solution:
The true statements about levator ani are options 1, 3 and 5. 

The levator ani muscle is a complex unit, which consists of 3 muscle components namely:

  • Pubococcygeus - the fibres of this muscle is further divided into - 
    • Pubovaginalis - elevates the urethra and hence contributes to urinary continence
    • Puboperinealis - draws the perineal body towards the pubic symphysis
    • Puboanalis - elevates the anus and keeps the urogenital hiatus narrowed
  • Puborectalis
  • Iliococcygeus

Levator ani arises from condensations of the obturator fascia. It is inserted into the coccyx and the anococcygeal raphe or ligament. The branches of the anterior rami of sacral nerves S3 and S4 innervate this muscle. 

It is one of the most important muscles in the pelvic floor and maintains a constant state of contraction. They provide a stable floor and support the weight of the abdominopelvic contents against intra-abdominal forces. The vaginal, urethral and rectal lumen is obstructed by the contraction of the levator ani and relaxation of the muscle is needed for defecation and urination. Puborectalis and pubococcygeus, help maintain the rectal tone as well as create the anorectal angle.

questions.text:
A premature male infant was born at 26 weeks gestation with a birth weight of 1150 g. He was diagnosed with respiratory distress syndrome and received continuous positive airway pressure for 2 weeks. As per the RBSK guidelines for universal eye screening in newborns, when should the baby be screened for retinopathy of prematurity?

RBSK- Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram
questions.solution:
In the scenario above, the gestational age is 26 weeks and birth weight is <1200 g, therefore, the infant must be screened at 3 weeks postnatal age as per the guidelines for the screening of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP).

Screening:

  • The first ROP screening should be done at 4 weeks if gestational age is 28–34 weeks or birth weight is <2000 g.
  • The first ROP screening should be done at 2-3 weeks if gestational age is <28 weeks or birth weight is <1200 g.
  • Ideally, 2 examinations must be performed; however, 1 may suffice if it shows complete retinal vascularisation.

Retrolental fibroplasia is also known as retinopathy of prematurity.

  • Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), previously known as retrolental fibroplasia, is a disease of the eye that affects prematurely born babies.
  • ROP can be mild and may resolve spontaneously, but may lead to blindness in serious cases. As such, all premature babies are at risk for ROP, and very low birth weight is an additional risk factor.
  • Both oxygen toxicity and relative hypoxia can contribute to the development of ROP.
  • Location

Concentric zones centred on the optic disc are described.

  • Zone I is bounded by an imaginary circle, the radius of which is twice the distance from the disc to the centre of the macula.
  • Zone II extends concentrically from the edge of zone I; its radius extends from the centre of the disc to the nasal ora Serrata.
  • Zone III consists of a residual temporal crescent anterior to zone II.

Stages of ROP:

  • Stage 1: Demarcation line
  • Stage 2: Intraretinal ridge formation
  • Stage 3: Neovascularization
  • Stage 4: Subtotal retinal detachment
  • Stage 5: Total retinal detachment

"Plus" disease signifies a tendency to progression and is characterized by the dilatation and tortuosity of blood vessels involving at least two quadrants of the posterior fundus.

Aggressive posterior ("rush" disease, AP-ROP) is uncommon but if untreated usually progresses to stage 5, sometimes within a few days. It is characterized by its posterior location, prominence of plus disease, and ill-defined nature of retinopathy.

Treatment:

  • Type 1. Treatment is now recommended within 48 hours for type 1 disease. It is done by laser photocoagulation of peripheral avascular retina.
  • Type 2 disease requires observation for progression.
  • Intravitreal anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) agents, e.g., bevacizumab (only for AP-ROP)
  • Laser ablation of the avascular peripheral retina
  • Pars plana vitrectomy for tractional retinal detachment not involving the macula (stage 4A)

questions.text: A young woman presents with a history of easy fatiguability and appeared pale for the past few months. A peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic cells, serum iron was low. Which of the following findings would not be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Increased ferritin would not be found in this patient.

The given scenario of a young woman presenting to the clinic with a history of easy fatiguability, and a peripheral smear showing microcytic hypochromic anemia is suggestive of iron deficiency anemia. Low serum iron and serum ferritin, increased TIBC, decreased transferrin, and high Mentzer index would be seen in this condition.

Iron deficiency anemia is an example of microcytic hypochromic anemia. It occurs due to inadequate diet, impaired absorption, increased requirement, and increased blood loss.

Manifestations of iron deficiency anemia depend upon the underlying cause. In general, features such as koilonychia, alopecia, atrophic changes in the tongue, gastric mucosa, malabsorption, and pica (craving for eating non-food stuff) can be present.

Diagnosis is mainly by laboratory studies. The typical findings are low hemoglobin and low hematocrit. Serum iron and ferritin are low while the total iron binding capacity is increased. These changes lead to a decrease in transferrin saturation. Decreased stores of iron inhibit hepcidin synthesis and hence hepcidin is low.

A peripheral blood smear reveals small and pale red cells typically described as microcytic and hypochromic. An enlarged zone of central pallor may be seen in the red blood cells. Poikilocytosis can be seen in the form of elongated red cells, known as pencil cells. 

The image below shows a peripheral blood smear with microcytic hypochromic cells.

 

Bone marrow shows a mild to moderate raise in erythroid progenitors. The absence of iron stains in macrophages is a significant finding.

Red cell distribution width (RDW) is a quantitative measure of variation in cell size that is calculated from MCV (mean corpuscular volume). Normal RDW is 11-14%. A high RDW denotes anisocytosis, suggestive of iron deficiency.

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

Investigation Iron- Deficiency Anemia Alpha or beta thalassemia Anemia of Chronic Disease
Serum Iron <60 µg/dL Normal/Increased Decreased
Serum Ferritin <20 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased
Transferrin saturation <15% Normal Normal/Decreased
MCV Decreased  Decreased Normal/Decreased
RBC count Decreased Normal/Increased Normal/Increased

TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity

questions.text: During dissection, the professor points to a structure in the popliteal fossa marked with the red arrow shown in the image below. He further mentions that damage to this structure would cause a high-stepping gait and an inability to dorsiflex the ankle. The structure marked is ______.
questions.solution:
The damaged structure is most likely a common peroneal nerve. It is also called the common fibular nerve. It descends down obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa till the fibular head. It lies medial to the biceps femoris.

The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to the peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis which are the evertors of the foot and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between the great and second toes.

The common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the level of the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. The clinical features of common peroneal nerve injury include the following:

  • Foot drop (as shown in the image below)
  • Weakness or paralysis of ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and eversion
  • A diminished sensation on the dorsum of the foot including the first dorsal web space
  • Plantar flexion, inversion, and ankle reflex are preserved

 

 

Other options:

Option B: Sural nerve is a terminal branch of the tibial nerve and the common fibular nerve. Damage to this nerve results in a diminished sensation of the posterior and lateral aspects of the distal third in the leg. In the foot, there is diminished sensation over the lateral malleolus and the lateral side of the fifth toe.

Option C: Saphenous nerve is the longest and largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve. Damage to this nerve results in a diminished sensation in the skin over the patella, medial side of the leg, and medial side of the foot.

Option D: Tibial nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. It is derived from the anterior divisions of L4, L5, S1, S2, and S3. In the popliteal fossa, this nerve is overlapped by two heads of gastrocnemius. Damage to this nerve paralyzes gastrocnemius, plantaris, soleus, and popliteus muscles.

questions.text: You are a researcher studying the effects of acetylcholine on the heart and the muscarinic receptor M2 through which its actions are mediated. Which of the following change is mediated by muscarinic receptor subtype M2?
questions.solution:
The reduction of cAMP is mediated by the activation of the muscarinic receptor M2. 

Muscarinic receptors are G-protein coupled receptors and consist of five subtypes: M1, M2, M3, M4 and M5. 

M2 is a muscarinic cholinergic receptor that is located in the heart. When an agonist binds to the receptor, it opens K+ channels and causes inhibition of adenyl cyclase. This in turn inhibits the activation of cAMP. M4 subtype acts by the same mechanism but is located in the central nervous system. 

M1 is present in autonomic ganglia while glands and smooth muscles contain the M3 subtype. M5 is also located in the central nervous system. These subtypes act by increasing the inositol triphosphate (IP3) and Diacylglycerol (DAG)

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Mineralocorticoids
Androgens

Vitamins A

Somatostatin

Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: A pressure-volume diagram of the left ventricle is given below. Calculate the stroke volume considering the heart rate as 65 beats per minute.
questions.solution:
The stroke volume of this pressure-volume diagram is 70 mL.

The points in the graph indicate the following events of the cardiac cycle:

  • Point 1: Opening of the mitral valve. The corresponding reading on the graph denotes end-systolic volume (ESV).
  • Point 2: Closing of the mitral valve. The corresponding reading on the graph denotes end-diastolic volume (EDV).
  • Point 3: Opening of the aortic valve.
  • Point 4: Closing of the aortic valve.

Stroke volume is the amount of blood that the heart pumps out with each beat. It is about 70 mL from each ventricle in resting conditions.

In a pressure-volume diagram, stroke volume (SV) can be calculated using the values of ESV (50 mL) and EDV (120 mL):

Stroke volume = End diastolic volume – End systolic volume

Therefore, SV = 120 - 50 = 70 mL.

Cardiac output can be calculated from the given data using the formula:  Cardiac output = Stroke volume x heart rate

Therefore, in this case, cardiac output = 70 x 65 = 4550 mL.

questions.text: As a part of questioning a criminal, the police beat him on the soles of his feet using a rod. What is this form of torture known as?
questions.solution:
Falanga (also known as Falaka or Bastinado), is a method of torture that involves repeatedly striking the soles of the feet with an object such as a truncheon, iron rod, cable, bamboo cane, wooden pole, or rifle butt.

Other options:

Telefono: This form of torture involves repeated slapping of the sides of the head (over the ears). It may result in rupture of the tympanic membranes or damage to the inner ear.

Chepuwa: This form of torture involves tying the thighs and legs very tightly with bamboo sticks to induce severe pain.

Ghotna: This form of torture involves rolling a wooden log or an iron rod up and down the thigh while the log is being weighted by one or two individuals standing on it.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes and a BMI of 28 comes to you for advice on weight loss. He also reports fatigue, daytime somnolence, and poor performance at work. He has a family history of coronary artery disease. He has not achieved significant weight loss results, despite following a strict diet and exercise regimen for the past 6 months. Which of the following drugs is preferred for weight loss in him?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of obesity with obesity-related complications like hypoventilation syndrome, known diabetes, and cardiovascular risk. Liraglutide is a drug that can be given in such a setting.

Liraglutide is an injectable glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist, which can be also added with basal insulin. Liraglutide acts by:

  • Increasing glucose-mediated insulin release
  • Lowering the glucagon levels
  • Delaying gastric emptying
  • Decreasing feeding by stimulating GLP-1 receptors in the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus

It is found to decrease the risk of cardiovascular death, nonfatal myocardial infarction, and stroke in patients with type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Thus it has been approved for cardiovascu­lar risk reduction in type 2 diabetes patients at elevated cardiovascular risk.

Liraglutide is known to cause gastrointestinal side effects and is unsuitable for use in pregnancy. However, it can be prescribed in patients who require concomitant psychiatric medications.

Metformin, acarbose and empagliflozin are other antidiabetic drugs that can produce weight loss. However, studies have shown that the weight loss achieved with liraglutide is much more significant when compared to these other drugs.

Classification of weight status according to BMI is as follows:

Classification BMI
Healthy weight 18.5 - 24.9
Overweight 25.0 - 29.9
Class I obesity 30.0 - 34.9
Class II obesity 35.0 - 39.9
Class III obesity >= 40.0

Evaluation of obesity involves:

  • focused obesity-related history
  • physical examination
  • assessment of comorbid conditions
  • determination of fitness levels
  • assessment of patient readiness to adopt lifestyle changes

Evaluation of secondary causes of obesity like PCOD, hypothyroidism, Cushing's syndrome and drug-induced obesity should also be done. The recommendations for the management of obesity are as follows:

  • Diet, exercise, behavioral therapy - 
    • BMI - 25-29.9 with comorbidities
    • BMI ≥ 30
  • Adjunctive pharmacotherapy - 
    • BMI - 27-29.9 with comorbidities
    • BMI ≥ 30
  • Bariatric surgery - 
    • BMI - 35-39.9 with comorbidities
    • BMI ≥ 40

Bariatric surgery creates changes in anatomy and physiologic responses of hormones and metabolism. Bariatric surgery can produce an average of 30-35% weight loss that is maintained up to 5 years after the surgery. It is also successful in reducing comorbid conditions related to obesity like type 2 diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, and hypertension. 

Related Pearl: Anti-obesity drugs

Centrally acting anti-obesity drugs: The biologic effect of these agents on appetite regulation is produced by augmentation of the neurotransmission of three monoamines, norepinephrine, serotonin (5-HT) and dopamine.

  • Phentermine – Sympathomimetic (Phentermine is usually used in combination with topiramate)
  • Lorcaserin – Selective 5-HT2C receptor agonist

Peripherally acting medications:

  • Orlistat is a synthetic hydrogenated derivative of a naturally occurring lipase inhibitor, lipostatin, that is produced by the mold Streptomyces toxytricini.

Anti-obesity drugs in development:

  • Bupropion: Dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor
  • Naltrexone: Opioid receptor antagonist

Liraglutide: Glucagon-like peptide 1 receptor agonist

Note: Tirzepatide is a GIP and GLP-1 agonist recently approved for weight loss treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to clean a blood spill in the emergency room?
questions.solution:
Sodium hypochlorite, a compound of chlorine, is the best disinfectant for surface blood spills. It is used with a concentration of 0.5-5%.

If the spill contains large amounts of blood or body fluids, clean the visible matter with disposable absorbent material and discard the contaminated materials in appropriate, labeled containment. 

A 1:10–1:100 dilution of 5.25%–6.15% sodium hypochlorite (i.e., household bleach) or an EPA-registered tuberculocidal disinfectant has been recommended for decontaminating blood spills. 

Phenolic compounds (option B), Quaternary ammonium compounds (option C) and Alcoholic compounds (option D) are not effective in blood spills.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits the infertility clinic. She gives a history of 3 spontaneous first-trimester abortions. Routine investigations were done along with hysterosalpingography and MR imaging of the uterus which revealed the following images. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing recurrent first-trimester pregnancy losses and hysterosalpingography and MRI images are suggestive of a septate uterus.

A septate uterus is one where the uterus has a normal outline with the presence of an internal indentation at the fundal midline exceeding 50% of the uterine wall thickness. 

Obstetric outcomes in Septate uterus:

  • Spontaneous abortion
  • Preterm delivery
  • Repeated pregnancy loss
  • Intrauterine growth restriction
  • Abnormal presentations

Imaging modalities used for diagnosis:

Combined hysteroscopy and laparoscopy help to differentiate between a bicornuate uterus and a septate uterus. A septate uterus can be identified with the presence of a uterine fundus.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) cannot reliably differentiate between a septate and a bicornuate/arcuate uterus. If the angle of divergence between the two uterine cavities is <75°, the defect will most likely be a septate uterus. If the divergence angle is >75° but <105° a diagnosis cannot be made.

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is an accurate and noninvasive investigation to make a diagnosis of a septate uterus. If the septum extends to >30% of the septal cavity, surgical resection is indicated.

Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum has the best obstetric outcome. The procedure involves the resection of the septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of cesarean sections for future pregnancies.

Other options: 

Option A: Bicorporeal uterus is a uterus where the outline of the fundus is abnormal. An indentation that exceeds 50% of the wall thickness of the uterus at the fundal midline is indicative of a bicorporeal uterus.

Option B: Dysmorphic uterus is one where the fundal outline of the uterus is preserved but the presence of an abnormal uterine cavity excluding a septum.

Option C: A Hemi-uterus is one that is unilaterally formed due to development on only one side. The other side of the uterus is either incomplete or absent. The uterus that is present is fully functional. 

The following image shows the anomalies mentioned with a diagrammatic representation:

  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old G3P2L1 presents in labor at 30 weeks of gestation. She has a history of prior preterm labor. Which of the following are predictors for this condition?
  1. Cervical length on transvaginal ultrasound is 3.5 cm
  2. Bishop's score of 5
  3. Absence of fetal fibronectin
  4. Uterine contractions 3/hour 
  5. Presence of genital tract infection
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests that the lady has gone into preterm labor. The predictors of this condition are 2 and 5 only. 

Preterm labor is defined as one where the labor starts before the 37th completed week (<259 days), counting from the first day of the last menstrual period.

Predictors of preterm labor:

  • Clinical predictors - 
    • History of prior preterm birth
    • Multiple pregnancies
    • Presence of genital tract infection
    • Symptoms of preterm labor
  • Biophysical predictors - 
    • Uterine contractions ≥4/hour
    • Bishop score ≥4
    • Cervical length on transvaginal ultrasound ≤2.5 cm
  • Biochemical predictors - 
    • Fetal fibronectin (fFN) in cervical/vaginal discharge >50 ng/mL
    • Increased levels of IL-6, IL-8, TNF-alpha

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text:
Which of the following is a true statement about obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD)?

1. The mean age of onset is 20 years
2. Social phobia is a known comorbidity
3. Insight is impaired in most patients
4. Pathological doubt is the most common obsession
questions.solution:
Statements 1,2, i.e. the mean age of onset is 20 years and social phobia is a known comorbidity, are true about obsessive-compulsive disorder.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a disorder characterised by intrusive thoughts, preoccupations, and compulsions. The mean age of onset is 20 years. Men and women are equally affected.

An obsession is a thought, feeling, or sensation that is repetitive and intrusive. A compulsion is a conscious, recurrent behaviour, e.g., counting or checking, and is done to reduce the anxiety associated with the obsession. The patient might have an obsession, a compulsion, or both. These symptoms cause severe distress to the patient.

Symptom patterns include:

  • Contamination - this is the most common obsession. The patient feels that the objects are contaminated. They repeatedly wash their hands or avoid touching objects which are thought to be contaminated. In extreme cases, patients may rub the skin off their hands due to excessive hand washing or may refuse to leave the house for fear of germs.
  • Pathological doubt - this is the second most common symptom pattern. The patient presents with an obsession with doubt and a compulsion to check. This obsession arises due to possible danger or violence (e.g., forgetting to turn off the stove or not locking a door), which is followed by multiple trips to check, for example, if the stove is turned off if the door is locked, etc.
  • Intrusive thoughts - this is the third most common symptom pattern. These patients have intrusive obsessional thoughts without compulsion. These thoughts could be sexual or an aggressive act that the patient doesn't agree with. The patients might report themselves to the police or confess to a spiritual leader.
  • Symmetry - this is the fourth most common pattern, which can lead to a compulsion of slowness. Patients can take hours to eat a meal or shave their faces.

Most patients are aware of their condition and have preserved insight, while a few patients may have absent insight. The common psychiatric comorbidities in patients with OCD are depression, social phobia, alcohol use disorders, panic, and personality disorders.

Diagnosis of OCD is established when:

  1. There is the presence of obsessions, compulsions or both
  2. Symptoms are time-consuming
  3. Symptoms not related to substance abuse
  4. Symptoms are not better explained by other mental disorders

Management of OCD includes a combination of behavioural therapy and pharmacotherapy:

  • Pharmacotherapy - selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) or clomipramine
  • Behavioral therapy - approaches include:
    • Exposure and response prevention
    • Desensitization
    • Thought stopping
    • Flooding
    • Implosion therapy
    • Aversive conditioning

Related Pearl: Obsessive-compulsive disorder

Key points:

  • Most common:
    • Obsession: Contamination
    • Compulsion: Checking, cleaning
  • Treatment: Exposure and Response prevention - 1st line, Cognitive Behavioural Therapy(CBT), CBT with ERP, Pharmacotherapy.
  • Drug of choice: High dose SSRI
  • Treatment in nonresponsive patients: Clomipramine or antipsychotic augmentation
  • Treatment of severe or refractory cases: Deep brain stimulation

questions.text: Which of the following is not true with respect to Onchocerca volvulus life cycle?

choices.text: Female black flies are the intermediate host
L3 larva is the infective form
Lifespan of microfilaria in humans is 30 - 45 days

questions.solution:
The adult worm of Onchocerca volvulus can live in the human host for about 15 years while the microfilariae for about a year.

The life cycle is completed partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in a female black fly, the intermediate host (not male).

During a blood meal, the female black fly ingests the microfilariae from the skin and lymphatics of an infected person. It is within the vector that the microfilariae develop into first-stage larvae and subsequently into third-stage infective larvae (L3).

When the infected black fly bites another person, it introduces third-stage filarial larvae into the skin of the human host.

They penetrate into the bite wound and develop into adult worms in the subcutaneous tissues within subcutaneous nodules called onchocercomas or live freely in the tissues.

questions.text: A physician is studying parameter x. She checks the parameter x of all patients using an automated apparatus and compares them to manual checking (considered by her as the gold standard). For patient A, she finds that the automated apparatus and manual checking give very different values. However, on checking 5 times with the automated apparatus, all 5 values obtained are similar to each other. What can be concluded about the automated apparatus?
questions.solution:
The automated apparatus has low validity (accuracy) but high precision.

Validity (accuracy) refers to what extent the test accurately measures which it sets out to measure. It refers to the closeness with which measured values agree with "true" values. The values obtained by the automated apparatus are very different from the true values, reducing the validity of the automated apparatus readings.

Precision (reliability or reproducibility) is a measure of repeatability of a test. That is, the test must give consistent results when repeated more than once on the same individual or material, under the same conditions. The 5 values obtained by the automated apparatus are close to each other, making it precise.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

Related Pearl: Repeatability of a Screening Test

Repeatability is an attribute of an ideal screening test. It is also called reliability, precision, or reproducibility. It implies that the test must give consistent results when repeated on the same individual or material, under the same conditions.

It depends upon three factors:

A. Observer variation

  • All observations are subjected to variations.
  • Intra-observer variations or within-observer variations are when a single observer takes two measurements in the same subject, at the same time and obtained two different results.
  • Inter-observer variations or between-observer variations are when two different observers obtain different results on the same subject or material.
  • They are minimized by standardization of procedures, intensive training of observers, and making use of more observers.

B. Biological variation

  • It is also called subject variation.
  • They are due to changes in the parameters observed, variations in the perceptions of symptoms by patients, and regression to the mean where there is a tendency of values to be at either extreme of the distribution.

C. Errors relating to technical methods is due to the following:

  • Defective instruments
  • Erroneous calibration
  • Faulty reagents
  • Incorrect methods

questions.text: The ABG value of a patient presenting with vomiting is likely to correspond to which of the following areas in the given acid-base nomogram?
questions.solution:
The image shows the acid-base nomogram, which is plotted as arterial HCO3- against arterial blood pH. The area marked 'C' is suggestive of metabolic alkalosis, which is seen in vomiting.

In the area marked 'C', pH is above the normal limits (7.35–7.45) and thus implies the presence of alkalosis. Plasma HCO3-  is higher than the normal limits (22–28 mEq/L). This implies that the alkalosis is due to an increase in the plasma HCO3- and is thus metabolic in origin. 

Net gain of [HCO3-] or loss of nonvolatile acid (usually HCl by vomiting) from the extracellular fluid causes metabolic alkalosis. HCO3− secretion in the small bowel cannot begin when vomiting results in the loss of HCl from the stomach; as a result, HCO3− is retained in the extracellular fluid.

Compensatory responses for primary metabolic disorders move the PaCO2 in the same direction as the change in HCO3−. Electrolyte abnormalities seen are hypocalcemia, hypokalemia, and hypophosphatemia.

Clinical features include:

  • Mental confusion
  • Reduced level of alertness 
  • Predisposition to: seizures, paresthesia, muscular cramping, tetany, arrhythmias, and hypoxemia in COPD

Management of metabolic alkalosis involves:

  • Correction of the underlying cause
  • Remove factors causing an increase in HCO3- absorption like extracellular fluid volume contraction or hypokalemia.
  • In case of excess fluid administration, renal loss can be encouraged by the administration of acetazolamide.

Causes of metabolic alkalosis:

Loss of hydrogen:

  • Gastrointestinal loss:
    • Removal of gastric secretions, such as in vomiting or gastric aspiration
    • Chloride-losing diarrhea
    • Gastrocolic fistula
  • Renal loss:
    • Loop or thiazide diuretics
    • Mineralocorticoid excess (primary aldosteronism, Cushing's, steroids, licorice)
    • Hypercalcemia, including the milk-alkali syndrome
  • H+ movement into cells:
    • Hypokalemia

Exogenous Alkali:

  • Administration of NaHCO3, sodium citrate/gluconate/acetate/antacids
  • Massive blood transfusion
  • Antacids- Milk alkali syndrome
 

Other options:

Option A: (Area B- corresponds to chronic respiratory acidosis) An increase in PaCO2 and a decrease in pH indicates respiratory acidosis, which occurs due to severe pulmonary disease, respiratory muscle exhaustion, or anomalies in ventilatory control. Renal adaptation raises the [HCO3-] in chronic respiratory acidosis (>24 h) by 4 mmol/L for each 10-mmHg increase in PaCO2. It is seen in conditions like emphysema, pneumoconiosis and bronchitis. 

Option C: (Area F- corresponds to metabolic acidosis). Increased endogenous acid production (such as lactate and ketoacids), loss of bicarbonate (as in diarrhoea), or accumulation of endogenous acids due to low excretion of net acid by the kidney (chronic kidney disease) can all lead to metabolic acidosis.

Option D: (Area E- corresponds to chronic respiratory alkalosis). Respiratory alkalosis is induced by a process involving hyperventilation resulting in a decrease in PaCO2 and an increase in HCO3−/ PaCO2 ratio, thus increasing the pH. Causes include anxiety-hyperventilation, fear, hypoxic stimulation and pulmonary causes such as pulmonary embolism, pneumothorax and COPD exacerbations. Chronic respiratory alkalosis occurs when hypocapnia persists for >3–5 days. 

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with 3 months of amenorrhea. She was found to have abnormally high levels of serum β-hCG. Her ultrasound abdomen and pelvis is given below. Cytogenetic examination of this tissue will most likely demonstrate which of the following genetic patterns?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the ultrasonogram image showing the snowstorm appearance is suggestive of a complete mole. Cytogenetic examination of this tissue will most likely demonstrate diploidy. 

The snowstorm appearance is seen as an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XYY or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: A middle-aged chronic smoker has recently been discharged from the hospital after being admitted for an acute exacerbation of chronic bronchitis. He is now motivated to quit smoking and wants to know about medications that will help him with quitting. All of the following can be used in him, except ______.
questions.solution:
Mirtazapine is not used in smoking cessation.

Mirtazapine is a serotonin receptor antagonist, used in the treatment of major depression.

Pharmacological methods to quit smoking:

1. Nicotine replacement therapy - is highly effective, because it reduces withdrawal symptoms. It is available as - 

  • Nicotine gum - available over the counter and releases nicotine via buccal absorption. One to two pieces of gum per hour up to a maximum of 24 pieces per day can be used
  • Nicotine lozenges - useful for patients who smoke a cigarette immediately on awakening
  • Nicotine patches - administered every morning and produce blood concentrations of nicotine about half those of smoking
  • Nicotine nasal spray - available only by prescription, produces nicotine concentrations in the blood comparable to smoking a cigarette and is helpful for heavily dependent smokers However, adverse effects like rhinitis, watering eyes, and coughing are experienced by most patients
  • Nicotine inhalers deliver 4 mg per cartridge and resultant nicotine levels are low

2. Non-nicotine medications:

1st line:

  • Bupropion - both dopaminergic and adrenergic actions. 
  • Varenicline - a partial agonist for nicotinic Ach receptor. Side effects include sleep disturbances, depression, and increased suicidal tendencies.

2nd line:

  • Nortriptyline - tricyclic antidepressant which appears to be effective for smoking cessation.
  • Clonidine - alpha-agonist which decreases sympathetic activity and thus decreases withdrawal symptoms.

It is recommended to offer nicotine patches or varenicline along with counselling and behavior therapy as a part of the cessation attempt. Acute exacerbations of chronic bronchitis are valuable "teachable moments" for the patient and can help reaffirm the smoking cessation message serving as a springboard for a cessation attempt.

Related Pearl: Substances of abuse

Substance
Withdrawal symptoms
Intoxication features

Tremors, delirium, seizures
Blackouts, nystagmus and slurring of speech
BZD
Tremors, insomnia, anxiety
Lethargy and drowsiness.
Opioid/ Heroin
Diarrhea, yawning, mydriasis, lacrimation, piloerection, cold turkey phenomenon
Euphoria, depressed mental status, miosis, respiratory depression, constipation.
Nicotine/ Tobacco
Increased appetite
Shows a biphasic pattern. 
Early stimulatory symptoms of vomiting, hypertension and tachycardia. Later depressive symptoms of hypotension and bradycardia.
Cannabis
Irritability, sweating, tremors, decreased appetite
Increased appetite, euphoria, conjunctival injection, dry mouth, panic, synesthesia, impaired time perception, amotivational syndrome, run amok and flashbacks.
Amphetamine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts, unpleasant dreams
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, paranoid hallucinatory syndrome, violent behavior, psychosis and diaphoresis.
Chronic: Runs & crashes, choreiform movements, tooth decay. Can resemble schizophrenia.
Cocaine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, agitation, euphoria, chest pain, seizures and mydriasis
Chronic: Cocaine psychosis (Magnan sign) and black pigmentation of the tongue.
LSD/ Haluccinogen
Nothing significant
Synesthesia, brisk tendon reflex, tachycardia, hypertension, panic, ataxia, visual hallucinations, euphoria and dysphoria.
Phencyclidine (PCP)
Nothing significant 
Tachycardia, hypertension, ataxia, hallucinations, violent behavior, dissociation, amnesia and nystagmus.

Related Pearl: Adverse effects of specific antidepressants

questions.text: A patient presented with bilateral hearing loss. His MRI showed bilateral solid lesions with ice-cream cone appearance.  A biopsy of the lesion is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture along with the histological image showing Verocay bodies suggest the diagnosis of a schwannoma. MRI had shown bilateral solid lesions with an ice-cream cone appearance that is typical of bilateral schwannomas seen in patients with neurofibromatosis type 2.

This is due to a mutation in the NF2 gene on chromosome 22 that leads to the loss of expression of the protein Merlin.  Microscopically, they are compromised of dense and loose areas called Antoni A and Antoni B respectively.

Antoni A is a dense eosinophilic area containing spindle cells with rod-shaped nuclei lying in the palisading pattern. The resulting structures with central nuclear-free zones ratified by the palisading of nuclei are termed Verocay bodies.  The loose hypocellular Antoni B area contains spindle cells spread apart by the myxoid extracellular matrix.

 

MRI shows left bilateral cerebellopontine (CP) angle mass causing widening of the porous acousticus. The mass is seen extending into the intracanalicular portion of the internal acoustic meatus which is suggestive of vestibular schwannoma (acoustic neuroma). Bilateral acoustic schwannomas are strongly suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2).

Acoustic neuromas are the most common CP angle tumours. Extracanalicular extension into the cerebellopontine angle (path of least resistance) leads to its characteristic ice-cream cone appearance.

 

Neurofibromatosis is an autosomal-dominant neurocutaneous syndrome of 2 types:

NF1 (von Recklinghausen disease)- Mutation on chromosome 17

2 or more of the following should be present:

  • 6 or more café-au-lait spots
  • 2 or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neuroma
  • Freckling in the axillary or inguinal region 
  • 2 or more Lisch nodules
  • Dysplasia of the sphenoidal and tibial bone
  • A first degree relative with NF1
  • Optic gliomas

NF2 (Central neurofibromatosis)- Mutation on chromosome 22

It predisposes to multiple tumors of the nervous system. Most common are bilateral vestibular schwannomas; intracranial and spinal meningiomas, gliomas, neurofibromas, and posterior subcapsular lenticular opacities.

Vestibular schwannomas are benign tumors that arise from the intracanalicular segment of the inferior division of the vestibulocochlear nerve. Extracanalicular extension into the cerebellopontine angle can lead to an "ice cream cone" appearance in MRI.

Related Pearl: Chromosomal abnormalities and syndromes associated with brain tumors

Syndrome Gene defect Tumor
Neurofibromatosis type 1 Neurofibromin (chr 17q)

Neurofibromas,

malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors, optic nerve gliomas,

hamartomatous lesions, pheochromocytomas.

 
Neurofibromatosis type 2 Schwannomin (chr 22q)

Bilateral eighth nerve schwannomas, multiple meningiomas,

ependymomas of the spinal cord

 
Cowden's disease PTEN (chr 10)

Dysplastic cerebellar gangliocytoma (Lhermitte-Duclos disease),

meningioma, astrocytoma

Hemangioblastomas, Retinal angiomas

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with Grave's disease has been started on an antithyroid drug. Following this, she developed a fever, and sore throat, with an absolute neutrophil count of 80 neutrophils per microlitre of blood. This drug is also known to cause an absence of fetal scalp skin if used during pregnancy. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
This patient who is on anti-thyroid drugs for Graves disease is suffering from agranulocytosis. The anti-thyroid drug that causes agranulocytosis and the absence of scalp skin in the fetus (aplasia cutis) if used during pregnancy is seen with the use of methimazole.

Methimazole is an anti-thyroid drug that inhibits the coupling and iodination of thyroid hormones decreasing the production of the hormones. 

Another principal anti-thyroid drug that works with a similar mechanism is propylthiouracil. Propylthiouracil also has additional properties of inhibiting the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. These drugs are used in the spontaneous remission of Graves disease and to control hyperthyroidism in preparation for any surgeries in the patient.

The most serious adverse effect of methimazole and propylthiouracil is agranulocytosis. Agranulocytosis usually occurs in the initial weeks or months of therapy. It occurs rapidly and hence periodic monitoring of granulocyte levels is generally ineffective. However, it is reversible on discontinuation of the drug. Therefore, patients who are on these drugs should be instructed to report immediately if they develop a fever or sore throat. They can be treated with recombinant human granulocyte colony-stimulating factors.

Methimazole should be avoided in the first trimester as it is associated with methimazole-associated embryopathy. It includes aplasia cutis, choanal atresia and esophageal atresia. Aplasia cutis is a full-thickness skin defect of the scalp.

The most common adverse reaction is the development of a mild urticarial papular rash which can be treated with antihistamines and corticosteroids. Other less common adverse effects include joint pain, headache, nausea, skin pigmentation and loss of hair. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Anti-Thyroid Drugs

 Drugs inhibiting iodide trapping:

  • Thiocyanates
  • Perchlorates
  • Nitrates

Drugs inhibiting hormone synthesis:

  • Propylthiouracil
  • Methimazole
  • Carbimazole

Drugs inhibiting hormone release:

  • Iodine
  • Sodium iodide
  • Potassium iodide
  • Organic iodide

Drugs inhibiting peripheral conversion:

  • Propylthiouracil
  • Amiodarone
  • Iodinated contrast dyes (Iopanoic acid)
  • Propranolol
  • Glucocorticoids

Drugs that destroy thyroid tissue:

  • Radioactive iodine

Related Pearl: Drug of choice for hyperthyroidism/thyrotoxicosis in pregnancy

In the 1st trimester: Propylthiouracil

In the 2nd and 3rd trimester: Methimazole

questions.text:
Which of the following amino acids cannot be used for the synthesis of glucose through gluconeogenesis?
  1. Isoleucine
  2. Alanine
  3. Leucine
  4. Tryptophan
  5. Lysine
questions.solution:
Leucine and lysine yield only acetyl-CoA on oxidation (ketogenesis), and hence, they cannot be used for gluconeogenesis.

Most of the amino acids in excess yield pyruvate or the intermediates of the citric acid cycle. Pyruvate can be carboxylated to oxaloacetate, which is the primary substrate for gluconeogenesis. Thus, these amino acids that yield pyruvate or oxaloacetate are classified as glucogenic. The actions of transaminases, alanine, cysteine, glycine, hydroxyproline, serine, threonine, and tryptophan yield pyruvate. 

Lysine and leucine yield only acetyl-CoA on oxidation, and hence cannot be used for gluconeogenesis. Since these yield only acetyl-CoA, these are classified as ketogenic. 

Four other amino acids, namely, phenylalanine, tyrosine, tryptophan, and isoleucine, give rise to both acetyl-CoA and intermediates; therefore, they can be used for both ketogenesis and gluconeogenesis.

Related Pearl: Irreversible enzymes in gluconeogenesis pathway

The enzymes can be remembered using the mnemonic Pathway Produces Fresh Glucose.

Pyruvate → Oxaloacetate

mitochondria

Activated by acetyl-CoA
Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase Oxaloacetate → PhosphoenolPyruvate (cytosol) GTP
Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate → fructose-6-phosphate (cytosol)

Citrate(+ve)

Fructose 2,6 bisphosphate (-ve)
Glucose-6-phosphatase Glucose-6-phosphate → glucose Endoplasmic reticulum
