questions.text: A patient presents to you with intra-peritoneal extravasation of urine due to rupture of the bladder. Which of the following history would most likely be associated with such an injury?

choices.text: Road traffic accident with the seat-belt on

questions.solution:
The history associated with such an injury would most likely be a road traffic accident with the seatbelt on resulting in blunt trauma to a distended bladder and its subsequent rupture. The patient has intra-peritoneal extravasation of urine caused due to intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

The bladder dome is the most commonly involved part in intraperitoneal bladder rupture (causing extravasation of urine) as it is the weakest part of the bladder.

Bladder rupture may be extraperitoneal or intraperitoneal. The type of bladder rupture depends on the location of the injury and its relationship with the peritoneal reflection as below:

  1. If the bladder rupture is above the peritoneal reflection (on the bladder dome), the urine extravasation will be intraperitoneal.
  2. If the bladder rupture is below the peritoneal reflection (eg: neck) and not on the dome, the urine extravasation will be extraperitoneal.

Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is the most common. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by blunt trauma or surgical damage.

Intraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by a blow or fall on the distended bladder. Intraperitoneal bladder rupture manifests as sudden severe pain in the hypogastrium and syncope. There will be an associated increase in BUN and creatinine due to systemic absorption of the extravasated urine and it may also lead to chemical peritonitis.

Other options:

Option A: Foley catheterization or urethral instrumentation usually causes injury at the site where the urethra bends or is narrow. The most common sites of urethral injury include the sub-meatal area, the bulbar urethra and the membranous urethra.

Option C: Perineal injury while cycling usually results in injury to the bulbar urethra. Bulbar urethral injury is the most common type of urethral injury. It occurs when there is a blow to the perineum. It occurs commonly due to cycling accidents, loose manhole covers, and gymnasium accidents. Clinical features include perineal bruising, hematoma (butterfly distribution), bleeding from urethral meatus, and retention of urine is present.

Option D: Cystitis is not associated with bladder rupture.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about miRNA?

choices.text: DICER is involved in the processing of miRNA

questions.solution:
The inhibition is done at the level of translation.

RNA interference (RNAi) is a biological process in which miRNA/ siRNA molecules inhibit gene expression by neutralizing targeted mRNAs.The microRNA (miRNA) belongs to a group of non-coding genes. The miRNA genes are transcribed but not translated into proteins. They play a role in the regulation of the expression of the target gene by post-transcriptional silencing.

Mechanism:

  • The miRNA gene present in the nucleus is transcribed to primary miRNA, which is further converted to pre-miRNA by an enzyme DROSHA intranuclearly and exported to the cytoplasm by an export protein.
  • The pre-miRNA undergoes trimming, by an enzyme called DICER, into mature single-stranded miRNA.
  • The mature miRNA is associated with a multiprotein aggregate called RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC).
  • The target mRNAs contain seed sequence in their 3′ untranslated region (UTR) that determines the specificity of miRNA binding and gene silencing.

Depending on the base pairing between the miRNA strand and its target mRNA, the RISC causes gene silencing either by mRNA cleavage or by repressing its translation.

siRNA is similar in function to miRNA and is used in RNA interference.

miRNA expression has been found to be dysregulated in many cancers. Such misregulation is thought to have a causal role in the pathogenesis of such cancers. Some types of miRNAs are oncogenic (referred to as oncomiRs) and are overexpressed in cancerous tissue. On the other hand, tumour-suppressive miRNAs that counteract oncogenic characteristics are found to be underexpressed in cancers.

questions.text:
Match the following surgeries with their associated complications.
Surgery Complication
1. Breast surgery a. Diaphragmatic weakness
2. Thyroid surgery b. Hoarseness of voice
3. Thymectomy c. Weakness of the lower lip
4. Parotidectomy d. Winging of scapula
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Surgery Complication
1. Breast surgery d. Winging of the scapula
2. Thyroid surgery b. Hoarseness of voice
3. Thymectomy a. Diaphragmatic weakness
4. Parotidectomy c. Weakness of the lower lip

1. During breast surgery, removal of axillary lymph nodes is common. This carries a risk of injury to the long thoracic nerve, which originates from the C5-C7 roots of the brachial plexus. It innervates the serratus anterior muscle. Injury to this nerve during surgery results in paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle leading to winging of the scapula.

2. Thyroid surgery may cause injury to both external and recurrent laryngeal nerves (RLN). The upper part of the RLN is closely related to the inferior thyroid artery. Hence, during thyroidectomy surgeries, there might be unilateral or bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury. Unilateral RLN injury may be asymptomatic but in a few may cause hoarseness of voice. 
Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy can also occur postoperatively. It causes dyspnea and stridor but the voice is good. These cases required emergency tracheostomy.

3. Thymectomy is performed for patients with myasthenia gravis and thymoma. During surgery, the entire thymus and all accessible fatty areolar tissue in the mediastinum are removed. This ensures the removal of all ectopic thymic tissues and hence a reduction in tumor recurrences. Preservation of the phrenic nerves is an important component of the surgery as it causes diaphragmatic weakness.

4. An important structure traversing through the parotids is the facial nerve. During parotidectomy, the facial nerve is dissected and preserved as well as possible depending on the type of parotid surgery. Though all the branches of the facial nerve could be injured, weakness is mostly in the marginal mandibular branch territory as it is stretched during surgery and presents as weakness of the lower lip in the affected side.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was recently diagnosed with non-Hodgkin lymphoma and was started on an anticancer drug. After a few days, the patient started passing blood in the urine for which mesna was used as a treatment. Which of the following is responsible for the side effect?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is suffering from hemorrhagic cystitis as an adverse effect, due to the toxic metabolite of cyclophosphamide called acrolein. This can be decreased by vigorous hydration and by the use of mercaptoethanesulfonate (mesna).

Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent that interferes with DNA integrity and function. It induces cell death in rapidly proliferating tissues. It is metabolised by hepatic cytochrome enzyme to form 4-Hydroxycyclophosphamide. The tautomer of 4-Hydroxycyclophosphamide called aldophosphamide cleaves non-enzymatically in the tumor cell to form phosphoramide mustard and acrolein.

Antitumor effects are due to phosphoramide mustard, while acrolein causes hemorrhagic cystitis. Vigorous intravenous hydration should be done in patients with high-dose treatment. Brisk hematuria in a patient receiving daily oral therapy should lead to immediate drug discontinuation.

Cyclophosphamide is an essential component of many effective drug combinations for non-Hodgkin lymphomas, other lymphoid malignancies, breast and ovarian cancers, and solid tumors in children.

questions.text: A resident asks you to assist while performing an e-FAST on a patient with multiple rib injuries due to an RTA. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this procedure?

choices.text: Abdominal cavity, thoracic cavity, and pericardium are assessed
It is reliable in detecting even less than 100 mL of free blood
It is unreliable for assessment of the retroperitoneum

questions.solution:
e-FAST is not reliable in detecting less than 100 mL of free blood.

e-FAST (extended-focused assessment with sonography for trauma) is a rapid diagnostic examination to assess patients with potential thoracoabdominal injuries. It is used to assess the presence of free fluid in the abdominal cavity, thoracic cavity, and pericardium. It is performed within 2­-4 minutes.

Disadvantages:

  • It is not reliable in detecting less than 100 mL of free blood.
  • Does not directly identify injury to the hollow viscus.
  • Cannot reliably exclude injury in penetrating trauma.
  • It is unreliable for the assessment of the retroperitoneum.

If there is a doubt, eFAST may be repeated or supplemented with other investigations.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient was brought to the emergency room with complaints of severe headache, sweating, and palpitations. She gives a history of the consumption of red wine. She was on selegiline for treatment of Parkinsonism. On examination, her BP is 200/110mmHg. Which of the following drugs is preferred for treating hypertension in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cheese reaction and phentolamine is the preferred drug for treating hypertension in this patient.

Tyramine is a sympathomimetic amine. In patients who are on monoamine oxidase inhibitors (selegiline), when they consume tyramine-rich foods like cheese, aged meat, red wine, fish, etc, the amine does not undergo degradation along the intestinal walls and liver and reaches the circulations. These amines release large amounts of catecholamines in the adrenergic nerve endings.

Therefore the patients will present with hypertension, agitation, diaphoresis, tachycardia, muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, etc. This will be followed by hypotension and coma.

Patients should be managed symptomatically by cooling, use of antipyretics, fluid administration, etc. This hypertensive crisis is treated with short-acting drugs like phentolamine.

Phentolamine is a non-selective alpha antagonist that opposes the alpha receptor-mediated vasoconstriction of sympathomimetics. It is also used in:

  • clonidine withdrawal
  • short-term control of hypertension in pheochromocytoma
  • limiting the duration of soft tissue anesthesia.

Other options:

Option A: Phenoxybenzamine is a non-selective alpha antagonist with irreversible action. Short-acting drugs are used to manage hypertension in cheese reactions because long-acting drugs will worsen the hypotensive phase that follows a hypertensive crisis. It is used pre-operatively to reduce blood pressure in pheochromocytoma.

Option C: Prazosin is a selective alpha-1 blocker. Catecholamines act on alpha 1 and alpha 2 receptors that result in vasoconstriction. Another major problem with prazosin is marked postural hypotension and syncope following the first dose (first dose effect). So, using phentolamine is better as it is a non-selective alpha-receptor antagonist. Prazosin has been used in the treatment of hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Option D: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker. It can worsen hypertensive crisis by unopposed alpha stimulation. It is used in various conditions like essential hypertension, pheochromocytoma, myocardial infarction, cardiac arrhythmias, etc.

Related Pearl: Parenteral drugs used in hypertensive emergencies

questions.text: The baby in the image below was born at 37 weeks gestation with a birth weight of 4.9 kg to a mother diagnosed with gestational diabetes. Which of the following complications is likely to be seen in this neonate?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the baby born to a mother with gestational diabetes has macrosomia i.e. the baby is large for gestational age. The neonate is likely to develop polycythemia as a complication.

Polycy­themia occurs as a fetal response to relative hypoxia. Fetal hypoxia is due to a hyperglycemia-mediated increase in maternal affinity for oxy­gen and fetal oxygen consumption. Along with insulin-like growth factors, this hypoxia leads to increased fetal erythropoi­etin levels and red cell production.

Other neonatal complications of gestational diabetes include:

  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hyperbilirubinemia
  • Respiratory distress syndrome 
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Cardiac malformations - ventricular or atrial septal defect, transposition of the great vessels, truncus arteriosus, double-outlet right ventricle, tricuspid atresia, coarctation of the aorta
  • Neural tube defects, sacral agenesis, caudal regression syndrome, microcephaly, anencephaly
  • Renal agenesis, duodenal atresia, single umbilical artery

Later complications include childhood obesity, diabetes and neuropsychological effects.

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements regarding "A" in the image shown.
  1. It is synthesized primarily in the liver
  2. It is a negative acute phase reactant
  3. Mutations leading to its excess production are implicated in Wilson's disease
  4. It represses iron release from the macrophages
  5. Its deficiency is implicated in hemochromatosis
questions.solution:
The molecule represented as "A" in the given image is hepcidin. It is synthesized in the liver, represses iron release from the macrophages, and its deficiency is implicated in hemochromatosis.

Hepcidin is the key regulatory hormone that allows the liver to communicate with the bone marrow. It has anti-bacterial properties and derives its name from hepatic bactericidal protein. It is also called liver-expressed antimicrobial peptide (LEAP-1).

It is produced in the liver. It suppresses basolateral iron transport in the intestine and iron release from the macrophages and other cells by binding to ferroportin. It is a positive acute-phase reactant and its values strongly correlate with ferritin.

Hepcidin responds to liver-mediated signals, HFE, TfR2, and hemojuvelin. Mutations in hepcidin cause a form of hemochromatosis. It is excreted by the kidney and reabsorbed in the proximal tubules.

questions.text:
A patient with lung cancer on treatment for the past few months now presents with a mild headache, confusion, vomiting, and 2 episodes of convulsions. CT scan of the head appears normal. Laboratory investigations reveal hyponatremia and increased osmolarity of the urine. Which of the following drugs can be used in the management of this patient?
  1. Hypertonic saline
  2. Conivaptan
  3. Demeclocycline
  4. Fludrocortisone
  5. Desmopressin
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of the syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion (SIADH). Options 1,2,3, and 4 i.e. hypertonic saline, conivaptan, demeclocycline, and fludrocortisone can be used in the management of this condition. 

SIADH can occur as a paraneoplastic syndrome to cancers of the lung. Inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion can occur due to ectopic production of the hormone, or increased release of the hormone, or increased administration of the hormone. This occurs in carcinomas of the lung, duodenum, pancreas, ovaries, bladder and ureter. It is also seen in head trauma and infections like pneumonia, bacterial or viral, abscess (lung, or brain), cavitation (aspergillosis) and Tuberculosis.

Drugs that cause SIADH include vasopressin or desmopressin (5), serotonin reuptake inhibitors, oxytocin (high dose), vincristine, carbamazepine and nicotine. 

Increased anti-diuretic hormone results in the retention of water within the body causing dilution of the body fluids. Patients usually present with features of water intoxication. They include mild headache, confusion, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, coma, convulsions, and hyponatremia.

Treatment includes correction of sodium levels using hypertonic saline. Tolvaptan and conivaptan are AVP receptor-2 (arginine-vasopressin) antagonists. They block the action of anti-diuretic hormones. Other drugs which are useful in the management are demeclocycline and fludrocortisone.

Related Pearl: Causes of SIADH

questions.text:
While assessing an antenatal mother, you would suspect fetal asphyxia almost certainly if the biophysical profile score is:

AFV- Amniotic fluid volume
questions.solution:
Fetal asphyxia is suspected almost certainly if the biophysical profile score is 2/10.

BPP is a multi-parametric, screening test to assess uteroplacental insufficiency. It consists of five components or variables and the observations are made in a 30 minutes time period.

Components of BPP:

(Mnemonic:BATMaN)

  • B - Breathing movements of the fetus
  • A - Amniotic fluid volume (AFV)
  • T - Tone of the fetus
  • M - Movements of the fetus
  • N - Non-stress test (NST)

Each parameter has a maximum score of 2 and a minimum score of 0. So the total maximum score will be 10. A score of 4 or less indicates fetal acidemia.

Interpretation and management of BPP scores:

BPP score Interpretation Management
10 Normal, nonasphyxiated fetus Repeat test weekly (or biweekly in diabetic mothers or post-term pregnancy)
8 with normal AFV Normal, nonasphyxiated fetus Repeat test weekly (or biweekly in diabetic mothers or post-term pregnancy)
8 with decreased AFV Suspicion of chronic fetal asphyxia Delivery
6 Possible fetal asphyxia

Deliver, if AFV is abnormal or >36weeks or if the repeat test score is ≤ 6. If the repeat score >6, observation and repeat test weekly
4 Probable fetal asphyxia

Repeat testing same day

If the repeat score ≤6, delivery
0-2 Almost certain fetal asphyxia Delivery 

BPP is directly related to fetal pH and fetal outcome. A lower BPP score is associated with a poor outcome (stillbirth, perinatal mortality) and lower APGAR scores at birth.

A score of <10 is associated with a pH of <7.2 and a score of 0 is associated with 100% fetal acidemia.

Note: The modified biophysical score has only 2 components i.e NST and amniotic fluid index only. It is considered abnormal (nonreassuring) when the NST is non-reactive and/or the AFI is <5.

questions.text:
Match the following mutated proteins with the disease that they can be associated with:
Mutated protein Disease
1. RB A.Familial gastric cancer
2. Menin B. Retinoblastoma
3. p53 C. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
4. E-cadherin D. Li Fraumeni syndrome 
5. STK 11 E. Multiple endocrine neoplasia-I
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-B, 2-E, 3-D, 4-A, 5-C. The table below depicts the mutated proteins correctly paired with the diseases they can cause-

Mutated protein Disease
1. RB B. Retinoblastoma
2. Menin E. Multiple endocrine neoplasia- I
3. p53 D. Li Fraumeni syndrome
4. E-cadherin A. Familial gastric cancer 
5. STK 11 C. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome 

1. RB protein is derived from the RB gene. The main function of this protein is to inhibit G1 to S transition during the cell cycle progression. Hence, it controls proliferation by regulating an important step in cell division. Both the RB genes must undergo mutation in order for a child to develop retinoblastoma (Knudson's two-hit hypothesis). These mutations can be inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion or may be sporadic. Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular tumor seen in children.

2. Menin is a protein that normally functions as a transcription factor. It is derived from the MEN I gene. Mutations in this gene result in the MEN I syndrome (multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome I) which presents with tumors of the pituitary, pancreas, and parathyroid.

3. p53 is a protein that is involved in cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in response to DNA damage. A mutated p53 results in the proliferation of damaged cells that can ultimately lead to cancerous cell lines. This mutation is seen very commonly in Li Fraumeni syndrome, which can present with a broad spectrum of tumors such as breast cancer, adrenocortical tumors, leukemias, etc. 

4. E-cadherin is a protein derived from the gene CDH 1. This protein is responsible for cell adhesion and inhibiting cell motility. Its mutation can result in familial gastric cancer. Mutations in E-cadherin are also thought to be responsible for metastasis in breast cancer.

5. STK11 is normally a cell growth suppressor. In the mutated form it can lead to Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, which can present with gastrointestinal polyps, pancreatic cancer, and other gastrointestinal tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following part of the nephron is the site of maximum water reabsorption in the presence of anti-diuretic hormone levels under normal physiological conditions?
questions.solution:
The proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), marked as "1" in the above image of the nephron is the site of maximum water reabsorption even in the presence of ADH under normal physiological conditions.

The structures marked in the image are as follows:

  1. PCT.
  2. Distal convoluted tubule (DCT).
  3. Loop of Henle.
  4. Collecting duct.

PCT reabsorbs about 60-70% of the filtered water. Isosmotic reabsorption occurs in the PCT i.e. the amount of solute and water reabsorbed are coupled and are proportional to each other. Here the solute that is reabsorbed along with the water is Na+. So 60-70% of both filtered Na+ and water are re-absorbed in the PCT. 

These large amounts of Na+ and water reabsorption are essential in maintaining the ECF volume. 

In addition to the isosmotic reabsorption, the water reabsorption in the PCT also occurs through the active water channels known as aquaporin-1. 

The loop of Henle accounts for about 15-20% of the total water reabsorption. The descending thin segment is highly permeable to water. The ascending limb is impermeable to water and is important for concentrating urine.

By the time, the tubular fluid reaches the distal tubule and the collecting duct, 70-80% of water is already reabsorbed from the PCT and loop of Henle.

The collecting duct epithelium is relatively impermeable to water in the absence of vasopressin. Antidiuretic hormone or vasopressin acts on the collecting duct via aquaporins -2. Vasopressin is secreted in response to the tonicity of the plasma and water is reabsorbed if the plasma is hypertonic. In normal conditions, it accounts for the reabsorption of only about 10-15% of the total water in the tubular fluid.

So, regardless of the anti-diuretic hormone levels, water is maximally reabsorbed from the proximal convoluted tubules, under normal physiological conditions.

Related Pearl: Water transport along nephron

Segment

Mechanism of Water Reabsorption

Proximal tubule(67%)

Osmosis, AQ 1

Loop of Henle (15%)

Descending thin limb only; aquaporin 1 channels

Early distal convoluted tubule(0%)

No water reabsorption

Passive(aquaporin-2) under the influence of ADH

questions.text: The spinal X-ray of an elderly man with diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) will have all of the following features, except:

choices.text: Anterolateral ossification of at least four contiguous vertebrae

questions.solution:
The spinal X-ray in diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) /Forestier's disease shows relative preservation of disc height.

Forestier’s disease is a common condition seen in the late-middle-aged/ elderly characterized by hyperostosis seen at multiple sites, but mainly in the spine at enthesis sites (where tendons and ligaments attach to the bone). The most common site for spinal involvement is between T7 to T12. Cervical and lumbar hyperostosis may also be seen.

DISH is not confined to the spine and may also be seen elsewhere in the skeleton - at attachments of ligaments to the bone around the pelvis, the calcaneus and other tarsals, elbow, hands, and patella.

DISH is fundamentally a radiological diagnosis and the symptoms are usually mild compared to the radiographic change.

Features of DISH include:

  • Ossification along the anterolateral aspect of at least four contiguous vertebrae
  • Relative preservation of disc height and absence of other features of osteoarthritis; and
  • Absence of sacroiliac joint erosion, fusion, and facet joint ankylosis
  • Hyperostosis along the anterolateral aspect of the vertebral bodies with bridging across the disc spaces
  • Calcification of anterior and sometimes posterior longitudinal ligaments appearing as 'flowing' or dripping like candle wax.

The spinal hyperostosis of DISH tends to be more irregular with a wavy surface contour than that seen in spondyloarthritis.

 

Ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament in DISH:

 

"Melted candle wax" appearance of calcification and ossification in diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH):

 

Ectopic calcification and new bone formation in diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH). Calcification in Achilles tendon insertion and calcaneal spur.

Related Pearl: Ankylosing Spondylitis VS Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis

           DISH         AS
Etiology Idiopathic Autoimmune
Age group Older patients (middle-aged) Younger patients
HLA No evidence of association with HLA-B27 Strong association with HLA-B27
Lab investigations Non-specific and inconclusive High ESR and CRP
Syndesmophytes Nonmarginal Marginal
Radiograph "Flowing candle wax"  "Bamboo spine" 
Disc space Preservation of disc space AS in cervical spine will show ossification of disc space

Associated disease Obesity, diabetes mellitus, hypervitaminosis A Autoimmune conditions like iritis, uveitis, ulcerative colitis

questions.text: Which among the following is not used in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation?
questions.solution:
Mendelsohn maneuver is not used in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation.

Mendelsohn maneuver is a form of a supraglottic swallow. It is done by voluntarily holding the larynx at its maximum height to prolong the duration of the cricopharyngeal opening. It has been used to treat patients with pharyngeal dysphagia.

Post-laryngectomy rehabilitation aims at establishing communication in a post-laryngectomy patient. Various methods used in these include:

  • Written language
  • Aphonic lip speech
  • Esophageal speech
  • Electrolarynx and transoral pneumatic device
  • Tracheoesophageal speech facilitated by Blom-Singer and Panje prostheses

Transoral pneumatic device is an artificial larynx used in those who fail to learn oesophageal speech. The vibrations generated in a rubber diaphragm are carried by a plastic tube into the back of the oral cavity. Here the sound is converted into speech by modulators. It uses expired air from the tracheostome to vibrate the diaphragm.

Blom-Singer prosthesis and Panje prosthesis are types of tracheoesophageal prosthesis. A tracheoesophageal prosthesis (TEP) involves a one-way valve that is inserted through a previously-created tracheoesophageal puncture. When the patient occludes the stoma, the exhaled air is shunted through the TEP into the esophagus, where it induces vibration of the upper esophagal sphincter, which is responsible for phonation. It generates the most intelligible, fluent, natural-sounding voice in contrast to other laryngeal speech methods.

questions.text:
Identify the tracts that are likely to be affected in a tumor involving the superior cerebellar peduncle.
  1. Anterior spinocerebellar tract.
  2. Globose-emboliform-rubral pathway.
  3. Dentatothalamic pathway.
  4. Posterior spinocerebellar tract.
  5. Corticopontocerebellar pathway.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option C - 1, 2, 3.

The tracts anterior spinocerebellar tract, globose-emboliform-rubral pathway, and dentatothalamic pathway enter the cerebellum through the superior cerebellar peduncle. Therefore, they are likely to be affected in a tumor involving the superior cerebellar peduncle.

The superior cerebellar peduncle includes fibers from deep cerebellar nuclei that project to the brainstem, red nucleus, and thalamus. The globose-emboliform-rubral pathway and dentatothalamic pathway are efferent tracts that pass through the superior cerebellar peduncle. 

The first-order neurons carrying fibers for unconscious proprioception from upper and lower limbs synapse with the nucleus dorsalis in the spinal cord. The second-order neurons form the anterior spinocerebellar tract which majorly decussates to the opposite side at the same level and ascends to reach the cerebellum through the superior cerebellar peduncle. It also sends collaterals to the same side as well. Therefore, any lesion in the superior cerebellar peduncle affects the afferents from the anterior spinocerebellar tract. 

Other options:

Posterior spinocerebellar tracts pass through the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

The corticopontocerebellar pathway is the afferent tract of the middle cerebellar peduncle.

Related Pearl: Cerebellar peduncles and their connections

  • Dentatothalamic pathway

questions.text: The image below shows the anterior surface of the left kidney. Which of the following areas is related to jejunum?
questions.solution:
The area on the anterior surface of the left kidney related to the jejunum is 2.

The other structures marked in the image are: 1 - pancreas, 3 - left colic flexure, and 4 - descending colon. 

The anterior relations of the left kidney include:

  • Left suprarenal gland 
  • Stomach
  • Pancreas
  • Jejunum
  • Spleen
  • Splenic flexure and the beginning of the descending colon

 The anterior relations of the right kidney include:

  • Right suprarenal gland
  • Second/ descending part of the duodenum
  • Liver
  • Hepatic flexure of the colon
  • Small intestine

The posterior relations of the kidneys are as follows:

  • Vessels - subcostal vessels
  • Ligaments - medial and lateral arcuate ligaments
  • Nerves - subcostal, iliohypogastric, and ilioinguinal nerves
  • Muscles - diaphragm, psoas major, quadratus lumborum, and transversus abdominis
  • Ribs -
    • Right kidney is related to the 12th rib 
    • Left kidney is related to the 11th and 12th rib

questions.text:
A patient presents with sudden onset nausea and pain in his right eye associated with blurring of vision and halos. On examination, ciliary congestion, corneal edema, and a mid-dilated pupil are observed. Gonioscopy reveals a closed angle of the anterior chamber. All of the following are sequelae to this episode except:
  1. Patches of iris atrophy
  2. Ciliary body shut down
  3. Glaukomflecken
  4. Iris bombe
  5. Spontaneous angle reopening
  6. Subcapsular lenticular opacity
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma. All of the above are sequelae to this episode, except 4 i.e. iris bombe.

Iris bombe refers to the collection of aqueous humour in the posterior chamber pushing the peripheral flaccid iris anteriorly resulting in appositional angle closure. It is implicated in the pathogenesis of angle closure glaucoma and is not a sequela.

Acute angle-closure glaucoma is an ocular emergency that causes acute red-eye and is associated with at least two of the following symptoms:

  • Acute onset ocular pain with nausea or vomiting
  • Intermittent blurring of vision with halos
  • Photophobia or
  • Loss of vision.

It is also associated with at least three of the following signs:

  • Ciliary congestion
  • Corneal edema and subsequent haziness
  • Fixed and mid-dilated, usually oval pupil
  • Shallow anterior chamber
  • Intraocular pressure elevated above 40 mmHg.

The clinical status of the eye, subsequent to an attack of acute angle-closure glaucoma is considered the sequelae of the attack, regardless of whether the patient has been treated or not. These include:

  • Post-surgical acute primary angle closure
  • Spontaneous angle reopening
  • Ciliary body shut down
  • Vogt's triad, which includes glaukomflecken i.e anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity, patches of iris atrophy, and slightly dilated non-reacting pupil.

The image below shows features of angle closure glaucoma.

 

Immediate medical management mainly aims at lowering IOP using drugs such as oral acetazolamide or intravenous mannitol. The definitive treatment is laser peripheral iridotomy. Prophylaxis of the fellow eye followed by long-term glaucoma surveillance and management of intraocular pressure in both eyes. 

Tricyclic antidepressants, drugs having significant anticholinergic action should be avoided or used with extreme caution in patients prone to developing acute angle-closure glaucoma.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: A known amount of inulin and Evans blue dye is injected into a healthy woman of 60 kg. The volume of distribution of inulin was 10 L and the volume of distribution of Evans blue dye was 2.5 L. What is the interstitial fluid volume in this woman?
questions.solution:
The interstitial fluid volume is 7.5 L in this woman.

Total body fluids are distributed between intracellular and extracellular fluid compartments. About two-thirds of the total body water is present as intracellular fluid and one-third is present as extracellular fluid.

The ECF comprises of three fluid compartments which are interstitial fluid, blood plasma, and another small compartment called the transcellular fluid. Interstitial fluid is about three-fourths (3/4th) of the ECF and blood plasma constitutes about one-fourth (1/4th) of the ECF.

The volume of distribution of Evans blue dye is used to measure plasma volume. From the given data, the plasma volume is 2.5 L (option C). The volume of distribution of inulin is used to determine the volume of extracellular fluid (ECF) which is 10 L (option B) in this case.

The interstitial fluid volume = extracellular fluid volume - plasma volume

Interstitial fluid volume = 10 L - 2.5 L = 7.5 L

Other volumes:

The intracellular fluid volume is about twice the extracellular fluid, which is around 20 L.

The total body water will be 20 L+ 10 L = 30 L

In an adult man, the total body water is about 60% of the total body weight and in a woman, it is about 50% of the body weight. This percentage varies with age, sex, and degree of obesity.

Related Pearl: Body Fluids Compartments

  • In ECF, a third specialized compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. Altogether it constitutes about 1-2 L.
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

Related Pearl: Indicators for measurement of body fluids

Compartments

Indicators

Plasma volume
  • Evans’ blue(T1824)
  • Human serum albumin tagged with radioactive iodine125

RBC volume

Tagging RBC with cr-51, Fe-59, 32P, also antigenic tagging

ECF volume
  • Inulin
  • Sucrose
  • Mannitol
  • Sodium thiosulphate
  • Sodium thiocyanate

Interstitial fluid

Cannot be measured directly.

ECF minus plasma volume gives the value

ICF

Cannot be measured directly.

TBW minus ECF gives the value (D2O minus Mannitol)

TBW

D2O (2H2O)

Tritium oxide (3H2O)

Antipyrine

Aminopyrine

questions.text: An ophthalmologist performs the swinging flashlight test which reveals the findings as shown below. In which of the following conditions is this finding likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
This finding is seen in extensive retinal detachment.

The image shows Marcus Gunn pupil/ afferent pupillary defect confirmed by the swinging-flashlight test. The right eye is affected, while the left eye is normal. It occurs in severe retinal diseases like extensive retinal detachment. 

The flashlight is swung to and fro and the pupillary response is observed. Normally, both pupils remain constricted. In the presence of RAPD (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect), both pupils dilate on moving the flashlight from the normal to the abnormal eye. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is called Marcus Gunn pupil.

Impaired pupillary constriction due to a defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex in one eye, causes a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or a Marcus-Gunn pupil on a swinging flashlight test. 

The following image shows the swinging flashlight test as seen in a normal person and in a patient with a right relative afferent pupillary defect.

 

Other options:

Option B: Argyll Robertson pupils (AR pupils) are bilateral small pupils with light-near dissociation and is a specific sign of neurosyphilis and is due to a lesion in the pretectal nucleus. When light is shone on the pupils, they do not react. However, they contract on convergence. 

Option C: The tonic pupil of Adie syndrome is a dilated pupil with light-near dissociation due to postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage. The affected pupil is dilated. When light is shone on the pupil, constriction is present but is of low magnitude. It has a sluggish reaction to convergence.

Option D: In complete optic nerve lesion, an absolute afferent pupillary defect. When light is shone on the normal eye there is constriction of both pupils. However, when light is shown in the affected eye there is no response in both pupils.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presented with severely pruritic, large, tense, multiple blisters on the trunk and flexor surfaces. Histopathology shows subepidermal blisters with eosinophils. Direct immunofluorescence reveals IgG deposits as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is wrong about this disease?

choices.text: The main target antigen is BP180.
There is an association with psoriasis.
Nikolsky's sign is positive in this disease.
Corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment.

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and the direct immunofluorescence image are suggestive of bullous pemphigoid. Nikolsky's sign is negative in bullous pemphigoid.

Bullous pemphigoid is one of the most common subepidermal immunobullous disorders. It is mostly a disease of the elderly. It is characterized by a subepidermal split, with tissue-bound and serum IgG antibodies against BP180 and BP230 antigens.

Bullous pemphigoid is associated with psoriasis and treatments of psoriasis, like phototherapy and psoralen. It is also precipitated by triggers like trauma, burns, skin grafting, and drugs like furosemide.

Clinical features:

  • Prodromal phase:
    • Excoriated papules, eczematous or urticarial skin lesions, and hemorrhagic crusts may be seen.
  • Bullous phase:
    • Intense pruritus is almost constantly present.
    • Symmetrically distributed tense bullae and vesicles are seen over the flexural aspects and abdomen of the body.
    • Partly hemorrhagic crusts and erythematous plaques with an annular pattern are seen.
    • Lesions heal without scarring, provided there are no superinfections.
    • The bullae contain clear, sometimes hemorrhagic, exudates.
    • Nikolsky's sign is negative.
    • Oral or mucosal lesions and milia formation are rare.

The image given below shows the lesions seen in bullous pemphigoid.

 

Histopathology shows the presence of subepidermal bullae with eosinophils. Immunofluorescent microscopy shows the presence of subepidermal split and deposition of IgG antibodies and C3 at the dermo-epidermal junction.

The below image shows linear IgG deposits at the dermo-epidermal junction seen in bullous pemphigoid.

 

Untreated bullous pemphigoid has a chronic, self-limiting course, with remissions and relapses. Complete remissions are possible with treatment.

Bullous pemphigoid is mainly treated with topical and systemic corticosteroids. Other drugs like azathioprine, dapsone, doxycycline, and immunomodulators are also used.

Related Pearl: Differences between pemphigus vulgaris and bullous pemphigoid

  Pemphigus vulgaris Bullous pemphigoid
Age 30-40 years 70-80 years
Antibody Anti-desmoglein Anti-hemidesmosome
Location of target antigens Intraepidermal Subepidermal
Immuno-fluorescence Fish-net pattern Linear, shoreline pattern
Bullae Thin and fragile Deep and tense
Mouth involved Yes No
Nikolsky’s sign Positive Negative
Symptom Painful Pruritic
Severity Life threatening Resolves

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy born to an HIV-positive mother is brought to the clinic with the findings shown in the image below. Which other condition can this child develop in the clinical stage that he is currently in?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of esophageal candidiasis and the image showing Kaposi's sarcoma is suggestive of HIV Stage IV according to the WHO staging of HIV/AIDS in children with confirmed HIV infection. The other condition that can develop in this stage is cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis.

Other Options:

Option A: Persistent parotid enlargement is seen in stage 2. 

Option B: Persistent oral candidiasis is seen in stage 3. 

Option D: Persistent hepatosplenomegaly is seen in stage 2. 

Related Pearl: Clinical stages of HIV in children/ infants

Stage 1

  • Asymptomatic
  • Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy

Stage 2

General-

  • Unexplained persistent hepatosplenomegaly
  • Recurrent or chronic upper respiratory infections (otitis media, otorrhoea, sinusitis, tonsilitis)
  • Fungal nail infections

Oral-

  • Recurrent oral ulcerations
  • Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement
  • Linear gingival erythema

Skin- 

  • Papular pruritic eruptions
  • Extensive wart virus infection
  • Extensive molluscum contagiosum
  • Herpes zoster

Stage 3

General-

  • Unexplained moderate malnutrition not adequately responding to standard therapy
  • Unexplained persistent diarrhea (14 days or more)
  • Unexplained persistent fever (above 37.6 °C intermittent or constant, for longer than one month)
  • Unexplained anemia (<8 g/dL), neutropenia (<0.5 x 109/L) or chronic thrombocytopenia (<50 × 109/L)

Oral-

  • Persistent oral candidiasis (after first 6-8 weeks of life)
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia
  • Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis/periodontitis

Respiratory-

  • Pulmonary TB/ Lymph node TB
  • Severe recurrent bacterial pneumonia
  • Symptomatic lymphoid interstitial pneumonitis
  • Chronic HIV-associated lung disease including bronchiectasis

Stage 4

General-

  • Unexplained severe wasting, stunting or malnutrition not responding to standard therapy
  • Chronic herpes simplex infection; (oro-labial or cutaneous of more than one month's duration or visceral at any site)
  • Extrapulmonary TB and disseminated non-tuberculosis mycobacterial infection
  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Oesophageal candidiasis (or candidiasis of trachea, bronchi or lungs)
  • Cytomegalovirus infection; retinitis or CMV infection affecting another organ, with onset at age over 1 month)
  • Disseminated endemic mycosis (extrapulmonary histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis)
  • Chronic cryptosporidiosis and isosporiasis
  • Symptomatic HIV-associated nephropathy or HIV-associated cardiomyopathy

Neurological-

  • Central nervous system toxoplasmosis (after one month of life)
  • HIV encephalopathy
  • Cerebral or B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis (including meningitis)

Respiratory-

  • Pneumocystis pneumonia
  • Recurrent severe bacterial infections (e.g., empyema, pyomyositis, bone or joint infection, meningitis, but excluding pneumonia)

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text: Which of the following features is false regarding cytotoxic T-cells and natural killer cells?

choices.text: Cytotoxic T-cells are MHC l restricted cells
Both are effective against virus-infected cells
Both require priming by antibodies to be activated
Natural killer cells is antigen non-specific

questions.solution:
The false statement is C. Natural killer (NK) cells do not require priming while cytotoxic T cells require priming with antigens for action since they are a part of cellular immunity. 

NK cells have different mechanisms of action while killing target cells. They can lyse IgG-coated target cells by binding to the Fc tail of IgG, through the CD16 receptor expressed on NK cells. This phenomenon is known as antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC).

NK cells secrete various cytokines such as interferon-γ (IFN-γ), which activate macrophages to destroy ingested microbes.

Target cell destruction by NK cells is also mediated through two others receptors - activating receptors and inhibitory receptors.

The activating receptors enable NK cells to recognize infected and stressed cells. The inhibitory receptors recognize self class-I MHC molecules, that are expressed on all healthy cells thereby preventing NK cells from killing normal cells. Virus infection / neoplastic transformation overexpresses the activating receptors and simultaneously reduces the expression of class-I MHC molecules. As a result, NK cells are activated and the infected cells are killed.

CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes directly kill damaged cells.

The differences between NK cells and cytotoxic T-cells are: 

Natural killer (NK) cell Cytotoxic T-cells
Does not require priming - rapid response    in hours  require priming - takes days to respond
MHC unrestricted  MHC restricted

Antibody-mediated and non-antibody  mediated killing

Non-antibody mediated killing / direct cytotoxicity

Kills virus-infected and neoplastic cells by apoptosis

Kills virus-infected, neoplastic, and donor graft cells by apoptosis
Antigen non-specific Antigen-specific 
Memory is absent Memory is present

questions.text: A young non-obese patient presented with increased fatigue for several months. Two of his relatives have a history of early-onset diabetes. Investigations revealed high blood glucose and low serum insulin levels. Urine ketones and islet autoantibodies were negative.  There was an improvement after 2 weeks of glimepiride. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: It responds to all oral hypoglycemic agents
It is associated with cystic kidney disease

questions.solution:
This patient is likely to have maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY). It responds only to sulphonylureas (glimepiride, glipizide), not all oral hypoglycemic agents.

The clinical vignette describes a young non-obese patient with a positive family history of diabetes. Features of reduced insulin level with no antibodies, negative urinary ketones, and a good response to a sulphonylurea drug (glimepiride) rule out the possibility of Type 1 diabetes mellitus.

MODY is a monogenic disorder inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion. It is generally inherited at the age of 25 years or younger. Patients are generally not obese. The pathophysiology of this condition involves impaired glucose-induced secretion of insulin. 

There are six types of MODY. However, type 3 is the most common. Types 1, 3 and 5 occur due to mutations in the hepatic nuclear factor. Type 2 occurs due to a mutation in the glucokinase gene and type 4 occurs due to mutations in pancreatic and duodenal homeobox 1. MODY type 5 is associated with renal cysts.

Patients usually respond to therapy with sulfonylureas but eventually require insulin as a result of beta-cell failure.

Vertical transmission through at least two successive generation (ideally three) is essential for diagnosis

Related Pearl: Types of Diabetes mellitus

II. Type 2 diabetes: Insulin resistance with relative insulin deficiency

III. Other specific types of diabetes

IV. Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM)

questions.text:
A 20-year-old boy presented with yellowish discoloration of the skin and sclerae for the last 3 days. He is otherwise asymptomatic. He had a viral fever one week ago which has now resolved. His investigations are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Serum bilirubin: 2.4 mg/dL
Unconjugated bilirubin: 2.1mg/dL
Conjugated bilirubin: 0.3mg/dL
Serum AST and ALT: Normal
questions.solution:
This patient has a short history of jaundice, which appeared only during a period of stress (viral fever). The lab reports show increased unconjugated bilirubin (normal 0.2-0.8 mg/dL) and normal AST and ALT levels. All this points toward a diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

Gilbert syndrome is a benign, familial disorder characterized by mild intermittent jaundice usually seen during stress, fatigue, or alcohol use. The condition is recognized to arise from a mutation in the promoter region of the UGT1A1 gene, which results in mildly decreased UDP-glucuronyltransferase production. This causes a reduction in the liver's ability to conjugate bilirubin, thus causing unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The total bilirubin value is usually < 3 mg/dL. 

Other options:

Option A: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and bilirubinuria. Patients are asymptomatic and other laboratory tests are normal. Liver biopsy shows characteristic deposition of black-colored pigment in the lysosomes of the centrilobular hepatocytes.

Option B: Rotor syndrome is similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome but has a milder presentation. Conjugated bilirubin levels are elevated. The liver biopsy does not show pigment deposition.

Option D: Crigler-Najjar syndrome is another syndrome that has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is of two types, with type 1 having absent/trace UDP-glucoronyltransferase production and type 2 having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Type 1 is far more severe and leads to kernicterus and neurological damage in infancy.

questions.text: The histology slide of a patient with renal cell carcinoma is as shown in the image below. While looking at the clinical history attached to the lab request, you learn that this patient also has cerebellar hemangioblastoma and retinal angiomatosis. This would lead you to suspect which of the following conditions in the patient?
questions.solution:
The histological image shows clear cell renal carcinoma, which along with the history of cerebellar hemangioblastoma and retinal angiomatosis is suggestive of von Hippel-Lindau syndrome. 

VHL disease is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait and is characterized by a predisposition to a variety of neoplasms, particularly hemangioblastomas of the cerebellum and retina. Hundreds of bilateral renal cysts, often multiple, clear cell carcinomas develop in 40% to 60% of affected persons. Those with VHL syndrome inherit a germline mutation of the VHL gene on chromosome 3p. A 'second hit' can lead to manifestations.

  • Benign and malignant breast tumors 
  • Epithelial thyroid carcinoma
  • Papillary RCC or other histological subtypes
 

Note: RCC with syndromic associations tends to be bilateral. They also occur early in life.

VHL: von Hippel–Lindau

RCC: Renal cell carcinoma

PTEN: phosphatase and tensin homolog gene

BHD: Birt Hogg Dube

TSC: Tuberous sclerosis complex

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: The image given below depicts the life cycle of _______.
questions.solution:
The image given above depicts the life cycle of Ascaris lumbricoides.

It is an intestinal nematode that causes ascariasis. Infection occurs through food or water contaminated with nightsoil or human faeces having eggs of Ascaris that contain the infective rhabditiform larva. Man is the only natural host. There is no intermediate host.

The life cycle is as follows:

  • Adult worms live in the lumen of the small intestine. A female produces eggs which are passed with the faeces. 
  • Unfertilized eggs may be ingested but are not infective.
  • Larvae develop infectivity within fertile eggs in 10-40 days. It depends on the environmental conditions (optimum: moist, warm, shaded soil).
  • After infective eggs are swallowed, the larvae hatch.
  • The larvae invade the intestinal mucosa and are carried through the portal system, then systemic circulation to the lungs.
  • The larvae mature further in the lungs (10 to 14 days), penetrate the alveolar walls, ascend the bronchial tree to the throat, and are swallowed.
  • Upon reaching the small intestine, they develop into adult worms. Between 2 and 3 months are required from ingestion of the infective eggs to oviposition by the adult female. Adult worms can live for 1 to 2 years.

Adult worms can be occasionally detected in the stool or sputum of the patient. A definitive diagnosis is made by demonstration of eggs in faeces. Fertilized eggs are always bile stained. 

Effective and safe drugs for the treatment of ascariasis are Pyrantel pamoate 11 mg/kg once, Albendazole 400 mg once, Mebendazole 100 mg twice daily for 3 days, Ivermectin 150-200 mcg/kg once.

The image below shows the life cycle of Ascaris lumbricoides: 

Other options:

Option B. Paragonimus westermani (lung fluke - trematode) infection is acquired by consuming freshwater crab/ crayfish containing metacercariae. It causes pulmonary symptoms similar to pulmonary tuberculosis (coughing and hemoptysis).

  • Definitive host: Man, cats, tigers, leopards, foxes, dogs, pigs, beavers, and domestic animals.
  • First intermediate host: Freshwater snail.
  • Second intermediate host: Freshwater crab or crayfish.

The adult worms live in the respiratory tract of the definitive host in cystic spaces surrounded by a fibrous capsule formed by the host tissues. Unembryonated eggs escape into the bronchi and are coughed up and voided in sputum or swallowed and passed in feces.

Praziquantel (25 mg/kg TDS for 1–2 days) is the drug of choice.

The given image shows the life cycle of Paragonimus westermani:

Option C. Fasciola hepatica is a liver fluke (trematode) that resides in the liver and the lumen of the biliary passages and causes fascioliasis. It mainly affects sheep and other domestic animals. Infection in sheep and man is acquired by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation.

  • Definitive host: Sheep, goat, cattle, and man.
  • Intermediate host: Snails of the genus Lymnaea and Succinea. Encystment occurs on aquatic plants, which act as the second intermediate host.

Oral triclabendazole (10 mg/kg once) is the treatment of choice.

Life cycle of Fasciola hepatica:

Option D. Brugia malayi is a nematode that also causes filariasis in man. The intermediate hosts of Brugia are vectors of genera Mansonia, Anopheles, and Aedes. In India, the main vectors are Mansonia annulifera and Mansonia uniformis.

Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice. It is given orally in a dose of 6 mg/kg body weight daily, for a period of 12 days.

Life cycle of Brugia malayi:

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with bilateral pedal edema. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. It was found PAS positive. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology image showing acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules are suggestive of Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease. It occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

The following renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Glomerular lesions - Capillary basement membrane thickening, diffuse mesangial sclerosis, nodular glomerulosclerosis /Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease- intercapillary glomerulosclerosis.
  • Renal vascular lesions - hyaline arteriolosclerosis.
  • Pyelonephritis - necrotizing papillitis.

Other options:

Option A: In Renal amyloidosis, glomerular deposits appear as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid.

Option B: In focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, there is focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall with lipid droplets in the sclerosed area.

Option D: In lupus nephritis, immune complex deposits are seen in the mesangium or along the entire basement membrane (wire loop lesions), with mesangial cell proliferation.

questions.text: Which of the following apoproteins is an activator of lipoprotein lipase?
questions.solution:
Apo C-II is an activator of lipoprotein lipase. 

Apo C-II activates lipoprotein lipase present on the endothelium. Lipoprotein lipase hydrolyses the triacylglycerols into fatty acids and glycerol which are either used for storage or energy.

Apolipoproteins or apoproteins are the protein moiety of lipoproteins. Usually one or more of these are present in each lipoprotein. They are denoted as apo followed by the letters A, B, C, etc. The various functions of apolipoproteins include: 

  • They are part of the structure of lipoproteins
  • They can act as enzyme co-factors, for example, apo A-I for lecithin: cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT), apo C-II for lipoprotein lipase
  • They act as ligands for interaction with lipoprotein receptors in tissues, for example, apo B100 for LDL receptors

Other options: 

Option A: Apo A is the major apolipoprotein of HDL (high-density lipoprotein).

Option B: Apo B100 is the major apolipoprotein of LDL (low-density lipoprotein) and VLDL (very low-density lipoprotein). Apo B48 is the major apolipoprotein of chylomicrons.

Option D: Apo E is transferred by HDL to nascent chylomicrons and nascent VLDL to form mature forms of those particles.

questions.text: A patient who recently underwent parotidectomy presents with flushing, sweating, and a burning sensation on the left side of the face during a meal. Injury to postganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibers of which of the following nerves can result in this?
questions.solution:
The symptom complex in this patient coupled with a history of recent parotid surgery is indicative of Frey's syndrome, in which the auriculotemporal nerve marked as "D" is involved.

Frey’s syndrome/ Gustatory sweating (auriculotemporal syndrome):

It commonly develops after parotid surgery or other trauma that results in the opening of the parotid capsule. It results from damage to the autonomic innervation of the salivary gland. There is a regeneration of the parasympathetic nerve fibres that stimulate the sweat glands of the overlying skin in response to salivary stimulation or mastication. It is thought to reflect abnormal innervation of sweat glands on the face by regrowing parasympathetic secretomotor axons that would have previously innervated the parotid gland.

The clinical features include sweating, warmth, and erythema over the region of surgical excision of the parotid gland due to the autonomic stimulation of salivation by the smell/ taste of food.

Diagnosis is made using the starch iodine test. The affected area painted with iodine will turn blue on exposure to sweat.

It can be prevented by using a sternomastoid muscle flap, temporalis fascial flap, and insertion of an artificial membrane between the skin and the parotid bed. This will minimize the inappropriate regeneration of the autonomic nerve fibres. 

Treatment includes the use of antiperspirants with aluminium chloride, subcutaneous infiltration of purified botulinum toxin into the affected area and denervation by a tympanic neurectomy or auriculotemporal nerve avulsion. But is often not curative.

questions.text: Identify the given karyotype and its common association.
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings and the karyotyping suggest a diagnosis of Trisomy 21 or Down syndrome. The most common cardiovascular lesion in Down’s syndrome is an endocardial cushion defect.

Other associated defects are atrial septum defects (ASD), ventricular septum defect (VSD), patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), aberrant subclavian artery, and pulmonary hypertension.

Other congenital defects are seen in some syndromes:

Syndrome Congenital defect
Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) Endocardial cushion defect, VSD, ASD
XO (Turner syndrome) Bicuspid aortic valve, coarctation of the aorta
William's syndrome Supravalvular aortic stenosis, peripheral pulmonic stenosis
Noonan syndrome Pulmonic stenosis, ASD
Holt–Oram syndrome ASD, 1st-degree heart block
Marfan's Syndrome Mitral or Aortic Regurgitation

Other options:

Option C - Edwards syndrome is associated with Trisomy 18, in which a complete extra copy of chromosome 18 is inherited as a result of meiotic nondisjunction. Heart defects are the most common structural malformations seen in Edwards syndrome. It includes defects of septum, patent ductus arteriosus, valvular defects. 

Option D - Patau's syndrome is associated with Trisomy 13 and is commonly presented with atrial septal defect, ventricular septal defect, and valve abnormalities.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presented with complaints of pelvic and abdominal pain, and significant weight loss. A CT scan of the pelvis showed bilateral ovarian tumors and a CT scan of the chest showed pleural effusion. Pleural fluid analysis showed positive cytology for ovarian tumor cells. What FIGO stage does this belong to?
questions.solution:
According to the FIGO staging of carcinoma of the ovary, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal carcinoma, the presence of pleural effusion with positive cytology is classified as stage IV-A.

Other options:

Option A: Stage III-A1 is defined as a tumor involving one or both ovaries with positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes only.

Option B: Stage III-B is defined as a tumor involving one or both ovaries with macroscopic, extrapelvic, and peritoneal metastasis ≤2cm ± positive retroperitoneal nodes with extension to the capsule of the liver or spleen.

Option D: Stage IV-B is defined as hepatic and/or splenic parenchymal metastasis, metastasis to extra-abdominal organs including inguinal lymph nodes and lymph nodes outside of the abdominal cavity.

Related Pearl: Staging of Ovarian cancer

  • Stage I:
    • A: Tumor confined to unilateral ovary
    • B: Bilateral ovary
    • C: Capsule rupture
      • C1: Surgical  spill
      • C2: pre-operative capsule rupture
      • C3: malignant ascites
  • Stage II:
    • A: Extension to fallopian tubes/ uterus.
    • B: Extension to other pelvic intraperitoneal tissues
  • Stage III:
    • A1:Positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes(para-aortic)
    • A2:microscopic extrapelvic peritoneal deposits
    • B: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits <2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.  
    • C: Macroscopic peritoneal deposits >2cm ± positive retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Includes extension to capsule of liver/spleen.
  • Stage 4:
    • A: Malignant pleural effusion
    • B: Extra-abdominal spread/Inguinal lymph node involvement

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who works in the glass manufacturing industry comes with complaints of abdominal pain, loss of appetite, and blueline on the gums. You suspect lead poisoning. Which among the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is a notifiable and compensatable disease
Lead sulphide is the most toxic lead compound
Inhalation is the mode of absorption in most cases
D-penicillamine as chelating agent is effective

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding lead poisoning is option B. Lead sulphide is considered the least toxic among the lead compounds.

Lead poisoning/plumbism is a notifiable and compensatable disease.

Industries that utilize lead are glass manufacturing, ship-building, printing and potteries, storage batteries, and rubber industries. All lead compounds are toxic - lead arsenate, lead oxide, and lead carbonate are the most dangerous; lead sulphide is the least toxic.

Inhalation of fumes and dust of lead is the mode of absorption seen in most cases. Other modes are ingestion and absorption through the skin.

Management: D-penicillamine is reported to be an effective chelating agent.

Related Pearl: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

Lead Toxicity
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action
  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase
    • Ferrochelatase
  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase
  • Competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Kidney

(ABCDEF)

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: A young boy is being evaluated for hematuria and unilateral abdominal mass. Further history and examination reveal learning difficulties at school and ambiguous genitalia. The following eye-finding was noted as well. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The findings of hematuria and abdominal mass are suggestive of a renal tumor. This, along with aniridia (seen in the above image), abnormal genitalia, and mental retardation is suggestive of WAGR syndrome. 

WAGR syndrome has the following components:

  • Wilms tumour (W)
  • Aniridia (A)
  • Genitourinary anomalies (G)
  • Mental retardation (R)

WAGR syndrome is a contiguous gene deletion syndrome with a 50% risk of developing a Wilms tumour. It is caused due to the deletion of WT1 and PAX 6 genes on chromosome 11. 

Wilms tumour or nephroblastoma is the most common primary malignant renal tumour of childhood. It is the second most common malignant abdominal tumour in childhood after neuroblastoma. Loss of function mutation of the WT1 gene on chromosome 11p13 is commonly seen in Wilms tumor.

The other congenital syndromes associated with Wilms tumour are - 

  • Denys-Drash syndrome- Wilms tumour, early-onset renal failure, gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudohermaphroditism)
  • Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome- Wilms tumor, hemihypertrophy, organomegaly, macroglossia

Histologically, Wilms tumour is made of blastemal, stromal, and epithelial cells. The diagnosis can be confirmed by radiological investigations like CT, abdominal ultrasound, and biopsy.

Treatment depends on the stage of the disease and includes surgery, and chemotherapy, with or without radiotherapy.

Ehlers–Danlos syndrome is an autosomal dominant inherited disease of impaired collagen formation. The manifestations of this condition include blue sclera, skin and joint hypermobility, atrophic scars, and easy bruising. 

Related Pearl: Syndromic Associations of Wilms Tumor

Syndrome Mutation Features
WAGR Syndrome
  • WT1 and PAX6 deletion on Chr11p
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Wilms tumor
  • Aniridia
  • Genital anomalies
  • Mental retardation
Denys–Drash Syndrome
  • Dominant-negative missense mutation of WT1 protein
  • Genetic basis- two-hit hypothesis
  • Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudo hermaphroditism)
  • Early-onset nephropathy
  • Gonadoblastoma
Beckwith– Wiedemann Syndrome
  • IGF-2 overexpression onWT2 region
  • Genetic basis- genomic imprinting
  • Organomegaly
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihypertrophy
  • Omphalocele
  • Adrenal cytomegaly
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Pancreato-blastoma
  • Adrenocortical tumors
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.

questions.text:
Match the tumors in column A with their microscopic appearances in column B.
Column A  Column B
1. Yolk sac tumor A. Signet ring cells
2. Ovarian serous tumor B. Call-Exner bodies 
3. Krukenberg tumor C. Schiller-Duval bodies
4. Granulosa cell tumor  D. Psammoma bodies
questions.solution:
The correctly matched set of the tumors with their corresponding microscopic appearance is 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B. 

Column A Column B
1. Yolk sac tumor C. Schiller Duval bodies
2. Ovarian serous tumor D. Psammoma bodies
3. Krukenberg tumor A. Signet ring cells
4. Granulosa cell tumor B. Call-Exner bodies

 

Schiller Duval bodies are seen in yolk sac tumors. A yolk sac tumor/endodermal sinus tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. Schiller-Duval bodies are pathognomonic for yolk sac tumors. These are glomerulus-like structures consisting of a central vessel surrounded by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

The image below shows Schiller-Duval bodies seen in yolk sac tumor.

 

Psammoma bodies are concentrically calcified bodies seen in ovarian serous tumors and a few other cancers like papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Ovarian serous tumors are malignant tumors and account for approximately 40% of all ovarian cancers.

The image below shows Psammoma bodies in ovarian serous tumors.

 

Signet-ring cells are seen in the Krukenberg tumor. Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. Signet ring cells are mucin-producing cells. The appearance of a signet ring often originates from the gastric mucosa.

The image below shows signet-ring cells in the Kruckenberg tumor.

 

Call-Exner bodies are seen in granulosa cell tumors. Granulosa cell tumors arise from granulosa cells, which form part of the developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral in nature, and the mass is cystic and encapsulated.  These are gland-like small structures with acidophilic material and immature follicles.

The image given below shows Call-Exner bodies seen in granulosa cell tumors.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors
