questions.text: A woman who was started on treatment for leprosy recently presents with the following painful lesions that developed over the existing hypopigmented lesions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Development of ulcerating lesions over the leprosy skin lesions following initiation of treatment for leprosy is suggestive of a severe type 1 lepra reaction/ reversal reaction. 

Lepra 1 reactions are due to an enhanced cell-mediated immune response to M. leprae. They usually present abruptly with redness and inflammation of existing lesions but can cause ulceration in severe cases. It occurs due to a large amount of M. leprae antigens in these patients which results in prolonged and repeated reactions during treatment. They are commonly seen in the borderline spectrum but are most severe in borderline lepromatous leprosy.

Another form of lepra reaction with ulcerating lesions is the Lucio reaction. It is a rare type of lepra reaction that is seen in patients with lepra bonita. It is often the initial presentation in untreated patients. It is common over extremities and spreads in an ascending fashion. It presents as tender nodules that form jagged ulcers.  

Related Pearl: Lepra Reactions

Lepra Reactions:

Type 1 Reaction

(Reversal/Upgrading)

Type 2 Reaction

(Erythema Nodosum Leprosum)

Mainly seen in the Borderline spectrum (BT, BB, BL)

Most severe in Borderline Lepromatous(BL) leprosy

 Mainly seen in LL(50%)>BL(15%)

Usually seen within 12 months of initiation of Multidrug Therapy

 Unrelated to Multidrug therapy. May occur before, during or after treatment

Type 4 Hypersensitivity

Due to enhanced cell-mediated response increased destruction of bacilli following treatment in reversal

Type 3 Hypersensitivity

Primarily Humoral

(Immune complex Deposition in tissues and vessels)

Cytokine involved - TNF-α

Inflammation of existing skin lesions (red, painful edematous skin lesions) that may ulcerate

New lesions may occur (rare)

Neuritis and Nerve abscesses (red, painful inflamed nerves)

New, erythematous and tender, subcutaneous and dermal nodules that are widely distributed over extremities and face

Existing lesions do not change
No systemic involvement Systemic symptoms present - fever, myalgias, arthralgias, anorexia, keratitis, iritis, nephritis, synovitis, orchitis, lymphadenopathy

Treatment:

Supportive therapy for mild reactions with NSAIDs

In case of severe reactions with neuritis and eye lesions- Oral corticosteroids

(Drug of Choice)

Nerve Abscess - Additional surgical drainage

Other drugs: Clofazimine, Cyclosporine

Treatment:

Oral Corticosteroids - First-line drug

Clofazimine (Steroid dependent ENL)

Thalidomide -most effective but not used first due to various side effects

questions.text:
Which of the following is seen in freshwater drowning?

1. Haemodilution
2. Hypokalemia
3. Hyponatremia
4. Arrhythmia
questions.solution:
In cases of freshwater drowning, hyperkalemia is seen due to hemolysis of swollen RBCs and not hypokalemia.

Freshwater is hypotonic to plasma and is rapidly absorbed from the alveoli and into the RBCs. The RBCs finally swell up and lyse resulting in the release of intracellular potassium causing hyperkalemia. Increased intravascular blood volume combined with hyperkalemia causes arrhythmia. 

Seawater is hypertonic to plasma and causing a shift of fluid from the blood to alveoli causing pulmonary edema. There is a net decrease in blood volume causing a fall in blood pressure.

The table below summarises the cause of death in different types of drowning.

Type of drowning           Cause of death

Freshwater drowning

Seawater drowning

 Disruption of surfactant 

Dry drowning

 Laryngeal spasm/Vagal inhibition
Post immersion Syndrome / Secondary drowning

Cerebral anoxia

Pneumonia

Pulmonary edema

Chemical pneumonitis

Metabolic acidosis

Related Pearl: Difference between freshwater and seawater drowning.

  Freshwater drowning Seawater drowning
Mechanism of death Disruption of surfactant - causes surfactant denaturation Disruption of surfactant - causes dilution of surfactant
Fluid and electrolyte changes

Hypervolemia

Hyponatremia

Hyperkalemia

Hypovolemia

Hypernatremia
Time to death

Lesser (4-5 minutes)

More (8-12 minutes)

questions.text: In a statistical analysis, the following scatter plot is obtained. What is the inference about the correlation coefficient according to the plot?

choices.text: There is a linear negative correlation with correlation coefficient equal to -1
There is a linear positive correlation with correlation coefficient equal to +1
There is a linear positive correlation with correlation coefficient equal to zero
There is a linear negative correlation with correlation coefficient equal to zero

questions.solution:
The above scatter plot shows a linear positive correlation, with the correlation coefficient +1 [rise in the value of (X) proportionately raises the value of (Y)]

The correlation coefficient can be determined using the appearance of the scatter plot. In the given scatter plot, all the plotted points can fit a straight line perfectly. Hence the correlation coefficient is +1. Conversely, if it is not possible to draw a straight line that would fit the plotted points, the correlation coefficient would be zero.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: A term infant with a birth weight of 3 kg develops jaundice at day 3 of life. It first appeared on the sclera and progressed to the trunk with a total bilirubin of 11mg/dL by day 5. He was managed with the following procedure. Choose the correct option regarding this procedure.

choices.text: 400–430 nm wavelength of light is used in this procedure
Porphyria is not a contraindication for this procedure
Bronze baby syndrome is a complication of this procedure
Irradiance in intensive therapy should be at least 15 µW/cm2/nm

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of neonatal jaundice and the procedure shown in the image is phototherapy. The correct option regarding the procedure is that bronze baby syndrome is a complication of this procedure. 

Bronze baby syndrome is a complication associated with phototherapy. It is a dark, greyish-brown skin discoloration seen in infants with direct hyperbilirubinemia undergoing phototherapy. Phototherapy can be continued in such cases if required. Porphyria is a contraindication for phototherapy.  

Complications associated with phototherapy include: 

  • Loose stools
  • Erythematous macular rash
  • Purpuric rash associated with transient porphyrinemia 
  • Overheating
  • Dehydration (increased insensible water loss, diarrhea)
  • Hypothermia from exposure

The most effective wavelength of light for phototherapy in neonatal indirect hyperbilirubinemia ranges from 460–490 nm (blue-green light). It is more effective than blue light (430 to 470 nm) due to the following reasons:

  • It converts bilirubin to harmless forms.
  • Its longer wavelength (460 to 490 nm) enhances skin penetration
  • Pure blue light can mask cyanosis in an infant

Clinical jaundice and indirect hyperbilirubinemia are reduced by exposure to the high intensity of light in the visible spectrum by 3 mechanisms:

  • Irreversible structural isomerization - most important mechanism; acts by forming lumirubin from native bilirubin. It is then excreted by the kidneys in the unconjugated state
  • Reversible photo-isomerization - converts toxic unconjugated bilirubin into an unconjugated configurational isomer. It is then excreted in bile without conjugation
  • Photo-oxidation - minor method

Phototherapy can be discontinued once two TSB (total serum bilirubin) values 12 hours apart fall below current age-specific cut-offs.

Sn-mesoporphyrin (SnMP), a synthetic metalloporphyrin is a potential alternative medical therapy for neonatal jaundice. It acts by competitive inhibition of the conversion of heme protein to biliverdin by heme oxygenase. A single intramuscular dose on the 1st day of life reduces the need for subsequent phototherapy. Complication from metalloporphyrins includes transient erythema if the infant is receiving phototherapy

Assessing the level of jaundice: 

Kramer described dermal staining of bilirubin. It is used as a clinical guide in assessing the level of jaundice.


Other options: 

Option D: Irradiance in intensive phototherapy should be at least 30 µW/cm2/nm.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with complaints of irregular periods, acne, and increased facial hair growth. Her pelvic ultrasound is shown below. Which of the following is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the ultrasound abdomen and pelvis showing neck­lace appearance are suggestive of polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD). Centchroman is not used in the treatment of this condition. 

Centchroman, also known as ormeloxifene, is a non-steroidal oral contraceptive pill. It offers a combination of weak estrogenic and potent antiestrogenic properties. It inhibits the implantation of the fertilized ovum. It is contraindicated during the first 6 months of lactation, PCOD, hepatic dysfunction, and cervical dysplasia.

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)/ Polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD)/ Stein-Leventhal syndrome is a multisystem disorder. It involves metabolic and endocrine dysfunctions that commonly occur among women in the reproductive age group. It has multifactorial causation, such as lifestyle changes, stress, diet, obesity, and hyperinsulinemic states.

The original Rotterdam consensus defined polycystic ovaries when ≥20 follicles were seen per ovary on USG. Each follicle should measure between 2 and 9 mm, and/or an ovarian volume should be >10 ml. Due to improvements in imaging modalities since that time, the threshold for follicle number has now been raised to 26 per ovary.

Important clinical features of PCOS are:

  • Menstrual abnormalities - oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, or dysfunctional uterine bleeding
  • Hirsutism, acne, and alopecia due to hyperandrogenism
  • Acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance
  • Infertility

Medical management of PCOD includes Oral contraceptive pills to regulate the menstrual cycle and hormones. Metformin is an insulin sensitizer, thereby it decreases hyperinsulinemia. It also reduces the free and total testosterone and increases the sex hormone-binding globulin. It rectifies the root cause of the endocrine disturbance to restore ovulation and thereby improves the fertility rate. 

Many patients with PCOS struggle with infertility. The first-line treatment for ovulation induction is clomiphene citrate. Letrozole is given off-label in cases that are clomiphene resistant for infertility treatment.

Surgical management includes laparoscopic ovarian drilling in resistant cases and bariatric surgery in morbidly obese patients.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text:
Given below are colors representing the various intravenous cannulae. Arrange them in increasing order of their size.

1. Pink 
2. Grey
3. Green
4. Orange
5. Blue
questions.solution:
The increasing order of size for the given cannulae is 5, 1, 3, 2, and 4.          

  • 5 (22G) - Blue
  • 1 (20G) - Pink
  • 3 (18G) - Green
  • 2 (16G) - Grey
  • 4 (14G) - Orange

A standard wire gauge (SWG) is used to size cannulas. It is a measure of the cross-sectional area. It refers to the number of wires of the same size as the cannula that could pass through a hole of a standard size in parallel. Therefore larger cannulae have a smaller gauge number.

questions.text: Identify the given retractor used during open appendicectomy.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is the Langenbeck retractor.

Langenbeck retractor is a general-purpose retractor, useful for holding open wounds, as in an open appendicectomy. It is used in pairs (one in each of the assistant’s hands).

They stay in position when the tips lock in under the fascia. The width of the lip of the retractors is variable.

Other options:

Option A: Deaver’s retractor is used for holding the liver during cholecystectomy.

Option B: Czerney’s retractor is used for superficial skin retraction during laparotomy.

Option D: Dyball retractor is used in major abdominal surgery to retract deeper parts of the abdominal wall or the bladder or the uterus while operating on the rectum and entering the rectovesical or rectouterine pouch.

Related Pearl: Identification of Surgical Retractors

questions.text: Which is the enzyme involved in the detoxification of ammonia in the brain?
questions.solution:
Glutamine synthetase is involved in the detoxification of ammonia in the brain. It combines ammonia with glutamate to form glutamine. It requires the hydrolysis of ATP.

Glutamine synthetase provides glutamine which serves as a carrier of nitrogen, carbon, and energy between organs. It also plays a major role in ammonia detoxification and in acid-base homeostasis.

The deficiency of glutamine synthetase in neonates results in severe brain damage, multiorgan failure, and death.

Other options:

Option A: Glutamate dehydrogenase is found in the liver mitochondria and deaminates glutamate to alpha-ketoglutarate and ammonia.

Option C: Glutamate aminotransferase converts α-amino nitrogen to ammonia along with glutamate dehydrogenase. This is termed transdeamination.

Option D: Glutaminase is present in the liver and converts glutamine back to glutamate and ammonia, which is then detoxified to urea.

questions.text:
The flow-volume curve after the spirometry of a patient is given below. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is:

The dotted curve indicates the normal pattern.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an obstructive pattern on the flow-volume curve. So the most likely diagnosis of this patient is bronchial asthma.

The flow-volume curve above shows a concave upward pattern in the expiratory limb. This is also called a scooped-out or coved pattern and is observed in conditions responsible for airflow obstruction like asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, etc. 

Other options: 

Option A: Myasthenia gravis shows a restrictive pattern on the flow-volume curve. It is characterized by decreased total lung capacity and vital capacity. Hence, the loop shrinks or narrows and shifts towards the right.

Option B: Tracheal stenosis shows a fixed upper airway obstruction pattern on the flow-volume curve. In this condition, there is obstruction and limitation of airflow during both inspiration and expiration. This leads to the flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs of the flow-volume loop. 

Option C: Vocal cord paralysis shows a variable upper airway obstruction pattern on the flow-volume curve. It is characterized by flattening in the inspiratory limb of the loop. 

The image below shows various patterns of flow-volume curves.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1L1 woman at term is admitted to the labor room for normal vaginal delivery. A per vaginal examination was performed once her membranes ruptured, and a pulsatile cord-like structure was felt. An immediate ultrasound revealed that the baby was still alive, and cardiotocography revealed prolonged and variable decelerations. What is the definitive management in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of cord prolapse and the definitive management in this condition is delivery of the baby by cesarean section.

The management algorithm of cord prolapse is based on three important factors:

  • Living or dead baby
  • Maturity of the baby
  • Degree of cervical dilatation

The definitive treatment for cord prolapse is the delivery by cesarean section when the baby is alive and mature as in this clinical scenario. Reconfirming if the baby is alive before the incision is important to prevent unnecessary trauma of surgery.

  • If the baby is dead - 
    • Reconfirmation with ultrasound
    • Spontaneous delivery when death is confirmed
    • Destructive operations are rarely needed
  • If immediate safe vaginal delivery is possible - 
    • When the fetal head is engaged - delivery by forceps. Ventouse is not ideal in such circumstances as it takes a longer time 
    • Breech presentation - the delivery is to be completed by breech extraction
    • Transverse lie - the internal podalic version, followed by breech extraction
  • When immediate safe vaginal delivery is not possible - 
    • Relieve pressure on the cord
    • Oxytocin infusion is stopped
    • Oxygen supplementation and intravenous fluids are given

The contraindications of immediate delivery are fetal death, lethal fetal anomalies, and a pre-viable gestation.

Forceps-assisted (Option A) delivery can be done if deemed quicker and the head is engaged. But, this is not the definitive management. Manual repositioning (Option D) of the cord is done to minimize exposure to the external environment that may induce vasospasm due to colder temperatures. It is rarely used nowadays and Vago's method is preferred.

In Vago's method (Option B) a Foleys catheter is placed and the bladder is filled with >500 mL of saline, and then clamped. The patient’s enlarging bladder provides upward pressure on the fetus and alleviates the compression of the cord and helps decrease uterine contractions. It is generally used to stabilize the mother and baby until definitive management is done. 

Other methods that may be used:

  • Manual elevation of the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the whole hand through the vagina
  • Positioning of the patient in a steep Trendelenburg position, an exaggerated Sim’s position, or knee-chest position as shown below
  • Tocolysis can be considered if there is a prolonged interval before delivery, but is associated with a risk of uterine atony after delivery

Sims postion:

Trendelenburg position:

Knee-chest position:

questions.text: A patient in ICU is started with a blood transfusion. After 20 minutes, the patient starts developing a fever with chills and flank pain. His urine appears red in color. What is the most likely pathophysiology behind this reaction?

choices.text: Preformed IgM antibodies against donor red cells
Inflammatory mediators derived from donor leukocytes
IgG antibodies against previously sensitized antigens
Factors in the transfused blood trigger activation of neutrophils

questions.solution:
The most likely pathophysiology behind this reaction is pre-formed IgM antibodies against donor red cells that fix complement. The clinical scenario describes an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction as the patient has a rapid onset of fever with chills, flank pain, and hemoglobinuria. 

Acute hemolytic reactions are caused due to pre-existing high-affinity IgM antibodies against the blood group antigens on the donor cells. This leads to complement activation and subsequent complement-mediated lysis, intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria. The signs and symptoms are due to complement activation since osmotic lysis of red cells results in hemoglobinuria with the absence of other symptoms of a hemolytic reaction.

When it is suspected, the transfusion should be immediately stopped and the blood bank should be notified about the reaction. The blood bank should evaluate the patient's blood samples for hemolysis and the presence of antibodies. Antibodies can be tested for by direct antiglobulin test (DAT), sometimes called the direct Coombs test. The blood levels of lactate dehydrogenase, indirect bilirubin, and serum haptoglobin should be assessed.

 Non-immunologic reactions:

  1. Fluid overload
  2. Hypothermia
  3. Hypocalcemia due to increased chelation of calcium by citrate
  4. Hyperkalemia due to increased release of potassium from lysed cells
  5. Iron overload
  6. Transient hypotension
  7. Transfusion-mediated immunomodulation- Multiple sittings of transfusion of allogenic blood leads to immunosuppression

Other options:

Option B: Inflammatory mediators derived from donor leukocytes cause febrile non-hemolytic reactions. It can present as chills and is usually evident within 6 hours of transfusion of red cells or platelets. These reactions increase with the storage age of donor blood and can be reduced by taking measures to minimize donor leukocyte contamination. Antipyretics can be used for management.

Option C: IgG antibodies against previously sensitized antigens cause delayed hemolytic reactions. These reactions are associated with a positive Coomb's test and other features of hemolysis like low haptoglobin and elevated lactate dehydrogenase. Antigens like Rh, Kell and Kidd can induce complement activation. But if there is no complement activation, it results in the opsonization of red cells, extravascular hemolysis, and spherocytosis.

Option D: Factors in the transfused blood trigger activation of neutrophils and cause severe and fatal transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI).

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

Related Pearl: Blood Transfusion Reactions

Immunological Transfusion Reactions             

Reaction
(Onset)

 Mechanism Presentation Management

Anaphylactic transfusion reaction

(Seconds-minutes)

Common in IgA deficient recipients 

Shock, respiratory distress, angioedema

Stop transfusion immediately, give epinephrine

Prevention – using IgA deficient plasma and washed cellular blood components

(Within 2-3 hours)

Recipient IgE against donor components causing mast cell activation

Urticaria, flushing, pruritus

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction

(within 6h)

 

(Most common complication of blood transfusion)

Antibodies against donor WBC and HLA antigens (sensitization)

Cytokine accumulation during blood storage

More common in multipally transfused patients and multiparous women

Fever and chills sometimes with mild dyspnoea

Antihistamines and antipyretics

Transfusion can be stopped if symptoms are severe

Prevention: Leukoreduced products

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)

(1-6 hours)

Anti-HLA type 2 antibodies in donor plasma bind recipient WBCs, increase capillary permeability

Hypoxia, non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema

Stop transfusion immediately

Supportive care

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction

(during transfusion to within 24h)

ABO incompatibility

(Type 2 hypersensitivity)

Pre-existing high affinity IgM antibodies rapidly induce complement mediated lysis, intra-vascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria

Fever, chills, flank/back pain

Sense of impending doom

Hemoglobinuria

DIC, Renal failure

Coomb’s test positive, pink plasma

Stop transfusion immediately, aggressively manage with IV fluids

Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction

occurs after 24 hours ( usually 2 weeks )

Recipients have prior exposure to RBC antigens. After the transfusion, anamnestic response results in antibody production

Typically caused by IgG antibodies to foreign protein antigens and are associated with laboratory features of hemolysis.

Mild fever, hemolytic anemia

Coomb’s test positive

Screening for new antibodies positive

Supportive care

Additional transfusions if needed

Non-immune mediated transfusion reactions are as follows:

  • Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO)
  • Hypothermia
  • Electrolyte abnormality- hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia
  • Iron overload
  • Transient hypotension
  • Immunomodulation
  • Blood-borne infections

questions.text:
Match the pictures with the corresponding plant poison.

A - Ricinus communis 

B - Atropa belladonna

C - Calotropis gigantea

D - Digitalis purpurea
questions.solution:
The correctly matched set is given in option A: 1-D, 2-C, 3-A, 4-B.

In the given image: 

  • 1- Digitalis purpurea (Foxglove)
  • 2- Calotropis gigantea
  • 3- Ricinus communis (castor bean)
  • 4- Atropa belladonna (belladonna or deadly nightshade)

Digitalis purpurea is also known as 'foxglove'. Digitalis is a cardioactive steroid that acts by inhibiting the sodium/potassium ATPase pump. Acute toxicity closely resembles that of digoxin and includes early GI symptoms followed by cardiac dysrhythmias. 

Calotropis gigantea is identified by the presence of purple or white flowers. The active principles include uscharin, calotoxin, calactin and calotropin (glycoside). It is an organic irritant. It acts as an abortifacient when applied locally. On external application, it produces an artificial bruise. When ingested, it acts as a gastrointestinal and cerebrospinal poison (not cardiac poison).

Ricinus communis is identified by rose-red softly spiny fruits. The entire plant is poisonous but the seeds are the most poisonous. The poisonous component is toxalbumin ricin. It is a glycoprotein that blocks protein synthesis. The seeds contain the highest level of ricin. The fatal dose is 5 to 10 seeds or 50-100µ ricin.

Ricinus poisoning leads to symptoms such as burning of oral mucosa, salivation, nausea, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea. It may also cause drowsiness, convulsions, delirium, and death

Atropa belladonna- All the parts of the plants are toxic. The active principle is 1-hyoscyamine. It acts by inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine.

Clinical manifestations include anticholinergic symptoms such as tachycardia, hypertension, flushing, dry mouth, mydriasis, and urinary retention. Agitation and delirium are the most serious problems in such patients. 

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

questions.text: A 45-year-old immunocompromised patient presented with fever and breathlessness for 3 weeks. Chest radiograph shows patchy infiltration in the lower lobes bilaterally and the lung biopsy showed the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is CMV-associated pneumonia. The given image shows a cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion surrounded by a clear halo known as owl’s eye appearance. Along with the given clinical scenario, it is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia. 

 

CMV is a β-group herpesvirus. It causes the following conditions:

  • Immunocompetent individuals - asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like infection  
  • Neonates - devastating systemic infections
  • Immunosuppressed individuals - serious, life-threatening, disseminated CMV infections of the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (colitis)

Other options : 

Option A: Invasive aspergillosis is caused by Aspergillus fumigatus. This can occur in prolonged treatment with steroids or in retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs. Voriconazole is the drug of choice.

Option C: Cryptococcal pneumonia is a fungal infection caused by Cryptococcus neoformans predominantly in immunosuppressed individuals and rarely in the immunocompetent population. Pulmonary cryptococcosis in AIDS/ immunosuppressed patients presents as an interstitial lung disease with lymph node enlargement. The histopathological diagnosis is made by identifying encapsulated yeast forms within sections of the inflammatory lung tissue.

Option D: Tuberculosis is associated with well-defined epithelioid granuloma and classical TB symptoms.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman comes for her antenatal check-up. She is in her third trimester now. She is a daily wage worker and reveals that she will continue working during the pregnancy. How much protein would you advise her to consume on a daily basis (RDA)?

RDA: Recommended dietary allowance
questions.solution:
The recommended dietary allowance of protein for a pregnant woman in the third trimester who is a heavy worker is 68 g/day.

According to the national institute of nutrition, the recommended RDA of protein is 46 g per day, regardless of the type of occupation and activity of the woman.

During pregnancy, the RDA of protein is increased in the second and third trimesters:

  • In the second trimester, it increases by 9.5 g. Therefore, the total protein requirement is 46+9.5 = 55.5 g/day per day.
  • In the third trimester, it increases by 22 g. Therefore, the total protein requirement is 46+22 = 68 g of protein per day.

questions.text: The MRI brain of a patient showed extensive damage to the medial undersides of both occipital lobes and the inferior medio-ventral surfaces of the temporal lobes. Which among the following would the patient likely develop?

choices.text: Inability to understand what they are saying

questions.solution:
Lesions to the medial underside of both occipital lobes and medioventral surfaces of the temporal lobes cause prosopagnosia, which is the inability or difficulty to recognize faces.

Prosopagnosia is seen when there is a lesion in the medial undersides of occipital lobes and the inferior medio-ventral surfaces of the temporal lobes.

Tactile agnosia (aka stereognosis) -  Inability to recognize objects by touch, in the presence of intact cutaneous and proprioceptive hand sensation; caused by a lesion in the contralateral parietal lobe.

Other options:

Option A: Inability to understand is seen in Wernicke's aphasia. The patient fails to comprehend the meaning of spoken or written words. The speech is full of jargon and neologisms that do not make sense.

Option B: The inability to recognize familiar voices is called phonagnosia. It is seen after damage to the inferior and lateral parietal regions of the right hemisphere.

Option D: Difficulty in forming words (verbal or written) is Broca's aphasia or motor aphasia. This occurs as a result of a lesion in Broca's area.

Related Pearl: CNS deficits and site of lesions

Term Defnition Site of lesion
Agnosia Inability to accurately perceive objects through normally functioning sensory mechanisms Posterior parietal cortex

Dyslexia

(word blindness)

Inability to interpret their meanings

(the person may be able to see words and even know that they are words but not be able to interpret their meanings)

 Angular gyrus
Aphasia inability to produce and/or understand language

All components of the language network are interconnected with each other and with

surrounding parts of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes. Damage

to this network gives rise to language impairments resulting in aphasia.

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

  Comprehension Repetition of Spoken language Naming Fluency

questions.text: The MR angiography of a patient is shown below. Which of the following structures is predominantly supplied by the artery marked in the image?
questions.solution:
The artery marked in the image of MR angiography is the anterior cerebral artery. It predominantly supplies the corpus callosum.

Circle of Willis is a large arterial anastomosis that unites the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems. It lies in the subarachnoid space within the basal cisterns surrounding the optic chiasma and infundibulum.  

The images below show the MR angiography and the cadaveric image of the Circle of Willis, respectively. 

The anterior cerebral artery is a terminal branch of the internal carotid artery. 

The anterior cerebral arteries course along the great longitudinal fissure, passing around the curve of the genu of the corpus callosum along its upper surface and ends to anastomose with posterior cerebral arteries. It gives the following branches.

Cortical branches  Areas supplied

1. Orbital branches 

  
  • Olfactory cortex
  • Gyrus rectus
  • Medial orbital gyrus
2. Frontal branches
  • Corpus callosum
  • Cingulate gyrus
  • Medial frontal gyrus
  • Paracentral lobule
  • Fornix
 3. Parietal branches
  •  Precuneus
Central branches
  • Rostrum of the corpus callosum
  • Septum pellucidum
  • Anterior part of the putamen, Head of the caudate nucleus and adjacent parts of the internal capsule
 

The cortical branches of the anterior cerebral artery supply the motor and somatosensory areas of the cerebral cortex that represent the lower limb.

Other options:

Option A: The thalamus is supplied by posterior communicating arteries, posterior cerebral arteries, and the basilar artery. 

Option B: The medulla oblongata is supplied by the vertebral artery, anterior and posterior spinal arteries, posterior inferior cerebellar arteries, and basilar artery. 

Option C: The midbrain is supplied by posterior cerebral arteries, superior cerebellar arteries, and the basilar artery. 

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

Related Pearl: Blood supply of Brain

The brain is supplied by Internal Carotid arteries and Vertebrobasilar arteries. 

Areas supplied by various arteries
Anterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves around the corpus callosum within the sagittal fissure

Supply - Dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes

Effects of occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA): 

- Contralateral Paralysis (or weakness) of muscles of the leg and foot - Upper part of motor area affected.

- Contralateral Loss (or dulling) of sensations from the leg and foot - Upper part of the sensory area affected.
Middle Cerebral Artery

Course - Runs within Sylvian fissure

Supply - Lateral convexity of the cerebral cortex

Effects of occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA):

- Contralateral Hemiplegia -  loss of sensations. The face and arms are most affected, foot and leg are spared.  

- Aphasia - Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas affected, especially if the thrombosis is in the left hemisphere in a right-handed person.  

- Contralateral Homonymous hemianopia - due to the involvement of optic radiation.  
Posterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves behind the midbrain

Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe

Effects of occlusion of posterior cerebral artery (PCA):

- Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing - Affected Cortical blood supply > Damage to association cortex of visual area causes visual hallucinations (distortion of colour vision).

Note: Macular sparing is due to collateral circulation from MCA to that cortical region.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is false regarding the modality that is considered the investigation of choice for diagnosis of osteoporosis?

BMD- Bone mineral density

choices.text: T-score of < -1 in the total hip is considered osteoporosis
T-score of < -2.5 in the femoral neck is considered osteoporosis
Bone spurs may cause increased BMD values
Small thin people tend to have less than average BMD

questions.solution:
T-score of < -1 in the total hip is considered osteoporosis is false. 

The investigation of choice for the diagnosis of osteoporosis is DEXA (dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry). A T-score <–2.5 in the lumbar spine, femoral neck, or total hip has been defined as osteoporosis.

DEXA measures the bone mineral density of an individual. In the DEXA technique, two X-ray energies are used to estimate the area of mineralized tissue, and the mineral content is divided by bone area, which partially corrects for body and bone size. However, as this is a two-dimensional method, the correction is not adequate and small slim people tend to have lower BMD as compared to the average.

Also, bone spurs, tend to falsely increase bone density, and are a particular problem in measuring spine BMD in older individuals.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text:
During a biochemical screening, an obstetrician identifies that a woman is carrying a fetus with trisomy 18. Which of the following markers would likely be low in this screening test?

1. Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein
2. Beta human chorionic gonadotropin
3. Unconjugated estriol
4. Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 2, 3, and 4. All of the above-given findings are decreased in trisomy 18 (Edward's syndrome). Maternal serum AFP, beta hCG, unconjugated estriol, and pregnancy-associated plasma protein A levels are reduced.

Combined first-trimester screening tests: It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks gestation. It comprises of:

  • Human chorionic gonad­otropin (hCG)
  • Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
  • Sonographic measurement of the nuchal translucency (NT)

The abnormalities seen on the triple screen are tabulated below:

 Parameter Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal

Quadruple testing is done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. It comprises:

  • Maternal serum AFP
  • Human chorionic gonadotropin
  • Unconjugated estriol
  • Inhibin A

Trisomy 18 or Edwards’ syndrome is a condition characterised by intellectual disability, micrognathia, low-set ears, rocker-bottom feet, and congenital heart diseases. The most characteristic finding is a clenched fist with overlapping fingers i.e. the index finger overlies the third and fourth fingers, while the fifth finger overlaps the fourth. This syndrome is also associated with polyhydramnios and a single umbilical artery.

questions.text: Which of the following fungal infections can be diagnosed by using β 1-3 glucan assay?
questions.solution:
Aspergillosis can be diagnosed by β 1-3 glucan assay.

The test detects the presence of (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) which is an abundant cell wall polysaccharide found in most fungi, except those which lack the glucan entirely or produce it at a minimal level like Cryptococcus neoformans, Zygomycetes like mucor species and Blastomyces dermatitidis.

It is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) designed to detect beta D glucan by using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes. 1,3 Beta D Glucan level of ≥80 pg/ \mL is considered a positive result. They are mainly used for invasive candidiasis, aspergillosis, and Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia.

questions.text: A new screening test for detecting cervical cancer is being studied in a group of 100 women.  60 women tested negative and 40 tested positive.  Among the women who tested positive by the new test, 30 were positive and among the women who tested negative, 10 were having the disease. What is the positive predictive value of the test?
questions.solution:
The positive predictive value is 75%

The data given in the question is tabulated as follows:

  Diseased Not diseased Total
Test positive 30 (TP) 10 (FP) 40
Test negative 10 (FN) 50 (TN) 60
Total 40 60 100

TP - True positive, FP - False positive, FN - False negative, TN - True negative.

Positive predictive value (PPV) = TP/(TP + FP) x 100.

Here PPV = 30/(30+10) x 100 = 30/40 x 100 = 75%

Predictive value of a positive test:

It indicates the probability that a person with a positive test result truly has the disease. Predictive value is affected by sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence. It is highly related to the prevalence of a disease. The predictive value of a positive test will be more accurate if the disease is more prevalent and vice-versa.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: The histopathological study of a cancerous ulcerative skin lesion is shown below. What kind of an ulcer edge is this pathology likely to have on gross examination?
questions.solution:
The above image showing atypical tumor cells and keratin pearls is indicative of squamous cell carcinoma. It commonly presents with an everted edge.

SCC is the second most common skin cancer. The primary risk factor and driving force for the development of this common cancer is UV exposure (ex: gardener), previous chronic wounds, or chemical carcinogens.

Variants : 

  • Bowen's disease
  • Erythroplasia of Queyrat

SCC initially presents as smooth nodular, verrucous, papillomatous lesions. All these lesions later ulcerate and have a characteristic everted edge and are surrounded by inflamed, indurated skin.

Keratin pearls are seen on histopathologic examination:

 

Treatment : 

  • Surgical excision is the treatment of choice.
  • Other modalities include cautery ablation, cryotherapy, drug therapy including imiquimod, and radiation therapy.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents with a dull aching pain in the right upper quadrant and pruritus. He also had jaundice, clay-colored stools, dark urine, and weight loss for the past three weeks. Medical records show a history of infection with Clonorchis sinensis. Laboratory investigations and the gross appearance of the liver are given below. Which of the following types of cancer is this patient most likely suffering from?

Lab investigations:

  • Elevated CA 19-9
  • Immunohistochemistry (IHC)- positive for cytokeratin 7
questions.solution:
The patient has cholestatic symptoms (jaundice, clay-colored stools, and darkened urine) along with a history of infection with Clonorchis. The image shows a large non-encapsulated, well-demarcated, white-tan nodular intrahepatic mass. These features point toward the diagnosis of cholangiocarcinoma, which is an adenocarcinoma.

Cholangiocarcinoma (CCA) is the second most common primary malignant tumor of the liver after HCC. It is a malignancy of the biliary tree, arising from bile ducts within and outside of the liver.

CA 19-9 is a tumor marker and cytokeratin 7 is an IHC marker expressed in cholangiocarcinoma. 

The risk factors include the following:

  • Infestation by liver flukes (particularly Opisthorchis and Clonorchis species).
  • Chronic inflammatory diseases of the large bile ducts, such as
    • primary sclerosing cholangitis
    • hepatolithiasis
    • fibropolycystic liver disease
  • Hepatitis B and C or non-alcoholic fatty liver disease - also have a higher risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) 
  • Other less-established, potential risk factors include:
    • inflammatory bowel disease
    • obesity
    • cirrhosis
    • diabetes
    • alcohol and tobacco. 

Precursor lesions: Biliary intraepithelial neoplasias, mucinous cystic neoplasms, and intraductal papillary biliary neoplasia

Histopathology:

Extrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma generally presents as small lesions and causes obstructive lesions at the time of diagnosis. Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinomas track along with the intrahepatic portal system and create a branching tumor within a portion of the liver.

The tumors are grey, firm nodules within the bile duct wall while some may be diffusely infiltrative lesions. Most tumors are moderate to well-differentiated with clearly defined glandular/tubular structures lined by malignant epithelial cells

They incite marked desmoplasia and appear to be firm due to the desmoplastic reaction. Regardless of the location, these tumors are typical adenocarcinomas that often produce mucin. Lymphovascular and perineural invasion lead to distant metastasis. 

Other options:

Option A- Angiosarcoma is a type of sarcoma which occurs in association with vinyl chloride exposure. The gross features include hemorrhagic necrosis, cystic degeneration, fibrosis, and apparent multicentricity.

Option B- Hepatic lymphoma is a rare disease seen in middle-aged men in association with Hepatitis B and C, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Most cases present as diffuse large cell B-lymphomas. It usually appears as a pale whitish tumour with central calcification. 

Option D- Adenosquamous carcinoma is a type of cholangiocarcinoma that is seen in a very small percentage of patients and is unlikely to be the most likely type.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old girl presented with cyanosis that did not improve with oxygen administration. On further probing, she revealed that she has been using large amounts of a 'numbing cream' called EMLA. What will be the appropriate management for this patient?

EMLA: Eutectic mixture of local anesthetics
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette depicts a scenario of cyanosis due to methemoglobinemia induced by the application of a large amount of EMLA cream. The most appropriate management, in this case, would be the administration of IV methylene blue.

EMLA is a eutectic mixture of local anesthetics containing a mixture of 2.5% lidocaine and 2.5% prilocaine. Methemoglobinemia is a serious side effect of the application of large amounts of prilocaine. Prilocaine is metabolized to O-toluidine, which converts hemoglobin (Fe2+) to methemoglobin (Fe3+) producing methemoglobinemia. This side effect is dose-dependent. 

Pulse oximetry in methemoglobinemia falsely shows 80-85% irrespective of higher arterial oxygen saturation. 

Treatment of methemoglobinemia includes reduction of methemoglobin to hemoglobin by intravenous methylene blue (1–2 mg/kg of a 1% solution over 5 min).

questions.text:
What is the effect of the mechanism of enzyme inhibition shown in the image below?

Km: Michaelis constant
questions.solution:
The given mechanism shows non-competitive enzyme inhibition. In this type of inhibition, Km remains the same.

In enzyme kinetics, Vmax is the rate of the reaction when the enzyme is saturated with the substrate. Km (Michaelis constant) is the substrate concentration at which the enzyme achieves ½ Vmax.

Km indicates the affinity of the enzyme to the substrate. When the enzyme has a high affinity for the substrate, ½ Vmax is achieved at a lower substrate concentration/ lower Km.

In non-competitive inhibition, an inhibitor binds to the allosteric site of the enzyme. This leads to a conformational change in the substrate-binding site which prevents the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. The free enzyme molecules have the same amount of affinity to the substrate because of which Km remains the same.

Since the inhibitor and the substrate bind to different sites, increasing the substrate concentration will not have any effect on reversing the inhibition. Therefore, non-competitive inhibition is considered irreversible inhibition. As some of the enzyme molecules become irreversibly inactive, Vmax is reduced in non-competitive inhibition.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: Based on the pattern of postmortem staining shown in the image below, which of the following positions was the body in at the time of death?
questions.solution:
The postmortem staining/lividity in the image provided is characteristic of hanging as it is more marked in the legs, hands, and external genitalia.

Postmortem staining is usually seen in the dependent parts of the body wherein there is gravitational pooling of blood. 

Medicolegal importance - Postmortem staining and its fixation can be helpful to ascertain the time since death. It can also be used to estimate the body's position at the time of death and if the body has been relocated since. 

Other options:

Option A- In supine position (shown below), postmortem staining is limited to the neck and entire back except for the points of contact between the body and the ground (occipital areas, scapulae, buttocks, calves, and heels). The absence of lividity in these areas, due to external compression of blood vessels, is termed contact pallor.

 

Option B- In the prone position, postmortem staining is marked on the anterior surface of the body associated with the presence of Tardieu spots. 

Option C- In a body lying on the side, postmortem staining will is marked on that particular side due to the pooling of blood in the dependent parts.

questions.text: Which of the following extraocular muscles and their innervations is incorrectly matched?
questions.solution:
The superior oblique is innervated by the contralateral IV cranial nucleus.

The nuclei controlling the superior rectus and superior oblique muscles have crossed projections.

There are seven extraocular muscles present in the eye. They are:

  • Levator palpebrae superioris - elevates the upper eyelids
  • Four recti muscles - superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti
  • Two oblique muscles - superior and inferior oblique

The muscles originate from the back of the orbit in a common tendinous ring called the annulus of Zinn and are inserted into the sclera.

All the extraocular muscles are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

  • Lateral rectus - supplied by the abducens (VI) nerve
  • Superior oblique - supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve

Related Pearl: Extraocular Muscles and Their Actions

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of secondary active transport?

choices.text: Movement of oxygen across cell membranes
Proton pumps in the gastric glands of the stomach

questions.solution:
Sodium-Iodide (Na-I) symporter in the thyrocytes is an example of secondary active transport.

Secondary active transport is a type of active transport where a primary active transport mechanism creates a difference in ionic concentrations across the cell membrane. This difference in concentration acts as a driving force for the movement of other ions across the membrane. 

An example of this mechanism is the Na-I symporter in the thyroid gland which is responsible for iodine uptake into the follicular cells of the thyroid. It is mainly present in the basolateral membranes of the thyrocytes. It transports two Na+ ions and one I- ion into the cell against the concentration gradient. The energy for this transport is derived from the Na+-K+ ATPase pump.

Na+-K+ ATPase pumps sodium outside the cell and causes low intracellular sodium concentration. This causes sodium to enter the cell by facilitated diffusion. Along with sodium, iodide ions also enter the cell via the  Na-I symporter. Since the energy to transport sodium and iodide ions in Na-I symporter is derived from Na+-K+ ATPase pump, this is called secondary active transport.

Other options:

Option A. GLUT transporters in the enterocytes are examples of facilitated diffusion. The molecules are transported via carrier-mediated proteins along the concentration gradient. This transport does not require energy.

Option B. Movement of oxygen across cell membranes in our body is an example of simple diffusion. In simple diffusion, the molecules pass directly through the cell membrane along the concentration gradient. It does not require energy and is not carrier-mediated. Examples include the movement of water, carbon dioxide, and nitrogen across the cell membrane. 

Option D. Proton pumps in the gastric glands of the stomach are examples of primary active transport. Primary active transport obtains energy from the hydrolysis of ATP to transport molecules against an electrochemical gradient. 

Related Pearl: Characteristics of different types of transport

Type Simple diffusion Facilitated diffusion Primary active transport Secondary active transport Cotransport Secondary active transport Countertransport
Electrochemical gradient Downhill Downhill Uphill Uphill Uphill
Carrier mediated No Yes Yes Yes Yes
Metabolic energy No No Yes Indirect Indirect
Na+ gradient No No -- Yes (same direction) Yes (opposite direction)

Inhibits Na+-K+ pump

 		 -- -- Inhibits Inhibits  Inhibits

Related Pearl: Characteristics of Carrier Mediated Transport

Properties Description
Stereospecificity For example- D-Glucose is transport by facilitated diffusion but not L-isomer. Simple diffusion in contrast will not distinguish between the two.
Saturation The transport rate increases as the concentration of the solute increases until the carriers are saturated (Tm).
Competition Structurally related solutes compete for transport sites on carrier molecules.

questions.text: A mother brings her infant to the pediatrician, worried about the noticeably small mandible of the child. Investigations reveal hypoplasia of the mandible and malformation of the ​middle ear. These features can be attributed to a developmental defect involving which of the following pharyngeal arches?
questions.solution:
The above-mentioned features are suggestive of the first arch syndrome, which can be attributed to a developmental defect involving the first pharyngeal arch. 

The first pharyngeal arch is known as the mandibular arch. The artery associated with the first arch is the maxillary artery and the nerve supply is provided by the maxillary and mandibular branches of the trigeminal nerve.

The derivatives of the first pharyngeal arch are:

i. Skeletal derivatives: It has 2 prominences,

  • Mandibular prominence (ventral)- The mandibular prominence has two components:
    • Meckel's cartilage- It forms the malleus, incus, spine of the sphenoid, and the sphenomandibular and anterior malleolar ligaments.
    • Mesenchyme surrounding the Meckel's cartilage undergoes membranous ossification to form the mandible.
  • Maxillary prominence (dorsal). The mesenchyme of this process forms the maxilla, zygomatic bone, and part of the temporal bone.

ii. Muscular derivatives include:

  • tensor tympani
  • tensor veli palatini
  • muscles of mastication
  • anterior belly of digastric
  • mylohyoid

Pharyngeal pouch derivatives include the auditory tube and middle ear cavity.

  • Left side: Arch of the aorta from the left common carotid to the left subclavian arteries
6th Recurrent laryngeal of Vagus (X)
  • Arytenoid cartilages
 		  
  • All intrinsic muscles of the larynx (except the cricothyroid muscle)
  • Right side: right pulmonary artery 
  • Left side: left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus

questions.text:
The following image shows the chemiosmotic mechanism and the bioenergetics involved in biological oxidation. Given below are a few toxic compounds known to inhibit the Electron Transport Chain. Which of these would inhibit the complex marked in the image?
  1. Hydrogen sulfide
  2. Atractyloside
  3. Carbon monoxide
  4. Oligomycin
  5. Cyanide
  6. Antimycin A
questions.solution:
The inhibitors of Complex IV of the electron transport chain are hydrogen sulfide, carbon monoxide, and cyanide.

Electron transport chain (ETC) is the final pathway by which all the electrons derived from the oxidation of carbohydrates, fatty acids, and amino acids are directed toward the final reaction with oxygen to form water and ATP.

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: A multiparous woman has a previous history of trauma during labor with injury to the structure marked 'A' in the image below. According to De Lancey's classification, which level of uterine support is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as 'A' in the given image depicts pubocervical fascia. Thus according to DeLancey's classification, level 2 of uterine support is affected in this patient.

DeLancey introduced a three-level system of genital tract supports:

  • Level I includes uterosacral and cardinal ligaments. Damage to these ligaments leads to uterine descent, enterocoele, and vault prolapse.
  • Level II includes pelvic fascia, paracolpos,arcus tendineus, pubocervical, and rectovaginal fascia. Damage to these structures leads to cystocele and rectocele.
  • Level III includes levator ani muscle and its damage leads to urethrocele, gaping introitus, and deficient perineum.

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

 

Related Pearl: Supports of the uterus

A. Primary supports

  • Muscular or active support of the uterus:
    • Pelvic diaphragm
    • Perineal body
    • Urogenital diaphragm
  • Ligamentous (fibromuscular or mechanical) support:
    • Transverse cervical ligaments of Mackenrodt or cardinal ligament
    • Uterosacral ligament
    • Round ligament of the uterus
    • Pubocervical ligament
    • Uterine axis

B. Secondary supports formed by peritoneal ligaments:

  • Broad ligament
  • Uterovesical fold of peritoneum
  • Rectovaginal fold of peritoneum

questions.text: An 18-year-old adolescent is being evaluated for primary amenorrhea. On examination, she has normal development of secondary sexual characteristics. Her ultrasound abdomen and pelvis reveal normal ovaries but an absence of the uterus and upper part of the vagina. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a girl with primary amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characteristics and ultrasonography showing normal ovaries and an absent uterus and upper of the vagina is suggestive of Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome. 

Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome or Mullerian agenesis is a condition wherein there is a congenital absence of the uterus and the vagina. The patients have a Karyotype of 46 XX, so the gonads present are ovaries. 

The patient's secondary sexual characteristics are well-developed with normal external genitalia. The ovaries are normal but have an absence of the uterus and the upper part of the vagina. The patients usually have a blind-ended vaginal pouch. 

Diagnosis is made with the help of pelvic sonography, MRI, and laparoscopy. Patients may have rudimentary Mullerian bulbs without an endometrial cavity. 

Other options:

Option A: Androgen insensitivity syndrome, also known as testicular feminization syndrome, has a karyotype of 46XY, so the gonads present are testes. Secondary sexual characteristics like the development of axillary hair and pubic hair are absent in these females. However, breast development is adequate due to the conversion of androgen into estrogen during puberty.

Option B: In Turner syndrome, short stature with poor development of secondary sexual characters will be seen. It has a karyotype of 45 XO. Female genital organs like the vagina, uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries are present.

Option C: Swyer syndrome is a type of male pseudohermaphrodite. As there is gonadal dysgenesis in these patients, they fail to secrete testosterone and antimullerian hormone (AMH). This results in the development of female genital organs i.e. uterus and cervix are developed. They present with primary amenorrhoea, absence of secondary sex characters, and female external genitalia. 

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

questions.text:
An elderly woman is rushed to the emergency room following an episode of syncope. Her caretaker reports that the patient had multiple episodes of loose stools and vomiting for the past 2 days. Her blood investigations and ECG are given below. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

Serum sodium: 140 mEq/L
Serum potassium: 7.1 mEq/L
Serum chloride: 100 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen creatinine ratio: 26.9
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the ECG showing tall T waves in all the leads and the laboratory investigations showing serum potassium of 7.1 mEq/L are suggestive of hyperkalemia. The next best step in the management is intravenous calcium gluconate.

This patient has acute kidney injury resulting from dehydration. Her BUN: Creatinine ratio is 26.9 which is >20:1 which suggests prerenal azotemia. Acute kidney injury results in impaired excretion of potassium resulting in hyperkalemia.

Although ECG changes are not specific and hyperkalemia may occur without significant ECG changes, the typical changes seen in ECG due to hyperkalemia are sequential and include:

  • Peaking of the T waves
  • ST-segment depression
  • Widening of the PR and QRS intervals
  • Sine waves
  • Ventricular fibrillation and asystole

The presence of cardiac toxicity is a serious manifestation of hyperkalemia and requires immediate cardiac stabilization with intravenous calcium gluconate. Calcium gluconate should also be initiated in all patients with serum potassium >6.5 mEq/L and patients with muscular weakness.

The recommended dose is 10 mL of 10% calcium gluconate infused intravenously over 2–3 min with cardiac monitoring. The dose should be repeated if there is no change in ECG findings or if findings recur after stabilization.

Treatment of hyperkalemia involves the following:

  1. Administer intravenous calcium gluconate, which raises the threshold and reduces excitability. It is cardioprotective.
  2. Administer regular insulin with dextrose. The insulin will reduce the serum potassium concentration by causing an intracellular shift. The dextrose will counteract the hypoglycemic effects of insulin.
  3. Provide salbutamol nebulization, which will also shift potassium inside the cell.
  4. Remove potassium with calcium-based resins, diuretics, or hemodialysis.

Other options:

Option A: Patiromer is a potassium-binding drug that can be used in chronic hyperkalemia. It doesn't play a role in acute hyperkalemia due to acute kidney injury like in this patient. Sodium zirconium cyclosili­cate and sodium polystyrene are other potassium-binding agents.

Option C: Hemodialysis may be needed in patients with acute or chronic renal failure to remove excess potassium, especially in patients who are oliguric. However, it should be undertaken after cardiac stabilization.

questions.text: A histological slide is shown to medical students. The type of cartilage depicted in the given slide stained with Trichrome-Masson stain is seen in _______.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a section of fibrocartilage stained with Trichrome - Masson stain. It is seen in the acetabular labrum.

Fibrocartilage is an intermediate between dense fibrous connective tissue (tendon and ligaments) and hyaline cartilage. It consists of bundles of collagen fibres (both type I and II) with rows of chondrocytes present between the bundles. They are not covered by perichondrium.

Fibrocartilage is found in:

  • Intervertebral discs
  • Pubic symphysis
  • Manubriosternal joint
  • Menisci of the knee
  • Glenoid and acetabular labra
  • Lining of the bony grooves for tendons
  • Articular disc of temporomandibular and sternoclavicular joint

On microscopy, fibrocartilage can be identified by:

  • Presence of chondrocytes
  • Matrix containing abundant collagen fibres

 Other options:

Option A: Arytenoid cartilages, except its apices, are mainly composed of hyaline cartilage.

Option C and D: Auricle (pinna) and apices of the arytenoid cartilages are composed of elastic cartilage.

 

Note: The colour of cartilage should not be considered while deciding its type, as it largely depends on the type of stain used. Instead, the structure or organisation of the cartilage tissue should be considered.

3 types of cartilages: Hyaline cartilage, elastic cartilage, and fibrocartilage. 

  • Hyaline cartilage (except the subtype of articular cartilage) and elastic cartilage have perichondrium
  • Fibrocartilage does not have perichondrium. 

The following are the images of Hyaline cartilage and Elastic cartilage respectively.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. On examination, you note flexion, abduction, external rotation, and lengthening of the lower limb. Which of the following radiographic findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient presenting with flexion, abduction, external rotation, and lengthening of the lower limb is suggestive of anterior dislocation of the hip which is represented in radiograph 3 of the given image.

Anterior dislocation of the hip is less common than posterior hip dislocations and accounts for about 10-20% of all hip dislocations. This injury is usually sustained following a high-energy accident.

On physical examination, the affected limb will be abducted and externally rotated. It is also slightly flexed. Additionally, a prominent anterior bulge will be present either in the pubic region or in the groin region.

According to the position assumed by the femoral head, anterior dislocation of the hip can further be classified as:

  • Type I - Superior or pubic
  • Type II - Inferior or obturator

Radiological findings include:

  • The displaced femoral head will appear larger than the normal side
  • As the thigh is externally rotated lesser trochanter is more prominent
  • A lateral view X-ray will be confirmatory. 

Treatment of anterior dislocation includes a closed reduction under sedation or general anesthesia. If closed reduction fails, an open procedure may be planned. 

The given image shows a patient with an externally rotated, abducted, and slightly flexed left leg due to anterior dislocation of the hip:

 

Other options:

Radiograph 1-  Intertrochanteric fracture of the femur- This is usually sustained following a fall or RTA and the leg is short and externally rotated. Clinical findings are more marked than the neck of femur fractures.

Radiograph 2- Posterior dislocation of the hip- This is commonly seen following dashboard injuries and in this condition, the patient presents with flexion, adduction, and internal rotation deformity.

Radiological findings include:

  • The femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • The femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • The lesser trochanter is not visualized
  • The femoral head and posterior acetabular wall fractures may also be seen 

Radiograph 4- Fracture neck of the femur - This can present with shortening and external rotation of the limb.

Radiological findings include:

  • Fracture in the neck of femur
  • Break in the medial cortex
  • External rotation of the femur with the lesser trochanter appearing more prominent
  • Displacement of the greater trochanter
  • Break in the trabecular stream
  • Break in the Shenton's line

Related Pearl: Anterior and posterior dislocation of the hip

  Anterior dislocation Posterior dislocation

Type of injury Deceleration injury/ Fall from height Dashboard injury
Attitude of the limb Flexion, abduction, external rotation (FABER) Flexion, adduction, internal rotation (FADIR)
Length of the limb Lengthened Shortened
Radiological findings
  • Femoral head may be seen inferior to the acetabulum
  • Femoral head appears larger than normal 
  • Lesser trochanter is prominent
  • Femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • Femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • Lesser trochanter is not visualised

questions.text: Identify the technique shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows each chromosome pair with a unique color, indicative of multicolor FISH. 

Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH) is a simple technique for the detection of specific genetic information on morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes.

Other options:

Option A: G banding is used for chromosomal identification using dark and light bands.

Option C: Southern blotting is a technique used to detect insertions and deletions in a DNA sequence.

Option D: DNA sequencing is used to detect Mendelian disorders, cancers, acute myeloid leukemia, etc.

Related Pearl: Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH)

It is a simple technique for the detection of specific genetic information on a morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes.

The fluorescent probes are added to cells usually arrested in the metaphase stage of cell division (when every chromosome is separately).

Types of FISH:

1) Chromosomal painting: Each chromosome is identified by using a different colour of the fluorescent probe, however, each chromosome does not have a unique colour. Since the fluorescent dyes are limited.

2) Multicolour FISH: 23 distinct fluorescent colours made by mixing 5 fluorophores. Thus each chromosome is identified by a unique colour. It is also known as spectral karyotyping (SKY). It offers various advantages such as

  • Detects structural and numeric abnormalities in chromosomes.
  • Detects gene amplification and subtle microdeletions
  • Maps a newly isolated gene to its correct chromosomal loci

However, this process requires prior knowledge of the genes and chromosomes.

3) Interphase FISH: It is a rapid procedure of FISH, wherein growing cells are not needed. It is used in prenatal diagnosis and in tumour diagnosis.

The image shown is of a Multicolor FISH also known as Spectral karyotyping with a unique colour to each chromosome pair.

questions.text: The proposed novel non-pharmacological therapies for the treatment of resistant hypertension include:

choices.text: Radiofrequency ablation of the renal parasympathetic nerves
Radiofrequency ablation of the renal sympathetic nerves

questions.solution:
The proposed novel non-pharmacological therapies for the treatment of resistant hypertension include endovascular ablation of renal sympathetic nerves.

The novel non-pharmacological therapies for the treatment of resistant hypertension include endovascular ablation of renal sympathetic nerves and device-assisted carotid receptor activation. However, trials are ongoing and clinical application is awaited until they take a primary role in the management of resistant hypertension.

Renal denervation is a minimally invasive procedure while carotid baroreceptor stimulation is a surgical procedure. 

Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure persistently >140/90 mmHg despite taking three or more antihypertensive agents, including a diuretic.

Resistant hypertension is more common in patients aged >60 years than in younger patients. Resistant hypertension may be related to:

  • Pseudohypertension- high office blood pressure and lower home blood pressure.
  • Non-adherence to therapy.
  • Identifiable causes of hypertension such as obesity and excessive alcohol intake.
  • Secondary causes of hypertension.

Evaluation for resistant hypertension includes monitoring of blood pressure at home to determine if office blood pressure represents similar results. Extensive investigations for all secondary causes of hypertension must be done.

Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists like spironolactone have been found to be the most effective add-on drugs for the treatment of resistant hypertension.

Increased sympathetic activity is often associated with resistant hypertension. Hence, renal denervation or carotid baroreceptor stimulation are being discussed as potential non-pharmacological forms of treating the condition.

Lorundrostat, an aldosterone synthase inhibitor, demonstrated clinically significant blood pressure reduction in phase 2 and 3 clinical trials for resistant hypertension patients.

 

Related Pearl: American Heart Association (AHA) 2019 guidelines for hypertension management

According to the AHA hypertension guidelines, 2019, pharmacologic treatment for hypertension is recommended

  • In patients who have ≥10% estimated 10year ASCVD risk, when BP ≥ 130/80 mmHg 
  • In patients who have <10% estimated 10year ASCVD risk when BP ≥ 140/90 mmHg 

 ASCVD - Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease

ASCVD risk is calculated using a calculator provided by the American Heart Association.

 

Lifestyle modifications in the management of hypertension

Intervention Goal Impact on BP
1. Weight reduction The best goal is ideal body weight -5 mmHg
2. Dietary sodium restriction
  • Total sodium - <1.5g/day (AHA 2019 guidelines)
  • Total NaCl (salt) intake - <6g/day
 -5/6 mmHg
3. Enhanced potassium intake 3.5 - 5g/day -4/5 mmHg
4. DASH dietary pattern  high in vegetables, fruits, low-fat dairy products, whole grains, poultry, fish, and nuts and low in sweets, sugar-sweetened beverages, red meats, and saturated and total fat. -11 mmHg
5. Physical activity Aerobic exercise, dynamic resistance and isometric resistance -4-8 mmHg
6. Moderation in alcohol consumption In individuals who drink alcohol - ≤ 2 drinks/ day for men and ≤ 1 drink/ day for women -4 mmHg

DASH – Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension

 

Target BP in hypertensives:

Clinical condition BP Goal, mm Hg
Clinical CVD or 10 year ASCVD risk  > 10% <130/80
No clinical CVD and 10 year ASCVD risk < 10% <130/80
Adults with CKD <130/80
Adults with Type 2 DM  <130/80

questions.text:
The following three MR images of the head taken in the sagittal plane are given to you. Match the image to the MR imaging technique used.
  1. T1 weighted
  2. T2 weighted
  3. STIR
  4. FLAIR
questions.solution:
Image 1 - T2 weighted MRI, image 2 - T1 weighted MRI, and image 3 is a STIR MRI.

By altering the sequence of pulses and the scanning parameters, different properties of the tissue can be assessed. These properties are referred to as the weighting of the scan. T1-weighted images and T2-weighted images are two types of imaging sequences with differences in image contrast.

T1 weighted images:

  • Fluid appears dark (blood, edema, CSF)
  • Fat appears white

T2 weighted images:

  • Fluid appears white 
  • Fat appears dark

STIR- Short tau inversion recovery or short TI inversion recovery

  • Inversion recovery time is short and is used to null signal from fat.
  • Fat appears dark
  • Highly sensitive to detect musculoskeletal disease, degenerative changes, MS lesions, and vertebral metastasis
  • More prone to motion artifacts. Therefore not used in the imaging of the thoracic spine

FLAIR (fluid-attenuated inversion recovery):

  • It is a T2 weighted sequence with a long inversion recovery time that suppresses signals from the fluid.
  • Fluid appears dark
  • Fat appears dark
  • Motion artifacts in CSF are removed

 

Note: CT can be differentiated from MRI depending on the appearance of bone. Bones appear white on CT, whereas, they appear dark on MRI.

The image below shows a CT scan of the neck (cervical bones appear white):
