questions.text: Identify the condition in which the given type of hypersensitivity reaction is implicated.
questions.solution:
The given image illustrates a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction that is implicated in systemic lupus erythematosus.

Type 3 hypersensitivity reaction occurs due to deposition of antigen-antibody complexes which in turn triggers compliment activation. Examples of type 3 hypersensitivity reactions include:

  • Reactive arthritis.
  • Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis.
  • Polyarteritis nodosa.
  • Serum sickness.
  • Arthus reaction.

Other options:

Option A: Atopic dermatitis is an example of type 1 hypersensitivity reaction

Option B: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia is an example of type 2 hypersensitivity reaction

Option D: Multiple sclerosis is an example of type 4 hypersensitivity reaction

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft 

Related Pearl: Examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity

Type IV Hypersensitivity Reactions 

  • Tuberculin reaction
  • Lepromin test
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Chronic graft rejection
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Type I lepra reaction
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Psoriasis

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with lesions on her face as shown in the image. Similar lesions were absent in the chest and back. What management plan is suitable for her?
questions.solution:
The image shows typical erythematous papules and small nodules along with a few whiteheads are suggestive of moderate acne vulgaris. It should be treated with oral antibiotics and topical retinoids.

The severity of acne can be classified as:

Mild Open and closed comedones with few inflammatory papules and pustules
Moderate Papules and pustules mainly on the face, occasional inflamed nodules on the chest and back also
Severe Many large, painful nodules and pustules

The clinical severity and approach to treatment are decided based on the type of lesion and based on extensiveness.

Only comedonal types can be treated with topical retinoids.

Papulopustular type can be treated with topical retinoid combined with an antibiotic (topical or oral) based on severity. More oily skin and the occurrence of nodules should prompt oral antibiotics.

Nodular or conglobate type can be treated with oral isotretinoin.

questions.text: What is the stain used in the given preparation for demonstrating H. pylori?
questions.solution:
The given slide shows the GI mucosa stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli (Helicobacter pylori).

Helicobacter pylori is a gram-negative rod and contains flagella. It is a risk factor for peptic ulcer disease, mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma, and gastric adenocarcinoma. It causes gastric injury by releasing various virulence factors like γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT), cytotoxin-associated gene A (cagA) product, virulence components vacuolating toxin (vacA), and lipopolysaccharides.

Important tests for the detection of H.Pylori are:

  • Rapid urease test
  • Histology
  • Culture
  • Serology
  • Urea breath test
  • Stool antigen test

Other options:

Masson trichrome stain demonstrating pulmonary hypertensive arteriopathy is shown in the image below:

 

Von Kossa stain demonstrating calcium and iron-containing Michaelis-Gutman bodies (MG bodies) in malakoplakia is shown in the image given below:

 

Alcian blue staining of mucin in Barret's mucosa is shown in the image given below:
